I'd recommend to buy the base game since after buying the Golden edition, which PROMISES access to the season pass and all content in said season pass, I don't have access to both DLCs, and the T-Bone bundle, and I don't even have access to the skin packs. That being said, regardless of the issues that lie in the season pass, the game is great. The story is quite intriguing, and the combat is fun. It has a myriad of side missions to do, and a research (skill) tree that really makes you feel like a better hacker the more you progress. Don't buy the season pass or anything other than the base game though.

[h1]Massive step down from Watch Dogs 1[/h1]

[quote]Context: I’ve completed Watch Dogs 2 about a week ago, but last played Watch Dogs 1 ~22 months ago, so my memories of it might be fuzzy[/quote]

Watch Dogs 2 is an “ok” game, ok enough that I completed it (~35-38 hours), but it lacks heavily in three critical areas in which Watch Dogs 1 didn’t (at least not that much): story, game design and balance.

[h2]Story[/h2]

Story in Watch Dogs 1 is memorable, makes logical sense and makes you want to play more to uncover it. Story of Watch Dogs 2 is bullshit:

[list]
    [*]You complete the entrance test to DedSec (hacker organization, member of which you become), so they kidnap you just to let you know that you are in. What?
    [*]DedSec is not trying to be secretive. They shoot video addresses with their real faces and basically everyone knows who you are. You can here something along the lines: “What is DedSec doing here?”, “DedSec shouldn’t be here” when doing missions from people in buildings, yet none of them are doing anything about you.
    [*]The premise “we need more followers to take down Blume” is not bad by itself, but it is entirely empty words. You “take down Blume” linearly, as you complete main missions, independent of how many followers you get in side missions.
    [*]They try to get followers by doing good stuff, yet some of the stuff they do is completely random and doesn’t portray them as “good guys”. Like: let’s steal the car used for movie shooting. Or: let’s hijack popular singer, to prevent his deal with a billionaire.
    [*]Some enemy says something and DedSec reputation plummets … Wait, what happened? So they go to hacking event, win and now everyone believes in DedSec again … Wait what?
    [*]So many seemingly random characters. Who are they? Who is Miranda? At some point [spoiler]Horatio[/spoiler] dies and the entire DedSec team is sad about it. Meanwhile I was like: who even is that dude? Watching a speed-run, he indeed was featured in one of the missions, but nearly not enough to remember and care about him as a player.
    [*]DedSec met some of its arch-rivals a few times. Why didn’t they try to kill each other all those times? (And they killed a ton of people throughout the game) Why did they need to wait until the final mission?
[/list]

Almost none of it makes sense.

[h2]Game Design[/h2]

There are just so many missions (especially side missions, optional items) which are of type: “climb to the roof” (to pick up or do something) and most of the times it is incredibly annoying to do it, especially annoying after you do it a couple of times. One of such mission’s walkthrough video’s top comment says exactly the same, so I’m not the only one who thinks so.

Watch Dogs 1 had cool police chase sequences, where there used to be a lot of things you could hack on the road: you could enter a road and then immediately close a passage behind you. This barely exists in Watch Dogs 2.

[h2]Balance[/h2]

is almost non-existent. I remember when playing Watch Dogs 1, I had to use all available play techniques: stealth, melee, shooting, remote detonation, etc. With Watch Dogs 2, the only viable technique left to complete most missions (as a non-pro player) is stealth+melee, because
[b]Reinforcements[/b]
the very moment you get noticed by anyone, [b]everyone[/b] in the restricted area gets immediately alerted. It doesn’t matter if you kill the person who noticed you half a second later and he’d realistically try to defend first and not have the time to alert others. Once you are seen, everyone is on alert. Even worse: it then only takes about 2-3 seconds for someone (most likely someone far away you can’t reach) to call reinforcements, which a bit later call their own reinforcements and so on, thus continuing an endless cycle. Reinforcements arrive almost immediately, even you are on a ship. What?! Then everyone surrounds you as if they could see your exact location (maybe they don’t and it’s just good AI). Once you get spotted, the endless cycle of reinforcements begins and it’s almost impossible to restore the game.
You can take down enemies with melee one-by-one, but in some missions, 2-3 of them are always close to each other - that’s when it gets really tricky.

Watch Dogs 1 as far as I can remember was also tricky with reinforcements, but nearly not as much: you had the opportunity to deactivate (with hacking) enemies’ ability to call reinforcements. You could explode enemies with area props, most of which in Watch Dogs 2 became “non-lethal shock” (read: almost useless, as the affected enemies don’t die, but everyone gets alerted anyway and as I told before, we want to avoid anyone getting alerted at all costs).

[h2]Multiplayer[/h2]

One very cool feature of Watch Dogs 2 is “automatic multiplayer”. I have never seen anything like this in any other game. You can play single player missions, but the game automatically detects when there are other players in the nearby area and suggests you to do some (online) missions together or against each other. For example, you can join the police chasing some other player. This all (mostly) happens without any loading screen, the game switches between single- and multi-player mode behind the scene. You can determine which mode you are in by opening the map and seeing if the car continues to move or pauses.

[h2]World[/h2]

is cool and beautiful. I like the graphics.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

I recommend to get Watch Dogs 1 and skip this one.

I am a 55 year old biker and trucker father, and probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 15 now. My son got this game from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 12 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he let me borrow his controller. Me and my son then played in turns and I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories.

It is a massive improvement over the first Watch Dogs, in my opinion, and in that regard, this game is already much better since the first installment was very mediocre.

But honestly, beyond the quality-of-life and gameplay adjustments/improvements, it's pretty bland and basic in terms of what you're actually doing. 

Story and world is a lot more interesting this time around, and the game looks pretty decent.

If it's on sale, and you don't have much else to play, this is not too bad, but if you're looking for something much more special, you will probably be disappointed by this game.

SUN SHADOWS AND CLOUDS FLICKER ON 3000 SERIES AND 4000 SERIES CARDS. For the 3060, I was able to stop it by limiting the framerate so that the GPU does not reach 99% utilization. Trying it on the 4070 and 4070 Ti I was unable to get it to stop. This is a [url=https://www.pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/Watch_Dogs_2#cite_note-10]known issue acknowledged by NVidia[/url] so it may be fixed in a future update, but until then I will leave this negative review!

As for the game itself, as someone who is tired of samey open-world games (thanks Ubisoft) I enjoy the Watch Dogs series, and 2 is my favorite of them. It's not like GTA at all and does it's own thing; I appreciate the focus on stealth even if it's not super deep. San Francisco is beautifully recreated in this game and I would recommend getting it when it's on sale.

EDIT: Using an older version of DXVK (version 0.72 I think) I am now able to run the game on my 4070 without the shadows flickering!

This game is definitely an improvement over the previous entry.

Beautiful environments, San Francisco looks amazing and the npc's roaming the world sometimes have some funny dialog or behaviors. The atmosphere of this game is great.

More lighthearted presentation and a really likable protagonist make this a pleasant experience. 

Combat is fun but I think the weapon selection is not something special.

The array of things you can hack don't vary that much either, but still really fun to use all the tools at your disposal.

Downside is the story, is not bad, but there is barely any screen time for the antagonist or villains and they don't feel as interesting as they could.

Overall this is a very fun game, buy it on sale if you can.

Looking for the public mayhem of [i]Grand Theft Auto[/i] but still want to be the hero on the moral high ground? [i]Watch_Dogs 2[/i] has got you covered!

As far as open world games go, this is probably the one I've enjoyed the most. More than just a pretty vista to look at, so much of the environment is interactable in ways few other games compare to. Buildings serve as 3D puzzles for you to climb, explore, and manipulate. Enemy strongholds give you a hundred different options on how you approach your attacks, and no two encounters are the same. The sheer amount of variety tucked into such a vast space will keep you entertained the whole campaign through. Oh, and the fast travel system - it’s golden. For players bored with traversing the vast distances, you can shortcut from one destination to the next with absolute ease. 

In terms of a [i]Watch_Dogs[/i] game, the mechanics familiar to the franchise got streamlined and fine tuned in all the right ways. It is definitely the superior of the two, feeling like the next evolutionary step for returning players, while being accessible to brand new players. You can skip the first one and miss nothing both in terms of play and story. Speaking of which…

Ubisoft took notes: audiences were bored with broody, bland Aidan and his vigilante quest for revenge. So they gave us an animated, quirky group of folk heroes sticking their middle finger to the man by causing ALL of the collateral damage. These are protagonists from tragic backgrounds, with chips on their shoulders and the tools needed for chaotic good to burn down a broken system. Go crazy, be a domestic terrorist, and then get back to your righteous crusade fighting corporate “monsters.” The game doesn’t just let you be a maniac, it [i]encourages[/i] you to be a maniac. If you ever needed a lesson in ludonarrative dissonance, this may be the game for you. 

Overall, it's pretty fun, if a bit pricey. Grabbed it on a Steam sale and got my money's worth out of it.
Could have been more serious like its predecessor but it's alright.

Great gameplay, weak story and quirky vibe

Watch_Dogs 2 as a sequel met my expectations in a weird way though. I lean towards dark & gritty atmosphere and serious tone but Ubisoft did complete opposite which isn't a bad thing, actually it's a good thing given Ubisoft record of using same formula since FC3 & ACB this was unexpected and bold move by Ubisoft.

Gameplay where WD2 shines most. Hacking skills improved a lot you can do so many crazy and creative stuff using your abilities. For example you can call cop on a target and witness him/her getting arrested or call hit on a target observe gangs doing driveby you can even do gang shootout just call a hit on rival gangs and watch them doing gangbanging in middle of street call cops too for extra chaos and watch it like a movie. You think that's enough? hell no! summon your explosive equipped drone and rain bombs on them and watch vehicles getting explode and bodies flying away... Hacking is focus here there are so many creative ways to utilise and take out your enemies I didn't use guns much only for last resort I mostly went with stealth and hacking. Game incentives for that style too because you can die easily and lethal gun takedowns & slow mo focus absent here. They still using same takedown system from first game so that was let down for me. You can punch pedestrian but there's no proper melee system and your melee weapon called "Thunder Ball" looks & behaves very silly I didn't like it but fits the setting of the game I guess. Driving mechanics not improved much still feels same as WD1 but vehicle variety increased. Game have a radio now you can listen different radio stations with it's DJ which is a great improvement but don't expect GTA's Lazlow quality. Song selection on the other hand uninspiring this might be subjective but I didn't like most of the songs in this game it just didn't put me into game's mood. This time game based on San Francisco a colorful and cheerful atmosphere complete opposite of Chicago's dark and moody atmosphere. Map size is big so many great locations to explore and rural areas also expanded greatly. What really impressed me most how versatile map design is you can climb so many rooftops using your parkour ability. There's even a crane; you can hack it, hump on it, lift it, rotate it then reach very tall buildings or better squish any poor enemies with it...

But if we look at story well it's kinda falls apart. This time we are part of DedSec hacker collective, throughout the game we're doing operations to expose big corporations's shady practices and take down main villain's goals. Mission structure not linear we can do main missions in different order and replay it these are great improvements but why story is weak then? well because of characters. Main villain for example I barely even remember his name he is very uninteresting and forgettable. Other big companies you expose through operations also not integrated well into main plot. Final mission also huge let down seems very rushed. WD1's final mission was very memorable and chaotic this ending isn't like that. Your companions not great either what's the point of "Horatio" he just appears at beginning of the game and few missions then gone, he felt last minute addition. Game also tries to create some tension between the crew but goes nowhere. Since I'm not really into hippie culture, silly jokes and constant pop culture references I just couldn't be attach to story nor it's characters. That doesn't mean they are terrible in fact "Wrench" by far the best one, out of all characters he stole the show I liked him a lot. T-Bone also returns as well he's still great just as WD1. What I really liked most on main missions though are level designs you can complete your objectives in multiple ways for instance you can use your RC Jumper without even stepping a foot or you can enter from various types of entry points. Side missions are good improvement over first game. Crew gives nice context for each side missions and some of them really good and hilarious like ATM mission. There are tons of activities you can do as well such as racing, taking pictures etc. 

Gameplay wise WD2 great improvement over WD1 but from story wise it's not, WD1 did it much better. I recommend it to any fan of this open world genre. As for WD1 fans be ready for drastic setting change. I also have to point out modding. This game uses Easy anti-cheat and it's not allowing to change game files you need to turn it off but turning off means you cannot play online. It's bummer but I didn't care because I really dislike camera in this game it's far from protagonist so I downloaded WD1 style over shoulder close camera mod to make my game enjoyable at the expense of online. After finishing 100% I tried online and it's fun they kept seamless solo/online experience intact they even added bounty hunter mode. If you planning modding this game keep that in mind.

This games a lot of fun. Great mechanics, natural feeling details, and San Francisco never looked better. I wish they paid more attention to detail to the actual map of SF though. The Bay Area isn’t big so they could’ve easily at the very least recreated downtown SF in its entirety.

The story continues!
Recommending for the hacking, cool story, development of how the MC can interact with the world, multiple ways of achieving the objectives (personally used a lot of the drone and RC car) lots of sidequests, and how the change in tone reflects the change in setting and story (Chicago - gritty story, SF - less gritty!)
Downsides is that the tone can sometimes be too lighthearted - it is easily possible to straight up commit multiple mass murders in cold blood, and the next cutscene still has the tone of a hacktivist group. But, not sure how that could be fixed in an open world game like this.

This game is a true gem of Watch Dogs series and in same time [u]one of the cringiest stories I ever saw[/u].

Really, after the first game we know DedSec as a group of genius hackers working underground and able to collapse whole ctOS system of Chicago. And in second game we see all of them: 

-	Hipster version of CJ from San Andreas
-	Girl doing painting and chilling
-	Guy with communication problems solving via tattoos, violence and BDSM-mask
-	Guy with even more communication problems solving via hard coding
-	Guy with funny name who motivates everyone[spoiler], mainly by dying in the mid of the game[/spoiler]

I understand that the game was launched at the prime of hipster culture and represents vibes of San Francisco, but seriously…  these guys are DedSec? If yes, omg we doomed. 

And the plot based on fighting corporate evil and solving personal problems of kids-like level is sometimes very hard to digest. 

This is my only concern about the game. Rest is a direct and quality evolution from the first game: visual (pixel arts), new mechanics just-in-time added (drones and weapons crafting), old mechanics evolving (privacy intrusions), and even multiplayer nicely incorporated into main game.

[b]7.5 mommy’s justice fighters out of 10[/b]

Great gameplay, weak story and quirky vibe

Watch_Dogs 2 as a sequel met my expectations in a weird way though. I lean towards dark & gritty atmosphere and serious tone but Ubisoft did complete opposite which isn't a bad thing, actually it's a good thing given Ubisoft record of using same formula since FC3 & ACB this was unexpected and bold move by Ubisoft.

Gameplay where WD2 shines most. Hacking skills improved a lot you can do so many crazy and creative stuff using your abilities. For example you can call cop on a target and witness him/her getting arrested or call hit on a target observe gangs doing driveby you can even do gang shootout just call a hit on rival gangs and watch them doing gangbanging in middle of street call cops too for extra chaos and watch it like a movie. You think that's enough? hell no! summon your explosive equipped drone and rain bombs on them and watch vehicles getting explode and bodies flying away... Hacking is focus here there are so many creative ways to utilise and take out your enemies I didn't use guns much only for last resort I mostly went with stealth and hacking. Game incentives for that style too because you can die easily and lethal gun takedowns & slow mo focus absent here. They still using same takedown system from first game so that was let down for me. You can punch pedestrian but there's no proper melee system and your melee weapon called "Thunder Ball" looks & behaves very silly I didn't like it but fits the setting of the game I guess. Driving mechanics not improved much still feels same as WD1 but vehicle variety increased. Game have a radio now you can listen different radio stations with it's DJ which is a great improvement but don't expect GTA's Lazlow quality. Song selection on the other hand uninspiring this might be subjective but I didn't like most of the songs in this game it just didn't put me into game's mood. This time game based on San Francisco a colorful and cheerful atmosphere complete opposite of Chicago's dark and moody atmosphere. Map size is big so many great locations to explore and rural areas also expanded greatly. What really impressed me most how versatile map design is you can climb so many rooftops using your parkour ability. There's even a crane; you can hack it, hump on it, lift it, rotate it then reach very tall buildings or better squish any poor enemies with it...

But if we look at story well it's kinda falls apart. This time we are part of DedSec hacker collective, throughout the game we're doing operations to expose big corporations's shady practices and take down main villain's goals. Mission structure not linear we can do main missions in different order and replay it these are great improvements but why story is weak then? well because of characters. For example main villain I barely even remember his name he is very uninteresting and forgettable. Other big companies you expose through operations also not integrated well into main plot. Final mission also huge let down seems very rushed. WD1's final mission was very memorable and chaotic this ending isn't like that. You're companions not great either what's the point of "Horatio" he just appears at beginning of the game and few missions then gone, he felt last minute addition. Game also tries to create some tension between the crew but goes nowhere. Since I'm not really into hippie culture, silly jokes and constant pop culture references I just couldn't be attach to story nor it's characters. That doesn't mean they are terrible in fact "Wrench" by far the best one, out of all characters he stole the show I liked him a lot. T-Bone also returns as well he's still great just as WD1. What I really liked most on main missions though is level designs you can complete you're objectives in multiple ways for example you can complete your objective using your RC Jumper without even stepping a foot or you can enter from various types of entry points. Side missions are good improvement over first game. Crew gives nice context for each side missions and some of them really good and hilarious like ATM mission. There are tons of activities you can do as well such as racing, taking pictures etc.

From gameplay wise WD2 great improvement over WD1 but from story wise it's not. WD1 did it much better. I recommend it to any fan of this open world genre. As for WD1 fans be ready for drastic setting change. I also have to point out modding. This game uses Easy anti-cheat and it's not allowing to change game files you need to turn it off but turning off means you cannot play online. It's bummer but I didn't care because I really dislike camera in this game it's far from protagonist style over shoulder close camera mod to make my game enjoyable at the expense of online. After finishing 100% I tried online and it's fun they kept seamless solo/online experience intact they even added bounty hunter mode. If you planning modding this game keep that in mind.

on sale I bought this game and every dlc that gave extra missions and one for cosmetics, I kept saying I should've looked at reviews but even looking at them on steam it seems the vast majority of people haven't played the first game, I like the first watch dogs 10 times more and will recommend that game any day of the week, but this game is nothing in comparison, I couldn't play it for more than a handful of hours without feeling annoyed at the lack of quality, the game kept bugging out and crashing for one but that's all watchdog games, but the story is NOTHING compared to the story in the first game, the first game it felt like every single thing you do contributes to who the main character is as a person and everything you do has purpose, even random missions for some odd reason you just felt immersed in the story, the story was WILD to say the least, in this game it feels very dull, the story feels like the devs just drew something on paper and didn't take any initiative, while most people may like it just because of the baseline game even though the characters aren't memorable at all, if you want to compare the stories as something you absolutely loved about the first watchdogs, this game has you go through a story without purpose, without immersing you into the story like the first one did, it feels very dull and very....idk, forced, I hated that I considered it a waste and bought the dlc's aswell, also knowing the reviews don't really look into the story at all much less comparing it to the first one, I hope the next two games are much much different, but this one was beyond disappointing and I'd encourage you to dive into the first game

7/10.

Wow man, this game is good. I went in with low expectations, and came out surprised, surprised how good this experience was. You can feel the love that was put into the game with San Francisco. The protagonist, Marcus Holloway, is as charismatic as he is fun to play with, actually a great character and a complete 180 from Aiden Pearce (He was good too btw).

The side characters were great and all, my personal fav has to be wrench. The guy is the GOAT.

Parkour was also great, you get this sense of speed. I never found myself complaining about running to my car that spawned a 100 meters away.

Story was decent, not as gritty as the first game, but decent.

8/10.

note: please do not buy any story dlc here in steam for this game unless you want to turn out like me. It seems the dlc only works if you play on Uplay, and that is going to lead into starting another save file.

This is my old review back in 2018:

(Please forgive my bad English as English is my second language)

WD1 is rather a disaster, from the huge downgrade in graphic to disappointed main story plot, there's many cons in the game. And because of that, I didn't plan to play WD2. However, in last year's winter sale, the price went down drastically, so I said to myself, why not? And I bought the game with the least expectation.
Turns out this game is MUCH MUCH BETTER than WD1, not only the graphics gets much better(2 Years gap, duh!), the main character, marcus and his buddies are much better in the main character role than grumpy old man Aiden. Here's the Pros and cons I've come up with, hope it can help you determine to buy this game or not!

Pros:
+Graphics
+MC are much better
+Many more guns and cars
+Phone looks much more like a phone than WD1
+Melee Animation
+Marcus actually uses a computer to hack stuff
+The Co-Op mission is really fun(For me)
+Like the Jumper and Quadcooper

Cons:
-Harder to earn money(Maybe should be a pro? idk)
-The showdown is crap
-One of the motocross races and all of the sailboats races are hard as hell
-[spoiler]Horatio died [/spoiler]
-There's other cons but I can't think of any right now

Overall is a fine game, good entertainment, recommended

Oh, here we go, talking about this Ubisoft game, right? I mean, Ubisoft, really? It's like finding out your gran has taken up skateboarding. Unbelievable, right? But, surprise, surprise, this one's actually good! I mean, they made it with love and dedication, which is rarer than a cat that fetches.

Let's break it down. Graphics? San Francisco looks bloody amazing, like they hired a bunch of artistic magicians. Characters are detailed, but the average NPC looks like they stumbled out of a budget costume party.

Now, the gameplay – that's where Watch Dogs 2 shines. Hacking galore! Phone distraction, vehicle control, traffic chaos – it's like a digital playground. And planting false evidence to watch the cops or gangs go nuts? Genius. Too lazy to sneak into enemy territory? Call in a SWAT team. It's like Uber for troublemakers.

Parkour system deserves a round of applause, making the movement smooth as silk. Backflips, front flips – it's a virtual Cirque du Soleil. Gunplay? Eh, it's there. Not much to say.

Story's decent, but the real stars are the characters. Wrench, with his crazy mask, destroying stuff for kicks. Josh, the depressed genius with a weird sense of humor – "cornhole," really? Sitara, the artsy DJ saving DedSec's aesthetic bacon. Horatio? Nice dude, but a bit of a wallflower.

Audio's good – voices are on point, and music's alright. You can pick your own tunes, even in combat. Difficulty? Balanced gunplay, smart enemy AI – they actually strategize! But the stealth system, mate, one guy spots you and it's like the whole army has your GPS.

Final thought? Ubisoft, against all odds, made a game that's actually worth playing. It's like seeing a dog play the violin – surprising, but hey, it works!

If you have an RTX 4000 series GPU (perhaps even 3000 series as I've heard from some forums), you'll more than likely experience extremely distracting shadow flickering that affects the sky and most of the game's geometry. As far as I'm aware, there's no sure way to fix it but people claim limiting your FPS fixes it, turning off HFTS shadows, or using DXVK. None of these fixed my issues except the 0.72 version of DXVK but it caused insane performance dips and stutters for me and I'm just not playing the game like that. Honestly, the flickering makes the game unplayable since not only is it immensely distracting, but destroys any semblance of immersion and is just downright painful to witness because of how bad it can be at times.

NVIDIA even released an official statement saying they're at an impasse with this bug because Ubisoft won't help them fix it (Proof - https://www.nvidia.com/en-us/geforce/forums/game-ready-drivers/13/520845/geforce-grd-53623-feedback-thread-released-61423/3361173/). I've also seen multiple instances of Ubisoft support just telling players to use DXVK to fix it, which is insulting I'd need a third-party application just to fix a game-breaking bug. Of course it's not their support department's fault, but that alone just says a lot about Ubisoft as a company, especially morally, and how much they truly don't care about their players or the future accessibility of their games, yet still charge nearly full price knowing this hardware issue.

There is a game breaking bug that basically locks content you paid for with no fix. Support tickets about not having access to DLC you've paid for go ignored and it goes unfixed still. They do not care. Ubisoft is indeed aware and does nothing. It's sad because this is a great game they ruin with things like this they could fix and the continued forcing of Denuvo malware on an 8 year old game despite the fact they cracked this one anyway. Save your money. I'm not telling you what to do, but I'm definitely not going to judge you either.

[h1]Ubisoft's Finest in My Opinion[/h1]
[hr][/hr]
[h2]Captivating Story and Gameplay[/h2]
"Watch_Dogs 2" truly shines with its story and gameplay. The narrative is engrossing, filled with intriguing twists that kept me engaged throughout. The gameplay mechanics complement the story, offering a seamless and enjoyable experience.

[h2]The Open World of San Francisco[/h2]
While the open-world depiction of San Francisco in "Watch_Dogs 2" might not be groundbreaking, it's certainly well-executed. Exploring the city is enjoyable, and it provides a good backdrop for the game's events.

[h2]Rich Characters[/h2]
A major highlight of "Watch_Dogs 2" is its characters. They're thoughtfully developed, adding depth and relatability to the gaming experience.

[h2]Overall Experience[/h2]
In my view, "Watch_Dogs 2" stands as the best game from Ubisoft. It brings together a solid storyline, good open-world dynamics, and memorable characters in a package that I thoroughly enjoyed.

[h2]Final Recommendation[/h2]
Overall, for anyone seeking an engaging story within a well-crafted game world, "Watch_Dogs 2" is a must-try. It showcases some of the best work from Ubisoft and has earned its place as my favorite title from their lineup.

This game is a great example that Ubisoft absolutely has the capability to make good games, which makes it all the more frustrating just how damn mediocre they are most of the time. 

The gameplay here is absolutely stellar. It's quite unique and a substantial improvement from the first game, with even more interactables and dynamism. While the gunplay is subpar, it is absolutely possible to complete the game without using anything more than melee takedowns, the taser, and environmental objects that you can hack. The most fun I've had playing this game was when I held myself to not using any lethal guns for an entire playthrough.

I also really like the game's depiction of the Bay area and its general worldbuilding, showcasing a dystopian but all-too-real future where health insurance companies can raise someone's rates for ordering "unhealthy" food and every aspect of life is datamined for the benefit of large corporations. The bay area here also provides a fun sandbox experience outside of missions, with many ways to mess around with pedestrians and even start conflicts between rival factions.

While I do love the general worldbuilding, I'm not as huge on the overall story nor the primary characters. Say what you will about the story of the original watch dogs, but the ludonarrative dissonance here is truly on overdrive at times. It does help to go for a non-lethal playthrough, but there are unavoidable moments that feel incongruent from the personalties of the involved characters. 

Overall, Watch Dogs 2 is a very fun experience that shows the promise of the IP and the unique gameplay elements center to it. It's a shame that this game ended up receiving far less attention than otherwise due to how much of a disappointment on multiple levels the first title was, and it's also a shame that Watch Dogs: Legion took a massive step back in a number of respects despite the interesting gimmick at it's core & the interesting environment London promised to be for the series. At the very least we did get one good watch dogs title, and that's about as much as I can ask for when it comes to this publisher.

Yo, so Watch Dogs 2 is straight up lit! The hacking vibes are dope, and Marcus is like the coolest hacker dude ever. The Bay Area setting is sick, and the graphics are on point.

The protagonist and main characters exhibit various degrees of cringe inducing behaviour. World feels dead. The overall joy you get from driving a vehicle in this game corresponds to the amount of nutrients you get from eating half a cucumber (the small ones). The story is incredibly unsatisfying to follow. The radio stations play music that would fit really well into the main menu of a skateboarding game from 2008. On average, this game is somewhere below average.

Here's my updated review after coming back to the game a few years later and giving it another try:

Not as bad as the first few hours made it out to be (not counting the intro - that was pretty solid), but it does take some getting used to. Expecting the charm of GTA isn't a good idea, although it does have its own cool moments. I found myself enjoying driving around the city and completing the small objectives and puzzles. It is not a challenging game, but the sort of overpoweredness that it gives you allows you to play around and have fun. The story isn't super interesting but it does feature internet memes and other types of internet fandango shenanigan thingymajingies that I haven't seen in many AAA games. 

The grid-hacking puzzles are fun. The spider-robot was very fixe pá.

A little later on into my playthrough..

I used to hate the characters in this game, and to some extend I still find them a little cringe, but they do have their charm. The story is not super serious, and I kinda wish killing people wasn't a thing you did, cause it creates this weird quirky-but-serious scharingadingdong that doesn't work. Game is not as bad as I previously thought, but a big part of that is me deciding not to take it too seriously. It's not a hard recommend but it is a "maybe haha".

The parkour is fun and well made. Reminds me of Assassin's Creed a little bit, although not as integrated and important as in those games. I wish they made it a bit more prominent and important to the overall gameplay experience, because throwing your drones above rooftops to figure out which path to parkour up is quite a satisfactory experience. Quaint, if I must say so, even.

Invading a building by sending in your drone first to retrieve the door key and then sneaking in to stun-gun everyone is satisfying. The whole sense of overpowered control that you have is fun, even though it makes most tasks in the game feel trivial. But it doesn't have to be hard, because the narrative of the whole story is that you are this overpowered group of hackers that are trying to turn the world around. 

The "we are anonymous" type of cinematics that play throughout the game are a scandal and I wish they stuck to the silly and goofy stuff. The ending was quite cool though, it's an ALRIGHT game, I will state again. Now I shall leave this keyboard and go do some parkour-lite (walking to the fridge).

There's a pretty good collection of indie-pop music present in the game which I didn't discover until after I had beaten it. The in-game radio has infected my own Spotify playlist a little. 

The graphics are pretty good but the characters are big bottlenecks. The facial animations aren't great and the way the lightning hits characters makes it look like they're made of plastic.

The parkour animations are pretty cool though, I like those.

Welcome back to the Watch Dogs universe with the second part of the franchise. The developers have again made a game with an awesome main character (Marcus), a great story and nice amount of main and side missions, this time located in the city of San Francisco.

I enjoyed playing this game far too much (especially with the little Nudle-car which is awesome), although I suck at driving. Did not spend money on the cosmetic DLCs but on the content DLCs, and since i bought the package on sale, it was definitely worth the money. Not only for fans, but for everyone enjoying a story-driven game, which you can play as you wish, either stealthily or doing an "overkill", taking out anything that moves. Most I enjoyed the puzzles, where you have to connect electrical connections - a nice little gimmick giving an additional challenge to some of the missions. Strong recommendation on this one, even if Aiden Pearce is not the protagonist.

One of Ubisoft's best games. Everything is hackable giving you much more freedom than Watch Dogs 1 and arguably Watch Dogs Legion. I play on Steam Deck LCD and turning the settings down to about Medium mixed with low and limiting my fps through steam deck settings I can get about 2 hours of play. On Steam Deck OLED with the same settings you could probably get 4 hours of play or more if you turn the settings lower. Multiplayer and general online functions don't work due to anticheat not working on Steam Deck/Linux. In my experience I can't play the game if I'm off wifi because whenever I try to login to Uplay/Ubisoft Connect it says my login information is incorrect when it isn't. The simple way around this is to just get into the game when you're on wifi and put the Steam Deck on sleep mode. Once you're off wifi and turn the Steam Deck back on you can play exactly as if you were playing on wifi.

Overall in my experience this is a pretty good game for the Steam Deck having been on consoles and works with the steam deck controller scheme just as it is played on Playstation or Xbox. You can even get a steal on the game if you wait for it to be on sale for about 8 dollars and something cents if the 49.99 is too much.

The game does require a bit of tinkering such as needing to run the game on Proton Experimental which you can do by going into the steam game's settings (the cog wheel), go to properties, Compatibility, force game to use of a specific steam play compatibility tool, change the proton version to Proton Experimental which should be at the top, then save it.

Next, because the game uses ubisoft's launcher it has ubisoft messages like "your graphics card is lower than recommended" which that message doesn't go away so it's annoying, it's also meaningless because the game runs fine on steam deck. 

Anyway to make the messages not show up add the back buttons and make one of them shift, and another F2, than while in-game (not in the main menu) hit them at the time time and it should bring up the ubisoft quick menu. Go to settings and turn off "Enable In-game Notifications". Now if you restart the game the messages may show up for a second but they'll go away. You can also now reset the back buttons in case you don't want to use them or if you want to assign them to different controls.

Finally, I've heard the game crashes sometimes and it's because of the multiplayer aspects that you can't use on steam deck. The best way to stop these crashes is to simply go into the in-game settings, multiplayer, and turn off all the multiplayer settings.

"Hacking Paradise" – (My take on it)

So, I just finished my epic hacking adventure in Watch Dogs 2, and let me tell you, it's like jumping headfirst into a tech-filled roller-coaster of emotions. Strap in, for what I am about to say!

First off, San Francisco has never looked this cool. It's a digital playground where every street corner hides a hacking opportunity. The graphics? They're so sharp you might accidentally cut yourself. Seriously, the attention to detail is on point.

The story follows Marcus Holloway, a badass mofo. He's like the love child of Anonymous and a parkour master. The dude can climb anything, and his hacking skills? Pure genius. You get to wreak havoc in the tech world, and it feels oh so satisfying.

Now, let's talk hacking. It's not just pressing a button; it's an art form. You can manipulate the city's infrastructure, turning it into your personal chessboard. Traffic lights, security cameras, even a random dude's smartphone – it's all fair game. And trust me, causing chaos with a few taps never gets old.

The characters? are quite good almost like Ubi nailed it. They're diverse, hilarious, and just the right amount of crazy. I found myself caring about this virtual gang more than some people in real life. Oh, and did I mention the soundtrack? It's a head-bobbing, mood-setting masterpiece. Get ready to hack to the rhythm.

Multiplayer? Heck yeah. Co-op missions, hacking invasions – it's a wild ride. Me and my friends causing chaos together? What more could you ask for?

Sure, every game has its quirks. The driving physics might make you question the laws of physics, but who cares when you're hacking a self-driving car, right?

In a nutshell, Watch Dogs 2 is a hacker's dream come true. It's bold, it's beautiful, and it's so damn fun. If you haven't jumped into the world of DedSec yet, what are you waiting for? This game is like a high-tech adrenaline shot straight to the my soul.

Certainly has its fair share of problems, for example it's optimisation, AI, Multiplayer Battles and participation, and the characters felt forced to be liked. But overall the game performed quite well. 

General opinion: It's fun to roam around and find new things to do, there's a good amount of missions both relating to the main story line, and also side quests. Some missions, like the ones where you have to paint murals around the city, really annoyed me, because it's all just grinding.  I added a spoiler on the bottom of the review in-case someone wants to read it. 

AI:
The AI in this game sucks, not that it was any better in the first one either in my opinion. Sure, it's not as bad as in ,,Rust" where the AI shoots you straight in the fucking head in a nanosecond, but it could of been better.

Optimisation:

The game mostly ran well, medium to high settings and it performed well. I haven't tried to change that many settings, but sometimes while loading in certain areas and mid-fights or chases the game stuttered a bit, nothing major to worry about. 

Multiplayer:

Oh man.. Some people really deserve to get hit through the monitor. 
If you're new to the game and need help with a difficult online missions and try multiplayer, be ready for fuckers who take on the role of trolls in-game and ruin it. Fuck being stealthy or helping you out, multiple times I've been sabotaged and failed missions which were hard to complete, all because the player helping you decides to fuck around. Certainly not recommending to play with anyone else, unless they're your friend.

Characters: 
 
Well...they're fine. Some of the characters I really like, some of them i REALLY don't like. Marcus is a good introduction to the series, but i feel like him getting into Deadsec felt a bit rushed. Josh was okay, Sitara was pretty cool with all the art she did and the dialogue with Wrench was the most fun you will have. Wrench and Marcus shared a lot of bro-mance through the game, and Wrench carried the whole dialogue mid-missions. Sure some stuff was annoying, but very rarely did I feel annoyed at characters in the game. Spoilers ahead: 	[spoiler]Aside from..Kenny. Kenny was really cool to talk to in the first game, but here I was always suspicious if he wasn't going to fuck me up or not, which ruined me to expect for him not to. I had to finish the whole game to find out he wasn't gonna do something, and it just feels like it flopped, because he never really proved himself to me that he can be trusted.


Spoiler alert ! : [spoiler] At some point the game is gonna make you paint on a fucking bridge, climbing all the way to the top, which takes about 15 - 20 minutes to complete. That, is a incredibly boring mission. [/spoiler] 

All in all, give it a chance. It's a very good game, and it's worth the attention.

This game was great when I played it on PlayStation years ago. But, WARNING: Do not buy this game on Steam, even if they're giving it away for a nickel. Works fine for 90 minutes of intro, then crashes a few minutes into gameplay, no matter what you do. Plenty of online threads support this has been a problem for a long time, nothing is being done about it. Even though the problem becomes evident in less than 2 hours, and happens 100% of the time, because I caught this game on sale over 2 weeks ago my refund request for being unable to play it was denied. If you buy this game for $5 all you're getting for the $5 is the 90 minute intro sequence. This is a shame, because things later in the game are great. Buy it for a console, or at a service that will let you refund it if it doesn't work at all.

Update 4 months later: spent another evening trying ideas from the dozens of google results around this error - compatibility mode, forcing it offline, priority changing, xml editing, running as administrator, fiddling with graphics card settings (AMD has even more issues, though i'm on nvidia) and it still crashes within a minute of playing the real game after the intro. This game should be delisted from Steam in its current state.

Good stealth game

You see, this game broke GTA for me.

Gameplay has varieties to them. They're not just a shooting fest or go point-to-point. Hell, killing enemies is difficult because they are actually intelligent and troublesome. The stealth part is actually the best part of the game. It has a lot of depth, and you need to strategize and not just blindly kill. You can even NOT kill anyone (which perhaps is unique from other """GTA clones""") if you are smart enough. Of course, I like it classic and headshotting everyone.

I enjoyed the story. I do not think it is cringe and the characters have their own charms. I hope what's in this game stays in the game because everything from ctOS, Blume, and that giant fucking Spider are goddamn terrifying and those who wish to reproduce them should not reproduce.

The puzzle (hacking networks) have been improved. Despite having the same puzzle pieces, instead of solving sets of networks in a fixed wall, you have to move around or use your gadgets to reach them. Much more fluid than the last game.

Definitely an improvement from its predecessor and calling this a GTA clone feels...condescending. I do not care about how good the graphics are or how large the world is, give me exciting and diverse gameplay and new concept that differentiate you from the competition, and I'll give you 27 hours of my life to play this heck-a-ton of gigabytes.

p.s. WRENCH I LOVE YOU FULL HOMO <3<3<3<3<3

This is a GTA clone.

That being said, it's pretty okay. I do not own any DLC, just the base game. I beat it in around 35 hours, at a leisurely pace while doing some side missions here and there. It'd probably take you 25-30 hours if you focus only on main objectives. I had a pretty decent time with it, I'd say, but there are plenty of problems.

 I wish that the open combat was given a bit more of a focus, but considering that this is a stealth-heavy game, I get why it doesn't. I also with there was weapon customization. When it comes to stealth weaponry, there's a stun gun, a silenced pistol, and a silenced assault rifle. That's it. You don't have any other options for stealth. No adding silencers or scopes or anything. It doesn't make sense to me to emphasize stealth and punish open combat, then limit your stealth options in such a way.

 The puzzles are alright. They're not too hard, and the last few missions do make you think. Shame that all the challenge is in those last two missions rather than the whole game. Also, it's all plumbing puzzles (Rotating pieces to make one continuous connection) and finding out what vent your jumper needs to go through. Those are the only kinds of puzzle there are. If you're looking for challenging, engaging and varied puzzles that really make you think, look elsewhere. You won't find them here. If you just want to have fun without hard puzzles getting in your way, then this probably won't bother you.

 I hate the integrated multiplayer. I keep trying to turn it off, but every time I start a new session it's turned back on again. It's really annoying when I'm in the middle of a police chase and some guy with a grenade launcher and sniper rifle comes and wrecks my shit, or when I'm just minding my own business and someone comes along and blows up everything around me and enters a "hacking invasion". It's extremely annoying. You might like this random PvP, but I don't. I hate it. When I buy a singleplayer game with multiplayer features, I want to play a singleplayer game with *SEPERATE* multiplayer features. Not a singleplayer game that randomly decides "You're playing multiplayer now, deal with it".

 Most things about this game that I don't mention in this review can be described in one word: *Fine.* Nothing amazing, nothing horrible. It's average. Nothing special. Graphics, driving, gunplay, all that can be described as just fine. Not much else to be said. It's just GTA but with hacking. The hacking, by the way, is also just fine. It's exactly what you'd expect. Aim at something electronic, press a button, and something happens. Make the traffic lights blink. Make a transformer malfunction. Hack into a camera. Make a car move remotely. It's all kinda whatever. Decent, but not great. It is *fine*.

 Speaking of cameras, they don't do anything except act as viewing places. You'd think that maybe you'd have to avoid them during stealth, wouldn't you? Make them look somewhere else, disable the camera guy, temporarily turn them off? Nope. They're just viewpoints for you. That's all they are. And related to that, security systems, namely the motion detectors. When you first encounter them, they're an actual problem you need to work around. But then you can just get a skill to turn them off, completely removing the challenge! What was an actual problem you needed to work around creatively using your drone or jumper, becomes a minor inconvenience to aim your mouse at them and press "C". Sure, you can just not take the skill, but why would you include the skill in the first place? It ruins the balance of mid to late game missions.

Oh, and now the story- it sucks. I mean, the plot itself is just a generic "Big bad company is bad and good underground rebel group fight bad company" story. Full of clichés, the characters are about as deep as a baby pool, and the game tries to portray the player as good when we steal money from the poor and homeless. And while that last one is optional, the other two are very real problems. The writing sucks. If you want to play for the story, don't.

TLDR, the game sucks in a lot of places and is just fine where it doesn't. Now, I had a decent time with it, but I'd still say it wasn't worth fifty dollars. If this game goes on sale for $35 or less, I'd say it's a good play. But it's not worth $50, much less $90 for a bunch of cosmetics and a few extra missions.

By the way, the description has a grammatical error. It says "execute the biggest hack *of* history", when it should be "in history".

This game is pretty good as a decent time-wasting open world collectathon, and most of the mechanics are executed not great, but pretty well. In an attempt to be a mix of assassin's creed and dues ex, it would end up being a somewhat mediocre combination of the two if not for one major issue.

The stealth mechanic is one of the most poorly done I've seen in any game. You can be fully concealed and have suppressed weapons, but if you take more than 1 shot to kill your enemy - even if it's 2 hits with a super fast automatic weapon - suddenly all the enemies in the area know exactly where you are. The only way to break the heat is to shoot your out (impossible if you're against the cops) or hightail it out of there (which is impossible when you're doing a mission). Because of this, the game ends up being a cover-shooter more often than a stealth game.

On top of that, the game is poorly optimized. my fps will range from 120 when walking around to 44 when driving at full speed.

So, what to say about watch dogs 2...

If you can get it for under 10 bucks or so, you know, it is kind of relative fun, and the story, even though it doesn't matter at all to the entire game has some fun small things embedded into it, that's just cool to do, soo, while it's on sale, like right now, probably worth it

It took me several hours to get this game playable. I asked for a refund (first time ever on Steam) which I did not get because I bought the game too long ago. Does it matter if the game just doesn't work? It shouldn't have been sold in the first place! 

The sarcastic thing is that you get a crash screen when you start the game. It really fits the unstable and constantly crashing game. If you search for "crash" on the Steam discussion page for this game, you will find 831 articles spread over 84 pages. Instead of the developers wasting their time making 100 types of clothes/appearances, they should spend that time making the game more stable.  

So now you already know that you should avoid this game, I will still say something about the game as I still managed to complete this game for 100%. 

The game offers many missions and variety and you can spend many hours in this game to complete the story and all the sub stories. Make sure you buy your drone early in the game as it will help you a lot to sneak through missions. The character in part 1 was much more interesting than the character in part 2. Part 2 is probably more appealing to 16-20 year old players because of the immature jokes in the game. 

On the positive side is the ability to complete the entire game non-lethally. Hacking gives you a lot more options compared to part 1. You can call SWAT on an NPC or put them on a gang hit list.

The DLC's Human Conditions and No Compromise are worth buying/adding to this game (if you ignored my advice not to buy this game in the first place).

I want to make the point that Dedsec are villains and you play as villains, which is either hilariously incompetent writing, or ironic genius. Want examples? In Watch_Dogs 2, you:

 - Steal random people's money on the street, including but not limited to: homeless, poor, rich, men, women, etc. There's no discrimination.
 - Graffiti a religious building (No, not New Dawn, an actual Church).
 - Hack the lights and electronics of a female streamer and scare her because she does 24 hour live streams because her nosy aunt makes assumptions with no proof there are simps in the stream.
 - Erase job applications from people because we don't like where they are applying to.
 - Supporters of Dedsec in New York start setting fires to corporate buildings. When asked if Dedsec should make a statement about it, Marcus says that the statement should be one of support for the arson.
 - Swat a kid playing Rainbow Six Siege. (Granted, he SWATS people too, so it's eye for an eye mentality. You decide.)
 - Stealing civilians cars on the street by hacking the alarm system.
 - Blow up vital infrastructure in San Francisco.
 - Mess with people's bank account for shits and giggles and recording reactions.
 - Cause numerous traffic accidents.
 - Leak company secrets for game journalists (yuk) (but an admittedly funny thing to do).
 - Vandalize the Golden Gate Bridge for advertising

Heck it's literally a plot point that because of Dedsec, people are afraid of hackers and are buying CToS 2.0 to fight it. Blume aren't the good guys, but it sure takes a villain to beat a villain I suppose. It's hard to tell if it's intentional, so you decide if this is genius, or stupidity from Ubisoft's writing department. 

Other than that? The game's pretty good. My favorite Watch Dogs and still fun in 2023, especially with the sale price it drops to often.

Bought it a few days ago, but I wasn't aware of the crashing problem with the RX6000 series (unfortunately, mine is RX6600).

The game is really cool—I like it. You go around hacking people, experiencing interesting missions (so far), co-op mode, and much more. But if you have an AMD card, DO NOT BUY IT.

I bought this on sale for a few dollars, obviously don't buy an old game for full price. 

Lots of fun running around San Francisco and fun being able to do missions cleanly with just stealth and your drones. You have access to all sorts of military hardware but it's nice not having to kill hundreds of NPCs if you don't want your non-violent activist hacker guy to be Rambo.

The story is very simplistic, get the evidence against the bad guys and put it out there. The public will listen and believe and react accordingly. Politicians and CEOs are easy to get rid of with a few hacks and some evidence gathering.

Whatever, it's fun and if you want a big running gunfight on the way to the next mission, just pop a few shots and let the madness ensue. When the cops kill you, you respawn quickly and near the place you died so it's not annoying getting in accidental fights either. The hacking puzzles are fairly well done and interesting throughout the game and the drones are well done and a fun mechanic that I've never seen used to this extent.

Watch Dogs 2… a game that went completely under the radar when it launched back in 2016, mostly because of the controversies surrounding the first game. People got burnt and didn’t give Ubisoft a second chance.
I didn’t play the original game, so I approached this with fresh eyes. And boy, am I glad I did. The San Francisco setting works well, even including some of the surrounding areas, like Oakland and Silicon Valley. It’s a GTA-style open-world game that doesn’t follow the typical Ubisoft formula, although it still has some elements.
I didn’t find the story particularly interesting; it’s a lot of exposing the evil plans of big corporations—a trope that's been overused. The characters are a mixed bag as well, and I didn't particularly like any of them. Most missions are also repetitive with similar objectives: hacking things inside a restricted area, although a few of them are fun.
There’re a lot of different collectibles to find, from money to skill points and cosmetic items. Some are locked behind puzzles, but they aren't that interesting. Some are annoying to get, and most are inside restricted areas as well, which isn't a lot of fun.
However, what I really enjoyed in Watch Dogs 2 was just messing around on the streets with your hacking abilities. That's where I had a lot of fun with the game. Even with your basic skills, you can already do things like hacking bank accounts and watching people's reactions to that. And that’s just the beginning. As you progress and gain more abilities, you can remote control cars, call the police and gang members on civilians, and even cause small blackouts.
The hacking skills are fun to use, and combining them leads to some of the best moments I had in the game, all unscripted. Only a few privacy invasion missions made me laugh as hard as hacking ATMs and seeing the reactions. This was much better than what I found in the main story.
Besides these, there’re a few optional activities, mostly time trials. I need to mention the sailboat races—they are very annoying because the controls are different, and you need to constantly watch the wind. But in contrast, these races have an unnecessary epic soundtrack that made the races hilarious at times, since you’re just sailing while listening to Two Steps From Hell. Maybe it’s just me, but I really enjoyed this detail.
Speaking of music, the overall soundtrack is okay. Not great, but memorable enough. It has radio stations that you can listen to at any time, not just inside vehicles like GTA. The graphics are also good for the time. What I didn’t enjoyed were the shooting mechanics.
The game also has online co-op, but I haven’t played that. But from what I saw, it still works, and you can even find people to play with. Besides co-op, there are some seamless multiplayer elements in single-player, but I disabled them since I don’t like to be interrupted and want to play at my pace.
Besides the average story, I had a lot of fun just free-roaming and messing around, and in normal circumstances, that would’ve been enough for me to recommend this. However, being Ubisoft, I have two MAJOR complaints, not with the game itself, that I can recommend, but with Ubisoft itself.
First, there’s a known issue affecting at least most of Nvidia 30 and 40 series graphics cards. There’s a lot of shadow flickering, no matter what settings you use, which is very annoying. It’s also very specific to this game, so probably not the cards' faults. Still, Nvidia tried to fix the issue in a driver update, but since the issue was very specific to Watch Dogs 2, it contacted Ubisoft for help troubleshooting the issue. And guess what happened? Ubisoft just ignored that request, leaving the bug unfixed on a lot of modern hardware.
I suppose they didn’t want to bother with an older game that doesn’t make a lot of money anymore, but still, what a joke. There’re some unofficial fixes available, but they also have annoying side effects. And the cherry on top, the game has the “Nvidia – the way it’s meant to be played” splash screen, which is ironic as heck.
Despite this, I managed to play through the entire game, so it wasn’t a huge deal to me. Some times, especially at night, it’s barely noticeable. It’s very inconsistent, but most of the time, I managed to ignore it. Still, unacceptable for a AAA release.
The second complaint, however, affected me the most. I bought the Gold Edition here on Steam, which includes the Season Pass with extra missions and cosmetics. However, most of the DLC simply didn’t appear to me. I tried everything: reinstalling the game, Ubisoft Connect, disabling and enabling the DLCs, even installing older versions of Ubisoft Connect, and nothing worked.
After some browsing, I found out more people were having the same issue, but no fix. Well, I tried Ubisoft Support, but conveniently they recently shut down live support, redirecting to a Discord channel. At the same time, I submitted a normal ticket.
On Discord, I saw more people with the same issue, and all Ubisoft had to say were generic fixes, which I tried again to no avail. After some back and forth, I finally got a response from the ticket, where they basically said it was an incompatibility issue between versions and there was nothing they could do about it. Like, WTF??? What incompatibility issue? You are still selling the game and its DLC on Steam.
Are you implying you know about this, and everyone buying the DLC on Steam is basically getting scammed? Or it’s another issue, but like the shadow flickering issue, you don’t care because it’s an older game? Maybe it’s not affecting everyone in that case, but me and some other people PAID for this content and can’t access it, and Ubisoft refuses to help.
Ironically, in the end, I managed to access that content after downloading a pirated version of the game with all DLCs. It generated a save file where all the content was correctly registered, and by transferring that save file to my legitimate copy, all the content worked, without losing any progress. So yes, the only way I found to play the content I PAID for was by pirating the game. That speaks for itself.
While I had fun with the game, these issues, especially the second one, really left a bad taste in my mouth. I spent hours trying to get the DLCs to work (I bet I put more time investigating this than Ubisoft did), without success legitimately. And in the end, that’s why I’m giving this a negative review. I can still recommend the game, just not this version.

The first 10 hours are some of the best Ubisoft can offer, with varied mission design, well made cutscenes, a beautiful and in depth city, and interesting hacking mechanics. However, the game suffers from a lot of repeat, recycle filth that Ubisoft is best known for nowadays. The open world is legitimately one of the best that Ubisoft has ever made, and is a great representation of San Francisco. The graphics are great for a game that came out some time ago. The story is laughably dumb, but the characters are interesting and there are some good side missions. The story is far worse than WatchDogs 1 but the characters are a bit easier to connect with, despite there being far more of them. Coop is also decently fun, and since you can turn off annoying random invasions, it become less annoying and more of an interesting mechanic, although to my knowledge you cannot play through special or story missions in coop, just the open world and specific side missions.

The biggest problem with this game is just how far downhill it goes after the 10-13 hour mark, as the missions get ridiculously repetitive and tedious. Guards now take 50 shots to the head (yes, even guards without helmets on), and the stun gun becomes more effective than an assault rifle. The game balance is hilariously broken, stealth sometimes doesn't work, as you'll be chilling around a corner and they will see you through the wall, or see you 150 meters away while you're hiding in a parked car with the engine and lights off. The game also has a gamebreaking glitch where, if you headshot a guard with a silenced weapon, the game will immediately freeze and bug out. This is fixed in a mod that removes decals, but that also means you can't play coop with the mod downloaded. Thanks Ubisoft. 

The game is unique, and you're bound to find something you love about it, but after the 10-12 hour mark, you'll notice a severe drop in quality in the mission design, uniqueness of levels, storytelling, difficulty, and basically everything about the game. The first 10-12 hours are worth a buy if you get the game for $7.5 like I did.

Watch Dogs 2 is not just a sequel; it's a triumphant leap forward for the franchise. Developed by Ubisoft, this open-world action-adventure game offers a captivating and vibrant world where hacking is your greatest weapon, and the city of San Francisco is your sprawling playground.

One of the first things that will strike you about Watch Dogs 2 is its stunning rendition of the San Francisco Bay Area. The game's attention to detail is astonishing, from the iconic landmarks to the diverse neighborhoods, which breathe life into the virtual city. The dynamic day-night cycle and weather effects add depth to the immersive environment.

The star of the show is undoubtedly the game's protagonist, Marcus Holloway, a brilliant and charismatic young hacker who's out to expose corporate corruption and government surveillance. His likable personality and compelling backstory make him a protagonist you'll genuinely care about. The supporting cast is equally well-developed, each character adding a layer of depth and diversity to the story.

The narrative in Watch Dogs 2 is a thrilling rollercoaster ride, exploring themes of hacktivism, privacy, and corporate greed. The game strikes a perfect balance between a gripping storyline and the freedom to explore the vast open world. You have the agency to choose your approach to missions, whether you prefer stealthy hacking, tactical combat, or creative solutions, and the choices you make have real consequences.

The hacking mechanics are the game's core feature and are executed brilliantly. You can manipulate the world around you by hacking into cameras, traffic lights, and various devices. This leads to an array of inventive and often humorous solutions to objectives and challenges. The possibilities are seemingly endless, providing players with a true sense of empowerment.

Watch Dogs 2 excels in its open-ended approach to gameplay. Whether you're exploring the world, infiltrating heavily guarded facilities, or participating in online multiplayer activities, the game offers a seamless blend of solo and cooperative experiences. The online integration allows for thrilling, impromptu encounters with other players, adding an extra layer of excitement.

The attention to post-launch support by Ubisoft ensures that players have a wealth of content to explore, from additional missions to fun and quirky customization options. This ongoing support keeps the game fresh and engaging.

In conclusion, Watch Dogs 2 is a remarkable and immensely satisfying experience that improves upon its predecessor in every aspect. Its striking visuals, engaging characters, thought-provoking narrative, and innovative hacking mechanics combine to create a gaming masterpiece. Whether you're a fan of open-world adventures, technology, or simply a gripping story, Watch Dogs 2 deserves a spot in your gaming library. It's a thrilling ride through the world of hacktivism that will leave you craving more long after the credits roll.

This game features an impressive open-world, complemented by a collectible system that seamlessly integrates with environmental puzzles and exploration. Hacking mechanics have seen significant improvement, along with the mission design. Overall, this game is very enjoyable; however, the story falls short compared to its predecessor. While efforts were made to incorporate more hacking, digital age, and big tech themes, they often come across as a somewhat clumsy parody. The characters could also benefit from more depth.

I've purchased both story DLCs, only to find them inaccessible despite being correctly installed and activated. This might be a server or DRM issue, and it seems that it is not uncommon! Unfortunately, I have not found a solution yet, and I am still waiting on Ubisoft Support for help. Given this, I strongly advise against purchasing the Gold Edition or any DLCs.

Watch Dogs 2 is overall one of the best games ive played, from the humor to the characters to the amazing gameplay i think this game is really good. Now here is where my problems arise: bugs. I have ran into multiple bugs in my playtime of wd2, but the main ones i would like to currently point out are as follows:
1. Screen Flickering: This seems to be an issue for just me as I havent seen anybody else really talking about this, but it is really really annoying to have constant flickering on my screen while playing this game. I've looked for a fix but haven't found one, if you have one please let me know in the comments.
2. Body ragdolls flying everywhere: Whenever i kill literally any enemy, for some reason they just go insane and start flying everywhere. This is really annoying and, like the other one, i have looked for a fix but not found one. Let me know if you have experienced this and have found a fix in the comments please. Other than that this game is awesome and i would 100 percent recommend it.

Overall: 7.5/10

The gameplay is not as good as people say it is. It's not very fun. The gunplay is rather clunky and everything feels even more repetitive than the First Watch Dogs.

The story feels weaker than the 1st Watch Dogs, but perhaps it will get better the more I play it. The characters are nauseating. You can barrel down a crowd of pedestrians and massacre the police force down to a woman (cause half the officers seem to be women for some reason) and then return to your loser club in the basement to hear more lame jokes and annoying comments from the average mentally deranged degenerate San Franciscan. The characters and story in the first game felt a lot more real (except T-bone) and impactful. These characters that I'm forced to tolerate seem like hipster children playing vigilante.

There's also clear leftist brainwashing in this game. Homosexual flags, a transgender character, black racialism comments, anti-free-market pro-socialism comments, just utter nonsense. Besides that, the hardware optimization is beyond dreadful, as usual.

Don't listen to the positive reviews. The only thing this game has going for it is a big map filled with boring repetitive tasks to try to get people to waste more of their lives on garbage. I would return this slop if I could, but for now I will give it another chance to see if I change my mind.

Edit: The gameplay is better than I originally thought once you unlock the hacking tools, but not too much more. Still mediocre. Ending is mediocre. Okay game, I suppose. Characters are a bit less annoying later on, but nothing is really developed between Sitara and Ray for some reason. No real development of characters in general, though there is potential. The liberal propaganda makes this a firm negative review though.

The game, while good, runs very poorly, even on a high end computer.  Turning down the settings helps somewhat, but the game becomes unplayable at its worst.

I beat the game at around 59 hours (although many of those were running side missions).

2 hours in and I almost refunded. The characters are annoying. The story wasn't nearly as good as the first one and I agree with Aiden Pearce, that DedSec is childish (reference from WD1). The foul language is excessive and absolutely I would not let my children play this. I was able to skip the cutscenes at least.

So why the positive review?
In the end, I grew to really enjoy the game mechanics especially after investing in some of the research (i.e. skills). The RC element was really fun and I appreciate the massive amount of time that went into the myriad of puzzles throughout the game. The online aspect was a pleasant surprise and seamless to the single player experience. Despite the mixed reviews, this game makes me want to play WD:L. I enjoyed that so many things were destructible and I felt I had a lot of control over what I was able to do. The world was stunning to drive around in and it ran perfectly on my 1070 Super.

NB: I bought this on sale for about $7. It was worth that amount for sure.

When playing a Ubisoft game, normally the game is either "fine" at best, or absolutely awful.
In Watch Dogs 2, is the first time since... ...a LONG time I actually found glimpses of something special in a Ubisoft game.

Although I still consider Watch Dogs 1 my favorite (Due to the overall mood, slightly better characters and better story), W_D2 is absolutely a great game, with refined gameplay formula, more freedom and also interesting characters and story.
My personal fun story with W_D2, was that I bought it full price on the PS4 and dropped the game in less then 3 hours due to it's annoying teenager characters and definitely millenials-trying-to-please-zoomers writing, that is not true tho, the game develops into something far more interesting later on.

I love the San Francisco they built with this one, even more than my beloved Driver: San Francisco (Bring that to sale again ffs).

The game has a lot of shortcomings (physics still sucks, some keybinds are questionable (esc cuts dialogue and also is the button to leave a hacking interface), flickering shadows bug in RTX40 series, soundtrack could have more metal (one single metal song, come on).

But I do recommend it, for sure. The game does not feel bloated to the brim with useless content as latest Ubi games and is actually a neat package.
Ah, the DLCs are pretty good too. 

Now, I will leave the comments open, as a fan of W_D1 and W_D2, should I play W_D Legion?

Whilst I think WD 1 was truly underrated and an amazing game. I think 2 expands on that in all the right ways! This game is an absolute blast and one I still come back to today after playing it since launch day in 2016. Whilst the tone is completely changed from 1, from a dark and gritty story, to a much more vibrant and happy one. I think this fits in perfectly with everything and especially with the sunny San Francisco, which is detailed perfectly and again just like Chicago in 1 is a location we dont often see in games! Furthermore the level of detail in the world itself is something to marvel at for sure. There is a reason people use footage from this game to pass of as 'GTA 6 leaked footage' every little alleyway and street is filled with so much life its truly something to experience. The world is extremely interactive expanding on the hacking tools from 1, and whilst the story can be a bit hit or miss there is no doubt this game is alot of fun and super detailed, and a blast to explore!

Oh I wish I could go back to the day I got this game. This game is much more fun than Watch Dogs 1 and Legion. The game play is great due to being able to control cars remotely, have the ability to use a drone, and a remote RC car. Using the drone and RC car are a great way to scan an area and be able to go in and out of an area with stealth. You don't have to play stealth either because the chaos is great. You can hack people's phones to initiate a gang attack or a police cruiser to make a scene. Doing so distracts the people in a restricted area and makes it easier not to be caught while stealthy. Lastly, the graphics are phenomenal for a game from 2016. It's so beautiful and after all these years I'm just now finding little details that make the world of San Francisco more immersible. Should buy this game if you're into GTA-like games. 10/10. Thanks Ubisoft. Please make another Watch Dogs game that's just as good.
