Not a bad game but definitly not First Watch Dogs.

I played WD in 2020 and really enjoyed it so bought WD2 earlier this year. It wasn't until I started playing it that I realised how old it is. Initially I did not like the style and it took me a while to get into it, but once I did I found that I enjoyed it every bit as much as the original. I guess the open world and variety of gameplay makes it special for me. I even kept playing the endless side-missions even though they just repeated similar scenarios in a handful of locations. I like that the progression with research points is balanced and it did not feel like I was doing much grinding, apart from money. And that was the only real flaw for me. Once I bought the drones and a weapon I had no further need for money. I really don't care about skins and clothes and once I got the money-profiling I soon amassed so much money that I lost interest in finding money bags. I ended the game with about $2M and had no use for it. But other than that I thoroughly recommend the game for anyone who missed it.

I bought the game and season pass for about £12 in the sale and played 86 hours, making it one of the best value for money games I played. Although I never pay too much for my games (because I leave it long enough) I would have paid twice that and been happy.

So, I was a fan of the first one as I felt it didn't deserve the hate it received. I was looking forward to playing the sequel, however, I won't go on about this one too much, as it's just more of the same.

Visuals are nice, great sound, great music and great voice acting. The story is also interesting enough and steers away from the bleak serious tone of the first one. The game-play however, feels pretty much the same as the first. Nothing new or innovative, just some new gadgets and features to mask the same open world tropes that have been done to death.

I did pick this game up well after release. But I think it's safe to say that open world fatigue had set in around the time it came out. This doesn't add anything new really, but if you're in the mood for another open world game, it'll do the job nicely. But, for the price of $89.95 AUD in 2023!? No way. Wait till it's on deep sale.
I like the graphics and mechanics like blowing up pipes or hacking things but I also like the ambiance of this game I highly recommend.

Watch Dogs 2 is an intuitive and addictive game with a great story. The online mode is so seamlessly reachable, Grand Theft Auto V pales in comparison. You also have the option of fast traveling, tho, in my opinion, it's better if you try not to use it too much. A negative point is that there are 4 additional missions behind 2 DLCs with a total cost of 25€ when they're not for sale. I'd recommend you put this, "Human Conditions," and "No Compromise" on your wishlist and grab it for cheap when it's on sale.

PART 1 Issues
Just like Back 4 Blood, I bought this game simply because It was released later than 2013. Just like Borderlands 2, there's a constant freezing problem. But, this one has to do with the props loading In and pausing the game to load props.
Supposedly It has something to do with online features, which I disabled using -eac launcher In the launch options for the game. I'm pretty sure It's A online feature related to occlusion culling, which Is loading props behind objects.
PART 2 You should buy it
So, I was compelled to buy and play this game because I tried the Demo out on Xbox One. And, watched the entirety of Whitelights review on this game. And It being similar to GTA. Which, I have 672 hours on, on the Xbox One. 
I have 73 hours on Watch Dogs 2.  I didn't complete the game. Spent most of that time doing shoot outs with the police, looking for cash dufflebags and driving around. And just from that little tidbit of doing nothing worth any value,
I love this game. You should buy it. 
PART 3 Headshots
My gripe with this game Is the braindead AI which don't challenge the player intellectually. They do the third person cover lock thing, and pop In and out of cover to shoot you, and occasionally
push up to get new cover. But, the one thing that frustrates me the most Is the fact that you cannot one shot headshot some enemies, which completely takes me out of the game and makes me wanna do other games.
You need 11 headshots to kill A heavy with A pistol. The headshots not instantly killing makes this game more of an RPG than A Third Person Shooter. I mean It totally takes you out of the game. 
I think they did that way to attract a certain kind of audience, to avoid criticism from GTA 5 players and to attract less the Third Person Shooter kind of crowd, and more the RPG Stealth kind. Because, the stealth In this game Is 
amazing. 
PART 4 Playstyles
Now, from when I played the demo or maybe It was A youtube video. But, they said there's 3 kinds of Playstyles in this game; The Ghost, The Guns Blazing, The Trickster. The Ghost does exactly what you think it does, they 
use nonlethal means and avoid arousing suspicion to complete missions. The Guns Blazing goes Into combat shooting every one and going on mass murder sprees to complete missions. The Trickster Is somewhere in between but not really,
The Trickster relies on tricks to pacify and to mess with the AI's behavior to compelete missions.
PART 5 Budget
So, now for most people they don't take this Into account.  But, some of the best games cost millions of dollars to make. And just mark off all the features and production parts of the game as trivial. 
But, there was A lot of thought put Into games like this and the cost was high to even make this game. Anyway, this game was released In 2016 with A budget of 11,000,000 Dollars and made 600,000,000 Dollars, claimed as A commercial and critical success.

Emerges as a vibrant and compelling open-world adventure that vastly improves upon its predecessor. Set in a meticulously recreated version of San Francisco, the game offers players a captivating playground for hacking, exploration, and story-driven missions. The protagonist, Marcus Holloway, brings a fresh and charismatic energy to the narrative, while the game's emphasis on hacking and social commentary feels more refined and relevant. The improved driving and combat mechanics enhance the overall gameplay experience, making for more enjoyable action sequences. With its seamless integration of technology, humor, and a socially conscious narrative, Watch Dogs 2 stands as a worthy and entertaining follow-up that successfully revitalizes the series and delivers an engaging modern-day hacker tale.

"Watch Dogs 2 offers a refreshing take on the open-world genre, providing an engaging mix of hacking, action, and exploration. The game's portrayal of a near-future San Francisco is both vibrant and dynamic, inviting players to interact with the city and its inhabitants in unique ways.

The hacking mechanics are a standout feature, allowing players to manipulate technology to achieve their objectives. It's incredibly satisfying to infiltrate security systems, control vehicles remotely, and disrupt enemy plans with a few strokes on the in-game smartphone.

The characters are well-written and likable, contributing to a more lighthearted and humorous tone compared to its predecessor. The diverse cast adds depth to the narrative and makes the story missions genuinely enjoyable.

The freedom to approach missions with stealth or all-out action adds replayability, and the ability to tackle objectives in various creative ways is a testament to the game's design. The cooperative multiplayer mode further enhances the experience, offering collaborative hacking challenges that can lead to some truly memorable moments.

While the game excels in many areas, some occasional technical glitches and AI inconsistencies can disrupt the immersion. Additionally, the story's plot twists might not resonate with everyone, and the humor may occasionally fall flat.

Overall, Watch Dogs 2 is a fantastic sequel that successfully builds upon its predecessor's foundation. With its engaging hacking mechanics, memorable characters, and lively world, it's a title that offers hours of entertaining gameplay for those who enjoy action-packed adventures in a tech-savvy world."

At least Watch Dogs 1 had a respectable main character and a half-decent story. Opening this game, I am immediately bombarded with the most on-the-nose, predictable introduction to a story I could possibly imagine. They didn't even [i]try[/i] to make it subtle. From the very beginning it forces you to sit through minutes long cutscenes where a narrator explains to you "GOVERNMENT BAD. GOVERNMENT SPY ON YOU. CORPORATION BAD. CORPORATION SELL DATA. ANARCHY GOOD. HACKER GOOD." The narration genuinely feels like I'm being lectured like a six year old.
The game also of course opens in the laziest way possible, following our protagonist breaking into a highly secure building to do something no one has ever done before. Who is he? How does he have the talents to delete his ctOS profile, something nobody has ever done before, and yet he somehow doesn't have the capacity to hack a forklift until you research it?
The dedsec characters themselves are also walking stereotypes of the modern internet. Every character is identified primarily by some surface-level detail about themselves. The protagonist and the other black character have almost nothing in common besides the fact that they're black, and that makes itself perfectly clear in the way that from the VERY moment these two characters speak for the first time the only thing they have to talk to eachother about is the fact that they're black.

If this is the level of storytelling I can expect out of this game, I'll pass. It feels more like I'm playing a piece of propaganda than it is a video game.

Watch_Dogs 2 is a fantastic, and criminally underrated game that had a huge mountain to climb back in the day after the monumentally disappointing original. This sequel doesn't take itself as anywhere near as seriously and instead provides a highly enjoyable experience in an incredibly immersive and detailed city. 

You play the role of young hacker Marcus Holloway as he teams up with hacking group DeadSec in San Francisco to take down the notorious ctOS 2.0 surveillance system taking over every aspect of the city. The visuals even today look absolutely stunning and the sheer detail of the city is incredible at times. Missions are varied and thoroughly enjoyable plus they can be completed in several ways thanks to your gadgets.

I did find the cast surprisingly likeable and the story is pretty entertaining even if a bit cheesy. NPC's feel pretty dynamic at times and the world always feels vibrant. This is by far the best game in the series and it's a real shame they didn't continue this standard with the third instalment of Legion.

Overall, I can say that this game is truly outstanding. This is the first game I've played in the Watch Dogs franchise. I've seen reviews and gameplay videos of other Watch Dogs games, but I decided to try this one first. Let's dive into it.

[h2] Graphics [/h2] 
Perfect. Maybe in 10 years, people will still be playing this game. The visual quality is on another level. I was impressed with the LOD and the overall aesthetics. It's freaking beautiful, especially when it comes to the city landmarks on the San Francissco map (Golden Gate Bridge is the best). U have a camera, use it.

[h2] Performance [/h2]
Some Ubisoft games I've played on platforms other than Steam, have poor performance and shiddy framerate. However, this time I'm satisfied with the frame rate. I got around 50-60 fps while playing on high settings at 1080p. The graphics are not too demanding, yet they still look stunning even on low settings.

[h2] Gameplay [/h2] 
I always imagined a game like this similar to GTA. Although not everything you can do in GTA is possible in this game, it still offers a unique experience. Playing as Marcus, a fast-paced character also good at sneaking combat, making the gameplay enjoyable and dynamic. Sometimes, the enemy NPCs can be a bit dumb and too easy to take down, but at other times, it can be challenging to remove the bounty stars.

[h2] Online activity [/h2] 
I've had numerous encounters with people in online sessions. I particularly enjoy PvP hacking invasions and other online co-op missions in this game (PvP bounty hunter is also the best one).

[h2] Story [/h2] 
The storyline can be described as impressive. The characters are well-rounded and likable, with unique personalities and individual story arcs. There are also plenty of funny and [i]cringey[/i] moments in this game too. Never forget to mention that WKZ news report on the phone and radio always keeps me entertained.

[h2] NPC behavior [/h2]
Every NPC in this game of course has a different name and even some of them look like the same model, but their recent activities and current jobs impressed me. I love how they interact with each other. Their conversations, and activities together are also good to praise. Look as realistic.

[h2] Things I don't like in this game[/h2] 
- Driving mechanics is not what I expected it would be. I can barely drive normally.
- Bullshhh enemy NPCs know exactly where I'm hiding, even in the bushes. Sometimes, hiding in a car proves to be useless.
- No Steam achievements bruhh.
- [spoiler] Controversial flags and pride-related things in the game. I'm not triggered by a flag but it's all over the place. [/spoiler]
- [spoiler] The Cyber Driver mission. [/spoiler]

Despite these drawbacks, I still highly recommend this game. I would give it an overall rating [b]8.5/10[/b]. Haven't played it yet? Do yourself a favor and have a go.

Ubisoft Montreal takes the open-world action-adventure genre to new heights with its hacking-centric gameplay. Set in the vibrant and tech-savvy San Francisco Bay Area, this sequel introduces a host of improvements and additions that make for an exhilarating and immersive gaming experience.

Graphics:
The graphics are visually stunning, depicting a beautifully recreated San Francisco and its surrounding areas. The attention to detail is impressive, from the iconic landmarks to the bustling streets filled with dynamic NPCs. The lighting effects and weather changes contribute to the game's realism, creating an atmospheric and engaging environment.

Gameplay:
The gameplay is the heart of "Watch Dogs 2," and it shines through its innovative hacking mechanics. Players step into the shoes of Marcus Holloway, a talented hacker who joins the hacker group DedSec to combat corporate corruption and oppression. The ability to hack into various devices, manipulate city infrastructure, and use stealth tactics offer a refreshing take on traditional action-adventure gameplay.  Moreover, the game gives players the freedom to approach missions in different ways, allowing for a mix of stealth, combat, and hacking tactics. The hacking options are diverse and creative, enabling players to feel like true digital vigilantes in the expansive sandbox of San Francisco.  While the game's AI is generally competent, there might be instances where enemy AI behavior appears inconsistent or lacks depth. This can occasionally lead to moments where the challenge feels artificial or less immersive.

Story and Characters:
The story is mildly compelling and but not poorly paced, revolving around themes of surveillance, privacy, and the power of information. The diverse characters of DedSec contribute to the game's charm, with each member bringing unique skills and personalities to the table.  While the antagonist Dusan Nemec has a significant presence in the game, his character development could have been further explored. Additional backstory or moments that delve into his motivations and background could have made him a more well-rounded and compelling character.  Nevertheless Marcus Holloway is a relatable and charismatic protagonist, making players invested in his journey to take down corrupt corporations and expose the truth. The narrative is also laced with humor and wit, making it an enjoyable experience from start to finish. Players will find themselves emotionally invested in the characters' motivations and connected to the larger fight against oppressive forces.

Sound:
The game's sound design enhances the overall experience, immersing players in the bustling urban atmosphere of San Francisco. The dynamic soundtrack complements the action and perfectly captures the vibrant and rebellious spirit of DedSec. The voice acting is top-notch, bringing the characters to life with authenticity and emotional depth.

Setting and Presentation:
San Francisco serves as a stunning and diverse playground for players to explore. The city's landmarks, neighborhoods, and iconic areas are recreated with meticulous attention to detail, making the open-world setting a joy to explore. Whether it's the bustling streets of downtown or the serene beauty of Marin County, the game offers an authentic depiction of the Bay Area. The presentation is sleek and stylish, with a user-friendly interface and smooth navigation. The attention to detail in the environment and character animations further elevates the overall presentation, creating an engaging and immersive experience.

Rating:
This is a remarkable open-world adventure that successfully builds upon its predecessor. With impressive graphics, innovative hacking gameplay, a captivating story, memorable characters, and excellent sound design, it offers an unforgettable experience. This thrilling digital playground of San Francisco will leave players entertained and immersed in its world long after the credits roll. I would rate this 9/10. Great

Watch_Dogs 2 is honestly one of the better "open world" titles out there. I played the game on the hardest difficulty (I really enjoy stealth) and honestly, outside of a few moments I had an amazing time. I didn't really engage with the multiplayer content, but the main game, the side quests, and in world activities are great. The Driver San-Francisco quests for one were great! 

Gameplay: Solid. Marcus controls well, flows well, and the driving is a huge step from the first game. Combat is FAST with high risk high reward. I would say this game plays better as a "fast" stealth game. While it does have its problems, specifically certain weapons ruining the balance, if you're capable of limiting yourself there is a TON of fun to be had. 

NPCs are actually quite realistic, compared to most other games I've seen, they do feel like they have lives, they interact with your character, especially when he's doing things that are not "appropriate" for the environment. Gangs fight each-other on the streets making a constant stream of chaos something that's possible to achieve. Paired with your hacking tools which allows you to distract enemies, explode grenades, move cars, and call in the police or other gangs there are tons of ways you can manipulate the world to do what you want it to. I also think it's fair to note that while police are insanely easy to avoid even at the level 5 wanted level, the chases are insanely fun even with a fully leveled character. I got the little electric Go-Kart and had probably the most fun police chase around the city, and that's largely due to the map, driving down narrow alleys, up and down stairs, through parks, off of ledges while the police were just doing their best to keep up is the best. 

The map is really amazing, this is something Ubisoft has always done well in my opinion, and this game lets it shine. Landmarks even have their own "app" that lets you find these unique places and it is honestly quite fun being able to just walk the city, steal money, botnet, read other people's texts and explore the landmarks. The game really is quite picturesque. There's even a free hi-res DLC that I would recommend. 

Plot wise this game is...okay. It loses itself in a few places, and of course the memes and humor have not really dated that well. Everyone beside Marcus is quite shallow and goofy, I'd even go as far to say that certain parts are quite cringy. But overall, the actual story is good enough for what it is. Gameplay actions vs the story's tone often don't match up (violent murder sprees vs the "killing people bad" moments). 

In conclusion? Great game. Solid entry into the series, and imo the most solid. Pick it up on sale and burn through it in 1-2 weeks easily.

Taking a brighter approach to world-building as we move from the dark streets of Chicago to the bright and sunny beaches of San Francisco. Hack your way into the world's now largest security organisation "Blume" and expose how they take advantage of their users to gain leverage over them. Watchdogs series is a criticism of the current time of our world. How the invasion of privacy can lead to disaster in the hands of the wrong individuals. 

Once again, apart from being made by the 2nd worst game developer, it is actually quite fun to play.

Multiplayer is a thing in this game, whether its co-op or PvP showdowns.

Open world is a very close replica of the real life San Francisco. Many of the locations are present and interact-able.

-

A big negative is that instead of a dramatic story with solid reasons for our main character; we have lousy, irresponsible and awkward teenagers who occasionally get detained for "loitering". Therefore it is hard to feel connected to the characters, except for Wrench, who happens to have the only decent story.

There are references to the first game. Dlc is kind of a joke, steer clear of that.

-

Fun game to play with friends (given you have any), worth at its base price. But if you really don't wanna give Ubisoft more money, then wait for a discount.

This is my first Watch Dogs experience. I read a ton of reviews and heard that Legion wasn't well received so i decided on 2. I mostly play Call of Duty so I was looking for something more chill when I'm playing alone, something I can enjoy and not have to think too hard for. This game has been fun for that. Im playing on normal mode and it's been pretty easy. I really like the story and there's always objectives all over to keep me busy. It's most comparable to the GTA games: you run around in third person, hijack cars, have all kinds of unlawful missions etc. This game adds a hacking feature though, which initially reminded me of Cyberpunk (which I like a lot). The hacking is pretty simple though, its actually a pretty small part of the game. Watch Dogs 2 is like that one eccentric friend who somehow manages to turn even the simplest of tasks into a wild adventure that leaves you in stitches. In this comically chaotic open-world game, you find yourself hacking everything under the sun while also being a part of the hippest, tech-savvy hacker group in town. From taking control of unsuspecting pedestrians' cars and driving them into rivers, to unleashing swarms of farting drones upon unsuspecting enemies, this game takes hilarity to a whole new level. It's like a technological version of the Wild West, where the hackers are the cowboys, and the city itself is their untamed playground. With its tongue-in-cheek humor, memorable characters, and outrageous missions, it's impossible not to laugh your way through the Bonkers Bay Area. Just be prepared to explain to your neighbors why you burst into fits of laughter while sitting alone in a dark room with a controller in your hand.

After playing both of the Watch Dogs games I am writing these reviews to compare the two and the experience I had playing them in 2023, after never having played either before.

I find Watch Dogs 2 to be a pretty phenomenal experience, it has a fun movement system, a pretty expansive (although lacking in comparison to the first's) gun library, and a lot of extra content, while the story in this game I will say is rather uninteresting and more dubbed down than the first's, the extra content, skills and online functionality are much better. I believe the final mission is 10X better than the first games finale and would have gone the mile to 100% the game, if it had steam achievements.

Besides those points I personally believe Watch Dogs 2 is the best Watch Dogs game and would recommend it to anyone for the fun factor alone.

Overall, I mostly enjoyed the game as long as I was sticking to DLC and main quests, and fully utilizing all the tools and abilities and focusing on stealth gameplay. Just be warned, the game quickly gets frustrating and punishing if you go off the stealth rails, and the side activities are mostly a repetitive waste of time.

If you do end up playing this, I would suggest minimize time on side quests and side activities as they get really repetitive. You get enough XP from the main and DLC quests to get the upgrades that actually matter, and those quests are more fun to play.

Good
+ The main quest has a good pacing to it and ends strong. Doesn't suffer from the problem of some AAA games where the good stuff is front-loaded.
+ Fun and thematic stealth action. When it all comes together and you're using a combination of the RC vehicles, taking control of things, and using hacking abilities and moving around as Marcus, it makes for quite a fun challenge
+ Enjoyed the story, characters, environments,
+ The original music tracks are pretty good too, especially during the missions. Nothing super memorable, but fitting and unique.

Bad
- The pursuits (by police, gangs, etc...) are frustrating and tedious, especially because the upgrades you get to make them easier actually seem to make them HARDER. Basically, using them to take out the enemies pursuing you can make it harder to escape. More enemies spawn out of nowhere to replace the ones you took out, almost immediately, and they spawn outside of your map view, surprising you. This even applies to the helicopters and also when on foot.

- The game discourages gunplay in a number of ways, despite giving you a lot of guns and related upgrades. You die quickly and you never get any sort of armor, and some of the enemies have a lot of HP and have some powerful guns. Especially towards the later game. Furthermore, your RC vehicles respawn but you don't. Often, if you die you restart the whole mission. So the more you can rely on your hacking abilities and RC car, the better. You will be punished if you, like I did, see guns as a valid playstyle rather than a situational option.

- The stealth can be janky and unpredictable until you learn its quirks. Sometimes when you are completely in stealth and you pop up to shoot someone, they will magically report your location to everyone for the microsecond between when you were visible and you shot and now you're in combat. Sometimes they don't. There are some silenced weapons, and some stun weapons, and the game doesn't really explain what effect those have on detection. 

- The non-combat/non-stealth gameplay gets really repetitive and tedious. I'm talking about roofs. Man, the game designers were OBSESSED with roofs and ways of getting up to them. You might as well call this "roof based gameplay" because it basically ends up always being "find a way to climb onto this rooftop" and it gets old fast. Find a crane, lift, vent for the rc car, or vehicle than can help you get higher to get to the objective. And that's basically it barring a few exceptions to make "clever" puzzles that end up being more annoying than everything. A lot of those things are really agonizingly slow as well, like moving lifts and cranes, driving around scissor lifts, etc...making these things even more annoying. This is especially the case for research points.

- For how much time you spend getting up to and down from roofs, they sure don't give you many tools to make this fun, interesting, or to speed it up in any way. For example even just getting down from rooftops to be on your way is a huge pain because you take falling damage and you have ZERO tools for climbing down. Like 99% of open world games of this sort have already figured this out.There are research points that you can't get without certain upgrades and the game doesn't warn you about this, causing you to waste quite a bit of time not knowing if something is currently possible to get.

Having been an ardent fan of the series, I snagged the Gold Edition of Watch Dogs 2 right upon its 2016 release.

The story revolves around Marcus, a hacker from San Francisco, joining forces with the hacker group DedSec, all with the shared goal of shutting down the city's intrusive surveillance system, ctOS 2.0. The formidable opponent they're up against is none other than Blume, a powerful entity controlling governmental resources.

Stacking it up against its predecessor, it's impossible not to notice the significant graphical upgrade and the contrasting narrative in Watch Dogs 2. Where the first game presented a somber, introspective journey following Aiden's solitary quest for vengeance in the desolate cityscape of Chicago, the sequel paints a vivid picture of hip-hop culture and the dynamic, warm hues of San Francisco. Though the sequel's narrative features a sunnier disposition, it still struggles to elicit strong emotions or create unforgettable moments, a common pitfall for many sequels. That being said, it's undeniably a noteworthy title worth adding to any gamer's collection.

Now, let's turn to Watch Dogs 3: Legion, which, I should mention, is indeed available on Steam. As a die-hard fan of the series, I was among the first to pre-order the Ultimate Edition in 2019. Unfortunately, Legion fell short of my expectations. I find myself straining to recall the main plot. Its futuristic London setting felt too familiar and lacked novelty, as if Ubisoft had taken the easy way out. However, the redeeming factor was the DLC content, bringing back our original protagonist, Aiden, back into the narrative fold.

Throughout the trilogy, the narrative evolves around the totalitarian central control system, CTOS, presenting unique tales of resistance - from an individual (Aiden), to an organization (DedSec), and eventually to society at large (Legion). It's an engaging narrative, particularly when the underdog is pitted against a power behemoth. However, Ubisoft's core message may be missed by many players.

The question we should be asking is: are we already living in a dystopia dominated by totalitarian technology? If we are, are there hackers like Anonymous out there, fighting back? Most people may not recognize this potential danger, and such obliviousness is itself a significant threat. Could 'Legion' be a prophecy of our future, leading to more and more people joining hacker collectives in the name of justice and human rights?

As Edmund Burke famously said, "The only thing necessary for evil to triumph is for decent people to do nothing." In a world where injustice is rampant, we might choose to live with silent anger and follow the so-called "rules" of survival, but who will stand up for us when our freedoms are compromised? Who will seek justice on our behalf?

In the words of Aiden and Reggie (Wrench) -

Aiden: "I once spent my life fighting people like Lambert because I simply thought it was worth it... and it didn't work."
Reggie: "So what? Should we give up?"
Aiden: "No, you shouldn't give up. Some resistance is worth losing everything you have."

Through the series, Ubisoft has gifted us with a lone wolf hacker with unwavering moral integrity, and an organization unwavering in its pursuit of justice. These narratives encourage us to confront the totalitarian implications of technology.

Although Aiden may be gone, his legacy lingers on. He's a symbol of street justice that transcended his own solitude and grief. My hope is that, in the face of encroaching totalitarianism, we can find our own inner Aiden.

However, after Legion, I've found it hard to ignore a nagging sense of disillusionment. It feels as if the spirit of resistance that once permeated the series has been lost. Much like how there were no Assassins after the Great Revolution, it seems there are no hackers after Watch Dogs 1. A poignant reminder that even in gaming, all good things must come to an end.

I really, really tried to give this game the benefit of the doubt and to hang on, but I cannot any further.

tl;dr: a game that shows promise and has its fun moments, but is sunk by extremely lazy and careless design and direction.

The good:
Graphics: 
The bay area setting is beautiful and quite nicely rendered. The game is PS4-era so don't expect to be wowed too much, and it has some optimization issues when you run it at 4k with framerate stutters in situations you wouldn't expect, but generally it looks great for its age and the city is vibrant and beautiful.

Banter: The game's new characters, which sometimes join you on missions but almost always take a "the guy /gal in the chair" position, are fun and have some level of fleshing out. Not all of them and not too deeply (bear in mind I put a bit under 20h into the game but never reached the end so I may be underinformed). The group is generally fun to talk to, although they are a bit naive if not oblivious (going after government agencies, other hacker groups and literal narco-gangs like they're not afraid of what it could do to them, so on).

Hacking improvements: 
Some quality of life improvements over Watchdogs 1 hacking, like better versatility in hack options, remote triggers, scouting devices like the "quadcopter" (a quad-motor aerial drone) and the... idr what they called it but it's an RC car; and inally a way to hack helicopters to get them off you (need to work to upgrade for it, but it's there).


The very, very bad:
Shallow GTA clone:
Coming out 3 years after GTA, I guess Ubisoft was in a panick and said "COPY EVERYTHING!.... but don't bother about doing it well".
You have it all. Random events happening around you - including police violence (I saw police randomly attack civilians - with lethal force even - for no reason), drive-by's (saw a guy drive up to a random dude, unload a full smg mag onto him [from inside the car, which you cannot even do as a player] and drive off while the other npcs went about their business), and random gang-fights (which the police generally ignores, or sometimes joins in - on the side of one gang, never seemingly wanting to do anything except shoot the last person to shoot near them).
Radio: but only 5 stations, with dubious genre relevance ("rock" meaning "anything not pop", pop meaning "whatever the sound guy liked", "electronica" meaning...)
Super-illegal-weapons: The game is set in the Bay Area, but doesn't try to go "this is alternate universe, where there are zero gun laws" like GTA. You can build (3d-print, yeah) multiple grenade launchers and other weaponry that would get you super-max'd... all from the comfort of your basement.
Mass-murder-immunity: Wanna kill a dozen civilians? a hundred cops? literal FBI agents? All fair game as long as you drive away and hide for a half minute.
Cars, boats, bikes, drive whatever: The driving physics aren't too bad - below GTA V's but not terrible; however most cars feel and drive alike and if you don't buy the vehicle (using, of course, in-game-apps) it will disappear as soon as any cutscene or loading takes place.

The enemy AI is not just extremely bad, it is "I thought I would never see AI like this after we left the PS3/Xbox-360/etc console generation". If an enemy sees you, even for a milisecond, even if you shoot them in the head at the precise point they noticed you, EVERYONE knows where you are. And I mean everyone, enemies off-map will come for you, enemies that were on the opposite side of the building and could never have known, will come for you. But! If they don't know where you are, you can kill them all off, one by one - shooting them, dropping bombs on them, detonating hazards near them, and they will go "wow, that's really weird, we should investigate but I can't call for reinforcements until any one of us sees the guy themselves [then we all can and will as we are telepathically bonded like a hive-mind and will instantly know everything about him --- even when we are a lowly gang-member minding their business guarding a drug stash, we will instantly know that the guy shooting us with a literal grenade launcher is "one of those hacker guys"].

Back on the "shoot people with impunity side"... Watchdogs 1 had its dark edge - you were a guy on a revenge rampage, a morally-grey if not fully dark-side guy looking to get vengeance for a dead family member. And even then, it was hard for me to get half of the kill-count I got in on this game halfway through. In this game, you are a happy-go-lucky hacker that joins a group of wannabe-techno-anarchists looking to "do good" and "fight the evil guys taking our liberties and information" and whatnot.
And yet the game is so happy to let you become a psychotic mass-murdering terrorist without consequence.
You can kill cops, gang members, FBI agents and civilians without anyone in your little hacktivist group batting an eye or even making mention of it. You can literally construct IEDs and weapons the NRA would be unable to justify any civilian posession or use of in any state - and you do it in a state with some of the more restrictive gun laws in the US.

Sure, you could go harmless/less-than-lethal stealth, but the game does not want that. At all. Between the hive-mind AI, most missions being of the "infiltrate this location that has ~10-25 armed guards who can also call more as reinforcements" and the "there is absolutely no penalty for killing everyone here, even civilians" mechanics, you need to be roleplaying for your own pleasure (and using your imagination to pretend it even mattered) not to.

------------

The game shows promise and could've been great, but it's design and delivery are so thoughtless it is just way too jarring and incongruent of a final product to deliver much more than occasional "ah that's cute/funny/lolzy" moments in a sea of "everything about this is terrible and I don't care anymore".

Will you have fun playing this?
At times, probably. In general, it depends how forgiving you are of how hard it will try to persuade you to go play something else. And there are so many better games out there, there is no reason to waste your time on this one.

Finally beat this game after having played it alot when I was young and then abandoning it midway through. Definately has some problems and some kinda lame ubisoft mission design but the core gameplay story, setting have all been vastly improved from the original. When it comes to gameplay its alot of fun with the heavier usage of drones in this game that make u feel more stealthy and hacker-esque lol. Also the inlcusion of a simple parkour system makes the combat encounters and traversal of the world more enjoyable. There would be missions where I would have to infiltrate a gang hideout, And instead of breaking in directly id find a parkour route to the top of the building and take out people from there, or in a cop chase climbing a tower and then lobbing grenades at their cars while the circle around the building. It just adds alot more variety and experimentation to the combat. Graphics are honestly kinda eh sadly there are alot better looking games that came out even in 2016 alone. Also the stories alot more fun than the last one. While the overly jokey writing misses alot and can sometimes feel like late 30 year olds trying to write dialogue that appeals to young people, it has a certain fuck the man attitude to it that feels genuine. Also alot more punk influence than I remember hearing one of my favourite dead kennedy's songs on the radio was a fun suprise 7.5/10

This game is decent, but if you have already played Watch Dogs 1 or 3 there isn't much here for you. While the gameplay is better than Watch Dogs 1 the story is much worse. 

Pros:
- game looks great
- gameplay is fun for a while, but not solid enough to warrant a second playthrough
- using the drones is fun

Neutral:
- forced PvP/PvE events that you either have to opt out of in the options or disable anti-cheat (I enjoyed these at first but they happen so often that eventually I had to disable them to just get on with the story)
- missions are very samey and I got bored of them
- lots of collectables which at first are fun but eventually became a boring slog

Cons:
- extremely cringey "celebration of nerd culture" dialog. Did they hire the writers from Big Bang Theory? I couldn't skip the dialog fast enough
- sky rapidly flickers and the devs blame nvidia
- physics absolutely borked when running on a powerful PC with high FPS
- messed up ragdoll physics cause killed enemies to fly around in the sky and bounce off walls, alerting other enemies and making stealth impossible
- cranes do not work properly at higher frame rates and whip around at mach 10, instantly killing you. Several missions require the use cranes so you will have to limit your frame rate to 60 then hope and pray that the cranes work when you restart the game
- higher difficulties often require abusing mechanics or playing in lame ways, like repeatedly using drones to drop explosives on enemies while hiding around a corner
- lots of time consuming use of cranes and lift trucks, I got very impatient with them

Conclusion:
Skip this game unless you really want to be hacker mans and like cringey dialog. Maybe worth a try if you can pick it up for $5.

This was honestly way better than I expected! 

Very large map, with lots to do, lots of both offline and online content, lots of stuff to collect and stories to live out. Loading times are also very short, so fast traveling is not a waiting game.

Gunplay improved massively from the first game, and `arcade` driving feel has also improved (but still feels a little over the top). 

New gadgets felt amazing, (you get the RC car and the quad drone to help you out in hacking), and now you can hack many more things (like cranes, lifts, forklifts etc.). However, hacking is the same like in the first game, with the hardest hacks being `connect the pipes` mini-game. 

Outside some aspects that annoy me on a personal level (pushing `woke` stuff, like pride, trans and other similar themes for unnecessary reasons), this game is pretty much a great addon to a more grounded GTA format of games. It improved everything that the first game had problems with and added a ton more things to do, and ways to do it.

The only thing I didn`t like is how the story panned out. It is very...cringy on so many levels and it felt like the `memes` were forced into the game on many occasions. Also, the videos that were created after every main mission (like a collage of what you did, but in a 8-bit/hacking way, made for your followers to see) were very...hard to watch to say the least. 

However, the core graphics and open world interactions felt so good, it is fine to let it slide.

A very strong 9/10.

It's rare that I get so frustrated with a game... but this thing just crashes left right and center for no reason. Would not recommend, basically unplayable. Go play Watch_Dogs 1 which is the best game in the series, no bullsh*t follower collecting, just simply a hacking game (which is why you bought this in the first place presumably). I don't remember that game crashing at all plus it was very enjoyable.
As for when the game actually runs, I'd say the only enjoyable thing is the city. Overall it's clear that much more quality work went into the art, textures, and the world as a whole vs, the programming (hacking game with 'script kiddies' developing it huh xD). The only consistent thing about the game is how trash the driving is compared to every other ubi game.

This is not to say that the foundation on which the game is built isn't good, just please do justice to the core gameplay mechanics by maintaining the pretty visuals and sounds, and taking a long hard look at the code.

EDIT: While the next 15 hours of BSODs and crashes weren't so nice, some of the later missions were enjoyable and there are some neat music choices in them as well. To top it all off, the ending is satisfying.
Don't take the game too seriously and you will have a ton of fun

Today, mainstream usage of "hacker" mostly refers to computer criminals, due to the mass media usage of the word since the 1990s.[5] This includes what hacker slang calls "script kiddies", people breaking into computers using programs written by others, with very little knowledge about the way they work. This usage has become so predominant that the general public is largely unaware that different meanings exist.[6] While the self-designation of hobbyists as hackers is generally acknowledged and accepted by computer security hackers, people from the programming subculture consider the computer intrusion related usage incorrect, and emphasize the difference between the two by calling security breakers "crackers" (analogous to a safecracker).

The controversy is usually based on the assertion that the term originally meant someone messing about with something in a positive sense, that is, using playful cleverness to achieve a goal. But then, it is supposed, the meaning of the term shifted over the decades and came to refer to computer criminals.[7]

As the security-related usage has spread more widely, the original meaning has become less known. In popular usage and in the media, "computer intruders" or "computer criminals" is the exclusive meaning of the word today. (For example, "An Internet 'hacker' broke through state government security systems in March.") In the computer enthusiast (Hacker Culture) community, the primary meaning is a complimentary description for a particularly brilliant programmer or technical expert. (For example, "Linus Torvalds, the creator of Linux, is considered by some to be a hacker.") A large segment of the technical community insist the latter is the "correct" usage of the word (see the Jargon File definition below).

Representation in mainstream media
The mainstream media's current usage of the term may be traced back to the early 1980s. When the term, previously used only among computer enthusiasts, was introduced to wider society by the mainstream media in 1983,[8] even those in the computer community referred to computer intrusion as "hacking", although not as the exclusive definition of the word. In reaction to the increasing media use of the term exclusively with the criminal connotation, the computer community began to differentiate their terminology. Alternative terms such as "cracker" were coined in an effort to maintain the distinction between "hackers" within the legitimate programmer community and those performing computer break-ins. Further terms such as "black hat", "white hat" and "gray hat" developed when laws against breaking into computers came into effect, to distinguish criminal activities from those activities which were legal.

I got Watch_Dogs 2 Standard Edtition free on Ubisoft App and completed a while back. 

This game is just amazing and fun and could be a 10/10 in my books if not for poor Ubisoft Launcher issues sometimes. 

Gameplay -> WD2 is a an amazing game which keeps the true spirit of hacking right till the end and it is so satisfying to play with. 

Missions -> Mission design were pretty much similar to each other but, it had nice mix and match of elements. Gameplay felt fresh to me for it's entirety.

Story -> Story was surprisingly interesting for my liking. Dystopian sci-fi tech plot which still connected to reality.

Characters -> No character growth but each of the 4 main characters (+2 rotating) and Main Villain actually had nice and different personality to them. Marcus and Wrench duo is probably the most fun to watch. 

Online -> There are still quite some players in online as of June 2023 and you can see random mission popping for pvp or co-op. Online is also very fun.

Gold Edition had 2 Expansions and few cosmetics =》 DLC missions are about total 7 hours long with 1 new enemy type and 1 old character making his return from WD1. 

My Total PlayTime -> 75 hours (including Ubi)
This is nearly 100% completion + Online. 

Is the game worth it ?? Yes, but only at a nice discount because it is 7 years old now.

This song has completely captured my heart and soul. From the moment the I got the RC Jumper and the story starts to weave its way through my ears, I'm transported to a different realm where all that exists is the pure, unadulterated emotion of the game. As the gameplay unfold, I find myself drawn deeper and deeper into the story that the game is telling, feeling every word as if it were my own. The rawness and vulnerability of the action, combined with the intricacy and complexity of the story, create a sonic landscape that is both breathtakingly beautiful and emotionally cathartic. It's rare to come across a game that speaks so directly to the human experience, that touches on the universal themes of love, loss, and the search for meaning in this world. But this song does all that and more, reminding me that no matter how lonely or isolated we may feel at times, we are all connected by the power of games and the shared experiences that it brings. The way the game builds and crescendos, the way the action ebb and flow, the way the story paint a picture of hope and longing, all of it comes together to create a truly transcendent experience. It's the kind of game that you want to play to over and over again, each time discovering something new and meaningful that you missed before. So thank you to Ubisoft of this masterpiece for giving us all a gift that will last a lifetime. You have truly created something special, and I'm grateful to be able to experience it.

This game is pretty fun in all aspects involving the gameplay. The map is a blast to transverse, both by car and by foot because of its highly interactive world filled with cool things to mess with like the traffic lights, other cars or just bully random NPCs. The driving feels pretty good too, even though the cars might feel a little bit floaty. Also the gunplay is great, with pretty varied weapons which might feel a little bit too basic but when combined with the ability to hack the world and the gadgets available is pretty satisfying. And the side activities are pretty varied and fun too, ranging from invasions in other player’s worlds to kart racing.

The only cons is that the story extremely cringe and feels written by an amateur out of touch millennial writer who thinks that trends from 20-15 years ago still hold up, surprisingly the characters are pretty likable. And the missions might feel repetitive too, since they tend to be an infiltration in some random building, hack something there and leave, but there are some surprises.

Watch Dogs 2 is another popular open-world action-adventure game developed by Ubisoft. It was released in 2016 as a sequel to the original Watch Dogs game.

Watch Dogs 2 received generally positive reviews from critics and players. It was praised for its lively and detailed open-world environment, improved gameplay mechanics, and a more likable protagonist compared to the first game. The game offers various hacking abilities and tools, allowing players to manipulate the city's infrastructure and devices to achieve their goals.

Additionally, Watch Dogs 2 introduced a cooperative multiplayer mode, enabling players to collaborate with friends and participate in various online activities. The game also incorporates social commentary on issues such as privacy, surveillance, and the power of technology.

However, Watch Dogs 2 also includes mature content, violence, and themes that may not be suitable for all players. As with any game, individual preferences can vary, so it's recommended to research and consider personal preferences before playing.

Overall, Watch Dogs 2 is a fun and engaging game for those who appreciate open-world gameplay, hacking mechanics, and socially conscious narratives.

I recently purchased Watch Dogs 2 with high hopes, being a fan of the original game. However, my excitement quickly turned to disappointment within the first 10 minutes of gameplay. I encountered an overwhelming amount of bugs that made the game virtually unplayable. This is the first time I've ever uninstalled a game after such a short period of time.

From the moment I started playing, it felt like the game was determined to frustrate me. Bodies were inexplicably flying through the air, and main character was performing strange sprint strafes.

I had heard rumors about bugs plaguing the game after its release, but I couldn't fathom just how bad it would be. If my experience within the first few minutes is any indication, I can only imagine the nightmare players must have faced post-launch.

Watch Dogs 2 had the potential to be a great sequel, but the abundance of bugs and glitches completely destroyed any enjoyment I could have had. Save yourself the frustration and disappointment by avoiding this game altogether. There are plenty of other titles out there that offer a polished and enjoyable experience, and Watch Dogs 2 simply doesn't belong among them.

As of right now I'm marking this as not recommended because this issue may be a problem for those wishing to play multiplayer and needing to turn off this system security feature......

[b]Cannot start game without first disabling Kernel-mode Hardware-enforced Stack Protection[/b]
So at first install, I disabled that and restarted.
The game loads up.
I quit the game and turn back on the Stack Protection.
Restart my system.
Try launching the game again and it will not run with that protection on. EasyAntiCheat will not let me.
Unacceptable. I'm not turning that off just to run this game and possibly compromise my system protection.

I did a search online and found that I need to add -eac_launcher to the target line of the game shortcut. This though will not allow me to play multiplayer. Not a big deal for me as I generally don't play online multiplayer anyway.
For anyone else it may pose a problem.

EDIT AFTER PLAYING LEGION: Ignore WD:Legion. This is the Watch Dogs to play. It's the best of them. By far, even.

ORIGINAL TEXT:
Ahhh... Ubisoft. Their games typically checks all technical boxes (large open worlds, good mechanics, nice graphics, a ton of content, loads of player options) - but feels so generic after a short while. They lack real storytelling enthusiasm. They feel too much like polished consumer products.

And one could say the same about this game. But I think this game holds more than that.

Sure, there's a generic "hacker" story. The game do not ONCE head outside of the very standard "computer nerd/hacker community" stereotypes. Instead the story itself is essentially just ALL the cliches stacked in one giant set of missions.
There's also ZERO character development during the course of the campaign. None. The characters are the same throughout the entire campaign. Also typically Ubisoft.

But... There's still an atmosphere in this game. There's a soul to be found. There are moments where it feels like the developers here actually cares for the characters and this universe.

Or, at least I do. Maybe it is because I am a computer nerd myself. Maybe because I know people that are more or less exactly like the characters found here. But I have a jolly good time in this game.

I particularly like how the hacker gang we get to know here, are not "superheroes" in any other way than their hacker skills (who, in true Hollywood fashion, has next to zero to do with real life hacking, but let's just accept that). So we need to use our heads when solving these missions.
Sure, there's guns, but it's usually very stupid to use them.

As of their games currently available on Steam, I dare say that Ubisofts best open world game is not found among the Assassins Creeds or Far Cries:
It's this one.

I got it on sale and still feel ripped off, of course I'm refunding it. This game is barely functional, crashing every few minutes all while looking terrible in the process. What's that? You want to make it look less terrible? Well good luck, because even if you have a 3060ti this game will stutter and drop to 50fps with Anti-aliasing on. That's of course assuming you even get to run the game at all.

When I originally started this game, I didn't enjoy it that much. the writing felt stuck in the early to mid 2010s and vintage internet lingo ran amuck, and while that is true, I feel like the game also has some really solid commentary on internet and technology being exploited by corporations and higher ups. I also wasn't expecting some really, really solid representation in the form of both Josh and Miranda (neurodivergent and trans rep. respectively). Both of these characters are written very well and don't fall into the stereotypes that would appear in more poorly written media, it's nice to see. The gameplay is kinda what you expect except it feels more refined, although it still feels a little rough around the edges. I really enjoyed the hacking puzzles this time, they felt like more effort was put into them than WD 1. Overall, I really enjoyed my time with Watch Dogs 2. Rose has given you the truth, Do what you will.

This game is pretty fun in all aspects involving the gameplay. The map is a blast to transverse, both by car and by foot because of its highly interactive world filled with cool things to mess with like the traffic lights, other cars or just bully random NPCs. The driving feels pretty good too, even though the cars might feel a little bit floaty. Also the gunplay is great, with pretty varied weapons which might feel a little bit too basic but when combined with the ability to hack the world and the gadgets available is pretty satisfying. And the side activities are pretty varied and fun too, ranging from invasions in other player’s worlds to kart racing. 

The only cons is that the story extremely cringe and feels written by an amateur out of touch millennial writer who thinks that trends from 20-15 years ago still hold up, surprisingly the characters are pretty likable. And the missions might feel repetitive too, since they tend to be an infiltration in some random building, hack something there and leave, but there are some surprises.

I was honestly quite skeptical of Watch Dogs 2 before I played it. I finally played the first Watch Dogs and found it really good, like, shockingly fun and engaging! And in the first two hours, I wasn't quite sold on Watch Dogs 2. But it clicked quickly after that and I had just as much fun with that game as I did with the first.

Watch Dogs 2 is, in my eyes at least, a Jedi Academy-esque sequel in the sense it vastly improves on it's predecessor's gameplay with no (!) downsides. These improvements include:

- noticeable smoother movement
- better cover (the cover jank from the first game is GONE)
- better driving
- better radio controls with actual dedicated radio stations
- better police (you can no longer escape even the highest wanted levels just by stepping on a boat)
- different clothing stores and more clothing customization
- improved graphics (Watch Dogs looks great, but Watch Dogs 2 has notably better reflections, character models and the indoor areas, Nudle campus being my favorite, are a highlight)
- new gadgets that are actually really useful!
- more gangs (though with less significance)
- gang warfare and police gang fights, with great fun to be had with related hacking abilities
- sailboats!!!!!
- better and actually useful sightseeing
- better car app
- VASTLY expanded hacking

and so on

All that while retaining the great sandbox levels the series is known for. Now, of course, there are a few small things that aren't improved. The finance system is improved from Watch Dogs, in particular, weapons are more expensive and hacking bank accounts nets way less money. But it still is kinda broken and before you know it, you're swimming in cash with not that many ways to spend it, in particular since your ammo still gets magically filled up around missions. Gunplay is slightly worse than Watch Dogs, didn't find it that notable though, and I REALLY liked the now-removed gang hideouts.

But overall, I was just amazed by how many improvements and additions the developers came up with. In the $911 mission, during the refinery section, I took out only the mandatory targets, snuck away undetected to the nearby pier and escaped via sailboat into the sun – that was PEAK Watch Dogs!

Aside from the gameplay, it get's less exciting. As for setting and style, it's at least cohesive, though in my personal taste, I prefer gloomy autunm Chicago any day of the week over sunny SF. Ubisoft Connect is also awful, but you know that already. The story?

The Story is, well, kinda bad. Part of this might be that I played the game in German. The german dub of WD1 is actually okay, I actually prefer german Aidan Pearce as the English dub is way to deep and raspy, perhaps further alienating players from him. The German version of WD2 is super cringe at times, in particular I cringed when they word-for-word translated things like "insulting sb intelligence" or "plausible deniability" - it just doesn't work! 

That being said there still is some cringe, in particular when they use internet/nerd slang. It feels tacked on. The story has the overarching problem that it's clearly written in reaction to Aidan Pearce's unpopularity, undeserved in my opinion. Marcus and the crew are happy, colorful people with literally zero edges to them. They also take themselves way too seriously. A small revenge subplot falls flat almost immediately and another "can I trust Ray?" does too. A good character doesn't have to be likeable, he has to be interesting. I loved WD1's story because it was interesting, cohesive (WD1's world wasn't fun or colorful, it was dark, disgusting etc. and so was Pearce's mood), atmospheric and it was serious. 

There is a real lack of cohesion and disconnect from this since as Marcus you will inevitably shoot and kill people whereas the other parts of the crew seem like peaceful college hacktivist kids. This isn't helped by the fact that the reputation system from WD1 was removed. This is porbably a good thing because it limited player freedom more than it was an interesting mechanic but it makes the disconnect even more apparent as Marcus can punch hoardes of civilians with zero impact. Marcus himself is a blank slate and until an audiolog right before the last mission, there is almost no background to him! Perhaps more importantly, the missions barely tie togehter. 

Yes, WD1 does feel strechted quite a lot but every mission was connected to the ultimate goal of bringing Lena's murders to justice. In WD2, only a few missions tie in to the overarching "defeat Blume"-goal. In short: WD2' story is LACKING.

Overall, still a clear A-tier game!

A good game, with a decent history and a peaceful gameplay. Comparing to the watchdogs 1, the history it's lighter wich i believe that suits perfectly with the San Francisco vibe, while Chicago is a dark city and more likely a "corporated Gothan style" vibe, bay area is a diverse region. The darkness still exists but now share space with a giant pop culture and the cali "way of life", with the beachs, the partys and the sunset. By far, at least for me, this is the best represented San Francisco on a game, most because the year that the game is supposed to take place, 2016, a year where i watch many things that are referred to on the game and the cars, you can see the electrification taking place more and more, drones being used more by civilians and others devices too familiars. Ending this review i have one thing that can describe this game: The best Watchdogs so far and the best San Francisco on 
a game, for those who seeks a history most like a movie experience, don't be so hopeful about that, but if you want to cruise the city and have a decent history and gameplay, just absorving the California vibe, this is a good game for all you.

On the highways, you're barely passing vehicles when you're at top speed and anyone chasing you can always catch up like you're standing still... 

Overall, I'd give Watch Dogs 2 a 4/10. Was definitely expecting more out of it since I'd rate Watch Dogs 1 as a 9/10.

Another bad ubisoft game. A buggy mess with terrible collision and driving physics. The story line is nice and bland for your liking

* Not nearly enough hacking for a hacker game. Most of the gameplay is about driving cars, climbing buildings, piloting drones, throwing bombs and shooting guns.
* The general storyline is okay-ish, the final mission extremely boring and uneventful.
* The enemy AI always knows exactly where you are. If you are in hiding, they always walk towards your position for no reason. Once they spot your RC car on the other side of the building everyone magically converges around you.
* The police/gang car chase system is way too annoying and aggressive, with unlimited cops spawning from all directions every few seconds.
* I had several issues with the Ubisoft launcher which had severe connectivity issues and sometimes caused my Windows to crash.

Game pushes absolutely atrocious ideals in your face non-stop. Gameplay is awful for the most part, except when you are put in just ridiculously outnumbered firefights of one to a hundred. Makes little sense, but that part is fun I admit.

Some quests are funny, but the questing system is obnoxious, which is the reason as to why I did not finish the game. After the first few forced story missions you have enough money to buy everything you could ever need too... best guns, best vehicle(s), favorite clothes. You unlock some of the best perks in the game in the first ten hours or so.

TL;DR
+ Tons of enemies on some missions
+ High difficulty
+ The few weapons in the game are rather fun
- Very few outfit pieces
- Mission system is awful
- Run out of things to spend the abundant money on in the first 5-10 hours or less
- Pushes ideals in your face non-stop
- Cutscenes consist of a poor quality voice over when compared to Watch Dogs 1's voice overs, and flashes early 2000's memes during them instead of... anything better
- (Edit) Another major con is that you never get to learn the NPCs really, up to where I have played, the story element in the first major chunk of the game is non-existent and I don't see it improving

Just go play GTA V

- Completed the game including all DLC missions. Online related stuff avoided.
- Story was ok but it had no complexity to it... no edge of your seat intensity, nothing too dramatic or explosive with action, etc. Each mission felt like it was it's own story separate from the others.
- Gameplay was pretty good overall, but there was a large amount of quality of life issues in which they really should have fixed, but that's typical of AAA titles I guess. Get the money and move on. The missions were often a bit too similar to each other, get to a few terminals and get out, rinse and repeat. Enemy was often spongy and required several bullets to the face to kill them and always outnumbered you making loud entry very difficult and sometimes even impossible given the limited actions available and QoL controls. Enemy can wear armor but you cannot, making you an easy target... luckily, you heal fast. There's no drawbacks to killing anyone at all and no benefit to using a taser, so why bother other than immersion? Police are a joke in the game (the only thing that triggers them are if you ram your vehicle into them, be caught in a restricted area or kill someone while around them).
- Music was the worst part of this game. There wasn't a single decent song in the entire game and yet there was a lot of focus around it for some reason.
- Game also crashed to desktop several times during the last few missions (completely random).

I ran the game on max settings at 1080p with fps cap to a stable 120.
My PC specs: Ryzen 5600x, 32GB ram, EVGA RTX 3080 12GB, sata SSD

Overall: Game is good, but not great. Also, Ubisoft is garbage and tries way too hard to get in your face.

Watch_Dogs® 2 is an incredibly fun and innovative open-world game that takes the series to a whole new level. The game is set in the San Francisco Bay Area, a sprawling and diverse city that is full of life, adventure, and plenty of secrets. The game's beautiful and vibrant graphics make it one of the most visually stunning games to date.

The game's story takes the player on an engaging and thrilling journey as they take on the role of Marcus Holloway, a hacker who is out to take down the corrupt and powerful ctOS network. The game offers a huge variety of missions and activities, ranging from stealthy hacking to thrilling car chases. The game also features a strong online component, allowing for cooperative and competitive play with friends and strangers alike.

Watch_Dogs® 2 is a great game that offers something for everyone. Whether you want to explore the city or just have some fun with friends, the game has something for you. The game's visuals are stunning and the story and characters are engaging, making it a great experience. If you're looking for a fun open-world game, then Watch_Dogs® 2 is definitely worth checking out.

Chocolate Chip Cookies:
1 cup butter, softened
1 cup white sugar
1 cup packed brown sugar
2 eggs
2 teaspoons vanilla extract
1 teaspoon baking soda
2 teaspoons hot water
½ teaspoon salt
3 cups all-purpose flour
2 cups semisweet chocolate chips
1 cup chopped walnuts

Step 1
Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).

Step 2
Cream together the butter, white sugar, and brown sugar until smooth. Beat in the eggs one at a time, then stir in the vanilla. Dissolve baking soda in hot water. Add to batter along with salt. Stir in flour, chocolate chips, and nuts. Drop by large spoonfuls onto ungreased pans.

Step 3
Bake for about 10 minutes in the preheated oven, or until edges are nicely browned.

Watch_Dogs 2 is the ultimate power fantasy for those who dream of running around in pink pony underwear while hacking into everything from traffic lights to police drones. As Marcus Holloway, a young hacker with a rebellious streak, you will fight against the system and big corporations with the help of a rag-tag group of hacktivists known as DedSec.

The game takes place in the sunny and colorful San Francisco Bay Area, where you can explore every inch of the city while causing chaos with your hacking skills. Want to cause a massive traffic jam during rush hour? Hack the traffic lights. Want to take down a corrupt CEO? Hack into his personal data and expose him to the world.

The real star of the show is the pink pony underwear. As Marcus, you can proudly wear your quirky undies while taking down the bad guys.

With the ability to customize your character's appearance, you can make your digital self truly stand out. I went with a bold and unforgettable look - pony underwear, red and green sandals, a garden gnome hat, and a rainbow hippie t-shirt. Needless to say, I turned heads wherever I went.

I really do have my grievances with this game. I enjoyed the first Watch Dogs very much, got both of them on sale for $14-total, which made it an exceptionally "Yes Please!" purchase. 

The first Watch Dogs has a bit more of a sorrowful, bitter story, interesting and colorful characters, but it was nicely refined, and I initially thought it was a bummer some of the features were dead because of Ubisoft terminating online servers for it, but it is very much playable and completed without issue. It was a charming game with character, and fun to be had, while not being overwhelming.

This Watch Dogs game, well, it's definitely a Watch Dogs game. The story so far is engaging, it has interesting and colorful characters (Nevermind my obvious Wrench simping), and it's got more content, as any sequel does. But, on the contrary, these online servers are still up. Cool, right? Until me, a small noob of a player seeing the game encourage me to rob a bank trunk. Sure, I'll steal it.

 [ENEMY PLAYER JOINED EVENT] 

"What?" Before I knew it a sports car was headed for me, I jacked the bank truck and began hauling out of there, fighting this very much real player off with a slow, big truck. Police were closing in, he got the best of me, and killed me, stole the package, and somehow left, leaving the package behind. I steal the package from the street, still pursued by cops. Turns out I need to flee while the package's tracker is being hacked to disable it, so I disable the tracker, now I need to escape the cops.

 [ENEMY PLAYER JOINED EVENT] 
 [ENEMY PLAYER JOINED EVENT] 

Now TWO fools are chasing a mere beginner, mind you, I have nothing more than a stun gun and pistol, I drove a van I stole into the water by accident, going so fast. I jacked a boat and fled as the- still very real players- were entering the pier I just drove off, stole a police boat and escaped the two. Made it back on land, died, respawned, collected the package

 [ENEMY PLAYER JOINED EVENT] 

FFS a fourth player come to steal my effort! I steal a car, and since a police helicopter is following, I do the classic Watch Dogs move and hack a garage door and drive into it. It's a dead end. Cops jam the exit, kill me, the fourth player rolls in, not wanted by the cops, picks up the package, and by default wins it since he has a package with a disabled tracker and no wanted level.

Now it makes me wanna go back to Watch Dogs 1 and enjoy the fact that no random player is just gonna roll up and ruin my day. There's still missions you can do alone or co-op, but I was expecting the usual formula of 'single player unless I open a lobby to multiplayer, or join a dedicated multiplayer mode', but nah, just walking around and someone can just drive right past you. One thing's for sure, I ain't robbing another bank truck, at least until I'm loaded

Watch Dogs 2 is an open-world action-adventure game developed and published by Ubisoft. Released in 2016, it's the second instalment in the Watch Dogs series and takes place in a fictional version of San Francisco.

One of the standout features of Watch Dogs 2 is its hacking mechanics, which allow players to use their smartphone to hack into various devices and systems throughout the game world. The game's hacking abilities add a unique twist to traditional open-world gameplay mechanics, allowing players to take control of the environment and use it to their advantage.

The game's storyline and characters are also noteworthy, as they explore themes of corporate greed, government surveillance, and the power of technology. The game's protagonist, Marcus Holloway, is a likeable and relatable character, and the game's supporting cast adds to the game's overall charm and humour.

The game's open-world environment is also well-crafted, with a vast and diverse city to explore, each with its unique landmarks, neighbourhoods, and activities. Players can engage in various side missions, such as hacking into corporations, solving puzzles, and participating in mini-games.

One downside of Watch Dogs 2 is that the driving mechanics can sometimes feel clunky, and the shooting mechanics are not as polished as some other action games. However, the game's hacking abilities make up for these shortcomings and provide players with a unique and engaging gameplay experience.

Watch Dogs 2 is a fun and exciting open-world action game with a unique hacking gameplay mechanic, an engaging storyline, and well-crafted characters. While it may have some minor flaws, the game's strengths make it a must-play for fans of the genre.

This is probably the best of the Watch Dog series and really improved upon the first game ten fold. The hacking is fun, the puzzles are (while sometimes overdone) rewarding, and the overall movement feels solid. Driving is "ehh" at best (it works) and gun play could have used some improvements, but they're not "bad". Stealth works as it should and is even forgiving in my opinion.

While the dialogue is obviously dated and comes off as cringey now, the story itself is really not that bad. I found it quite enjoyable to play through and the characters do come off as pretty endearing.

I give it a solid 8.5/10

[h1] This review is written with the help of AI ChatGPT [/h1]

Watch_Dogs 2 is the ultimate video game for anyone who's ever dreamed of being a hacker superhero. Seriously, I felt like a total badass from start to finish.

The game's open-world environment is nothing short of breathtaking. I mean, who wouldn't want to explore the vibrant, tech-savvy city of San Francisco from the comfort of their couch? And the attention to detail is so impressive that I found myself getting lost in the world for hours on end.

But the real highlight of Watch_Dogs 2 is the hacking mechanics. Whether you're infiltrating a secure facility, hacking into a rival gang's network, or causing chaos in the streets, the possibilities are endless. And the fact that you can do it all with just a few keystrokes and a smartphone is nothing short of empowering.

And then there are the characters. From the lovable goofball that is Marcus to the sarcastic and tech-savvy Wrench, the game's cast is as diverse and charming as they come. I found myself rooting for them from start to finish, and their banter never failed to make me laugh.

But let's not forget about the mini-games. Who knew that drone racing and noodle-eating contests could be so addictive? I found myself spending hours perfecting my racing skills and scarfing down ramen just to unlock all the achievements.

Overall, Watch_Dogs 2 is a game that truly has it all. Stunning graphics, exhilarating gameplay, and a cast of characters that you can't help but love. I highly recommend it to anyone who wants to feel like a hacker superhero for a day (or a few hundred).
