[h1]Pros[/h1]
- [b] Improved hacking[/b]. In the original Watch_Dogs the developers decided to boil down the hacking abilities to a single button, WD2 takes the exact opposite mentality, basically every hack has multiple options that let you vary up your approach (for example turning generators into non lethal shock traps or instant lethal detonations), and you can also now use social engineering hacks to bypass combat entirely, calling in gangsters or police to pit NPCs against each other.
- [b] Dramatically improved factions[/b]. The factions in Watch_Dogs 1 almost never interacted with each other in gameplay and all felt like clones of each other, using the same enemy templates, 2 completely fixes this by having factions look visually very different from each other, and by having them infight properly, with police forces pursuing arrests or getting involved in gunfights with gangs, and using the social engineering hacks you can instigate this too to basically outsource combat, one of the best strategies to deal with criminal enemies now is to just call the police.
- [b] Fun side missions[/b]. Each of the game’s side missions has its own mini story backed up by dialogue between DedSec, making each one feel interesting enough to be worthwhile, a massive step up from Watch_Dogs 1’s generic races and gang shootouts.
- [b] Improved controls[/b]. The player can climb objects much more freely than in the first WD, (which only allowed the player to vault or jump over obstacles when specifically prompted, even if a gap was climbable, if the devs didn’t add a climb prompt, you couldn’t do it) and you can also use your melee attack whenever you want (rather than only against enemies when the game gives you a takedown prompt as in WD1).
- [b] Expanded toolset[/b]. Not only does the RC Car from the first game’s Bad Blood DLC come back, but you can also get a quadcopter too, the game also improves the player’s non lethal toolset by adding an infinite ammo stun gun that can knock out enemies.
- [b] Immersive design[/b]. Features like the world map and radio are presented as actual apps that you install on your phone, the landmark collectibles now involve taking pictures on your in-game phone camera, and even the skill tree is explained with in-game backstory (where DedSec supporters give the group their computing power, which allows them to utilise more complex hacks and training tools).
- [b] Much better character customisation[/b]. In the original Watch_Dogs Aiden only had one style and all of the other outfits you could buy were just recolours of it, in 2 you have way more variety and each individual piece of clothing can be customised, different stores will also sell different clothes as well based on theme.
- [b] Fantastic story[/b]. All of the DedSec members are genuinely likeable, well developed and worth rooting for. The game also manages to touch on real world political issues with nuance, not just on privacy rights but on other topics like police brutality and police reform, racism and out of touch corporations.

[h1]Cons[/h1]
- [b] Item Cooldowns[/b]. The crafting system of Watch_Dogs 1 was removed, now gadgets like frag grenades, shock grenades, the RC and the Quadcopter run on cooldowns, once you use up your stock of grenades, or your RC/Quadcopter is destroyed, you simply have to wait for the cooldown until you can use them again, it’s nice to know you’ll never be stuck without these things for a mission, but having to sit around waiting for them to come back is just boring. 

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Watch_Dogs 2 is the ideal benchmark for what a sequel should look like, it improves on the original game by pretty much every metric and makes for a really fun, immersive experience.

The social engineering hacks, long distance tools like the RC and Copter and decreased emphasis on combat (with the focus more going to stealth and non lethal play) make the game feel a little closer to what hacking looks like in real life, rather than a standard open world shooter with the hacking as an extra gimmick on top.

San Francisco is a gorgeous city that feels alive, with a great variety of NPC behaviour, Marcus is a likeable protagonist, the soundtrack is fun, the gameplay has depth, I really couldn’t ask for much more.

I recommend you get the Gold Edition if you can afford it, the extra DLC missions are quality additions to the game and extra gear like the Paintball Gun is great for finding new playstyles.

This is honestly the best, most immersive open world game I’ve played in years, it deserves really high praise for building off of the first game and making something far more expansive and enjoyable, just go buy it, that’s all I can say really!

amazing game that still holds up. The best game in the watch dogs franchise, I highly recommend picking it up. It goes on sale pretty often, too. I recommend playing the game on "hard" for your first attempt, "normal" if you've never played a stealth game or "ubisoft open world"-type game before.

Pros:
-It's genuinely so freeing playing this game, since you can go basically anywhere you want. The parkour isn't exactly assassin's creed tier, but it's so smooth and moving around the map feels good in and of itself.
-It's an ubisoft open world, so a lot of it is going around completing tasks around the map, but that formula works so good for this game. Each location is tackled differently, and they can be tackled in a million different ways.
-hacking is easily the best in the series. You can tackle every single objective in (and this is not an exaggeration) hundreds of different ways. From calling an APB on a guy to get him arrested, to calling their cellphone and making them distracted so you can slip past.
-The quickhacks like city blackouts are very fun, and change up how you enter an area.
-Figuring out how to get the hidden stashes and skill points throughout the map is gratifying, and you genuinely have to think about how to do some of them.


Cons:
-the game can be cheesed easily
-vehicle hacking is really rudimentary, I would love it if I could fully remote control them instead of the 4 options of forward, backward, and turn left and right.
-no reason to get in a police chase, and getting out of them is easy as hell.
-vehicle handling is pretty boring, it feels like driving an RC car with how snappy it is. It's almost impossible to lose grip and driving on highways is just boring. On the plus side, you're usually moving on foot all the time anyways since fast travel points are extremely generous.
-switching to the hacking view just makes everything blue, and destroys all of the map design that ubisoft worked so hard on. Making it so that it's on a timer, and having everything available without it would make the game look a lot better than being a giant blue polygon city all the time. It could even be done like like hitman where it functions more like an overlay where you can still see everything just fine, it just turns up the gray filter and lets you see your goals through walls.
-Lethal options in this game aren't very fun, it's way more fun to be doing melee and stun gun only runs. Which is upsetting, because there is no penalty for ignoring hacking entirely and killing everyone. It feels so good to work within the limits of nonlethal options, and it feels like the game was only designed with those options in mind, as the happy-go-lucky story doesn't match up with mass murder.
-speaking of the story, it's decent, but it doesn't really hold me all that well. There are definitely better ones out there.


Overall, I highly recommend it. There is no good comparison point I can think of, as watch_dogs is kind of unique as a series. If you like stealth games and puzzle games, this is definitely for you.

At first, I was a bit hesitant about whether I should buy this game or not. I watched quite a few YouTube videos and took a while to make a decision but once I did, I didn't regret my decision whatsoever. The game has an interesting yet enjoyable story and I think using the concept of hacking really sparks the interest of a young audience which this game targets. Watch_Dogs 2 is an outstanding open-world game that combines thrilling gameplay with a fantastic story and great characters. Set in San Francisco, the game puts you in the shoes of a young hacker named Marcus Holloway, who is trying to take down a corrupt technology corporation.

The gameplay is a real highlight of Watch_Dogs 2, with an enormous range of tools and techniques at your disposal to hack into devices, manipulate systems, and wreak havoc on your enemies. The missions are varied and exciting, with a great balance between stealth, combat, and puzzle-solving.

What sets Watch_Dogs 2 apart, however, is its fantastic story and characters. The game has a great sense of humor and a real personality, with memorable and likable characters that you'll root for throughout the story. And the storyline itself is gripping and well-written, with plenty of twists and turns that will keep you guessing until the very end.

The graphics and sound design are also top-notch, with a stunningly rendered city that really feels alive and bustling with activity. And the multiplayer mode is an absolute blast, allowing you to team up with friends or strangers to take on challenges and missions together.

Overall, Watch_Dogs 2 is a fantastic game that delivers on all fronts. It's thrilling, engaging, and endlessly entertaining, with a great story, memorable characters, and plenty of exciting gameplay to keep you coming back for more. If you're a fan of open-world games, you owe it to yourself to give this one a try.

Watch Dogs 2 is an open-world action-adventure game that features the character of Marcus Holloway, a hacker fighting against corporate corruption in the Bay Area of California. The game is an improvement over its predecessor in many ways and offers a diverse set of objectives and a more lighthearted tone. Players can use remote-control drones to hack objects and find hidden paths and have multiple options on every hackable item. The game offers a balanced open-world approach, with plenty to explore but not overwhelming, and the player has access to the whole map from the beginning. The game offers a variety of weapons, including guns and explosives, but killing civilians may have a negative impact on the player's progress. The game contains some sexual content, drug use, and strong language. Overall, Watch Dogs 2 is a fun and engaging game that offers a unique mix of stealth, action, and puzzle gameplay.

[i]Endless reinforcements, police helicopters in a city with very limited hiding spots, police cars magically being faster than a sports car that can boost, confusing map icons that have no explanation and seemingly lead you nowhere, inability to equip silencers to your weapons, and a large list of implementations that serve no purpose other than to ruin any semblance of fun.[/i]

The game has potential, but for me it's just insulting. 
Any time the story tries to pull me into the fantasy, the gameplay pulls me out. There's too many mechanics that work against you, but you're meant to be this master hacker in a master hacker super secret group but the game constantly throws seemingly simple tasks at you that the lack, or intentional addition of mechanics make frustratingly convoluted. Getting a money cache in an area with 3 guards can be a 15 minute chore. Unbelievable.

Oh, and enjoy spending 20 minutes hacking for skill points but at the end find out you're missing the drone, or gunning down endlessly respawning guards to loot a clothing piece, but realize you can't access it because you need a forklift, that requires a hacking skill you need to unlock. This game doesn't tell you anything, and shows you missions/side content that you can't complete, I even had to google what certain operation intel was cause the map icons pointed me to the area, but nothing was there.. Did I find out in the end? No! There's no freaking info about anything online either.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

I couldn't finish it... What a boring story with even more boring characters with no personalities but typical Instagram/TikTok influencer's traits that suppose to humanize them. A bunch of young adults taking over the world by terrorizing pedestrians and killing dozens of security workers who are barely above minimum wage. Every mission is practically the same few actions over and over again with a bland driving from time to time. Cars have no significant weight and take turns like go karts with no loss of traction or balance - good thing that the game encourages you to use fast travel instead. Without it - going from A to B would be a total nightmare. Then there are clunky on-foot controls - I kept getting stuck behind tiny obstacles as I expect my hero to instantly turn, but naaah - he would take a nice rounded turn that messes up with what my brain expects. Very non-responsive! In the end there is nothing good about the game... just the same Ubisoft formula placed for a 100th time on top of yet another boring open-world with a story that could kill you on how tasteless it is.

When the Watch_Dogs gameplay peeked. A pretty creative Ubisoft formula type game with effective mechanics, an interesting setting and serviceable characters.

Watch Dogs 2 is a game that takes hacking and vigilante justice to the next level. With a cast of lovable misfits and a satirical take on the tech industry, the game doesn't take itself too seriously and invites players to let their inner hackers run wild.

Playing as the young hacker Marcus Holloway, you'll explore the vibrant and colorful city of San Francisco, using your hacking skills to take down corrupt corporations and expose shady government agencies. The game's open-world design allows for endless possibilities, whether you're hacking into a rival gang's security system or simply enjoying the scenery on your customizable skateboard.

But what really sets Watch Dogs 2 apart is its sense of humor. The game is filled with wacky gadgets, pop culture references, and hilarious one-liners that will have you laughing out loud. From a drone that shoots fireworks to a car that can drive itself, the game's gadgets are both useful and ridiculous in equal measure.

Overall, Watch Dogs 2 is a fun and creative take on the open-world genre, with its irreverent humor and inventive gameplay making for an enjoyable and entertaining experience. Whether you're a fan of hacking, vigilante justice, or just good old-fashioned silliness, this game has something for everyone.

[h1][Review #11]
Watch Dogs 2[/h1]
Open World and NPCs: The open world is vibrant and colourful and NPCs have their own lifes. They have picnic at parks, vent out their anger by smashing cars along the road and have conversations and get angry at each other. You can send gangs to police and vice versa and will result in a firefight. I really enjoyed seeing the gunfights but then it gets repetitive quite quickly.

Things to do: You can do side and main story missions, taxi services with requirements, sailboat and motorcross race and go around the world taking pictures of attractive landmarks. I have no complaints about the activities except for the sailboat races. I fucking hate them because they are fustrating to play and get first place for.

Progression: You progress by gaining followers, which is earned by doing all of the activities above. As you level up, you gain research points which can be invested into your hacking skills to make it more powerful and versatile. Eventually you will have to find the rest of the research points by picking them up or hacking them in places scattered throughout the world, which I don't really like. Overall, the progression system in WD2 is quite good.

Combat: There are guns in the game but it is very limited and there are lethal and non-lethal options to play the game. You also have explosives and non-lethal versions of it. Gunplay in the game is mediocre at best. You can also melee NPCs when you are near them. Stealth is an option when playing the game as you create distractions and can possibly take them out without ever getting near them by hacking environmental objects.

Hacking: Your hacking skills ranges from ability to control forklifts and cranes to mass hacking individuals to distract a whole of them, cars to force them to move away from you and infrastructures to disable them. You can send cars flying off bridges or force police cars chasing you to smash into buildings or activate steam pipes to explode.

DLCs: Buying the season pass nets you 3 major DLCs. The first one gives a modified school bus that can wreak havoc in the world, and the second and third DLCs gives you new story missions to do. Each DLC also offers other side content.

Multiplayer: 3 basic modes. The basic co-op mode, the bounty hunter mode, where you enter someone's world who is currently on a level 3 wanted level or higher and try to neutralise them, and a hacking invasion mode, where you hack a player and try to not get detected while the hacking gets done. Buying the DLCs gets you a new difficulty for coop and a new enemy type.

Overall, I really enjoyed this game (except for the sailboat races). Definitely buy it on sale. Also, the fucking police is a pain in the fucking arse which keeps appearing when I don’t need them to.

*I have 66 hours spend on the uplay version of the game in my uPlay account, but it is not reflected here.

I went into the game just for the funny characters, other than that my expectations for the game weren't incredibly high with it being yet another Ubisoft open world game and all. It definitely delivered with the fun banter, but I can also see that the type of humor in the game may not be to everyones tastes. I went in looking for a stupid lighthearted experience so I knew what I was getting into, and it was a lot of fun.

The story was alright at best, the characters' personalities do a lot of the heavy lifting to make it somewhat interesting. It had a couple emotional moments but they don't overstay their welcome, or really stay at all- what I'm trying to say is that the tone of the game has a bit of an identity crisis during some of the later missions.

Stealth mechanics and enemy AI felt very inconsistent, sometimes the enemy knows your exact pinpoint location from two miles away with no line of sight needed, and other times it won't notice you whacking someone to death 10ft in front of them. The hacking skills were fun to play around with and gave nice variety of options for approaching a mission. 

[i]PS. Ubisoft Connect forcing itself open every time I launch the game makes me feel like someone is about to launch a car right through my window Devil May Cry -style. I swear there wasn't a single time that the launcher or game opened without some weird hiccup.[/i]

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead, murdered by my brother-in-law Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, Hank came to me with a rather, shocking proposition. He asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using his connections in the drug world. Connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded, I... I always thought that Hank was a very moral man and I was... thrown, confused, but I was also particularly vulnerable at the time, something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me on a ride along, and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin so I agreed. Every day, I think back at that moment with regret. I quickly realized that I was in way over my head, and Hank had a partner, a man named Gustavo Fring, a businessman. Hank essentially sold me into servitude to this man, and when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn. Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling out. From what I can gather, Hank was always pushing for a greater share of the business, to which Fring flatly refused to give him, and things escalated. Fring was able to arrange, uh I guess I guess you call it a "hit" on my brother-in-law, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured, and I wound up paying his medical bills which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge, working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring, and did so. In fact, the bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen in the ranks to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA, and about that time, to keep me in line, he took my children from me. For 3 months he kept them. My wife, who up until that point, had no idea of my criminal activities, was horrified to learn what I had done, why Hank had taken our children. We were scared. I was in Hell, I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, to end this nightmare, and in response, he gave me this. I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. I... All I could think to do was to make this video in hope that the world will finally see this man, for what he really is.

Watch Dogs 2 is a sequel to its 2014 predecessor, and it takes place in San Francisco, California. You play as Marcus Holloway, a hacker and a member of the hacktivist group DedSec who aims to take down the new CTOS 2.0. It is way more polished and bigger that Watch_Dogs, the story is also great, especially when playing in coop. It's well worth the price.

If the game was say £20 I'd give it a thumbs up but I can't at the regular price. It's like playing an arcade version of the first game. I won't spoil it by saying what, but once you realise how, you don't need to fight. Just stand back for 10 minutes and the game will do it for you. There was at times a tense atmosphere in the first game but this one just seems like a stroll around a very pretty world. The puzzles are very easy to the point where I go 'oh no not another one of these annoying time-wasters'.  Then there's the annoying online element which you can turn off for a while but if you forget, it kicks in again. So, I'm trying to make it more interesting by using stealth, then all of a sudden I get a message to say another player has joined my game, They run right in and start blowing everything up and there goes my stealth. Don't get me wrong, it is a very nice game, it's just not as exciting as the first. It's certainly not worth £50 though. Glad I got on sale otherwise I'd be very disappointed.

Watch Dogs 2 is a mixed bag, offering both good and bad elements. On the positive side, the game has a fantastic open world filled with interesting activities, such as hacking into various systems, solving puzzles, and participating in adrenaline-fueled car chases. The graphics are also impressive, and the game's soundtrack is fantastic.

On the downside, some of the missions can feel repetitive and the character control can feel clunky at times. Additionally, the AI can be quite inconsistent, with enemies sometimes acting overly aggressive or too passive. The story can also be a bit underwhelming, with some of the characters and subplots not fully fleshed out.

Overall, Watch Dogs 2 is a solid open-world game that is definitely worth playing for fans of the genre. While it has its flaws, the fun hacking mechanics and the beautiful open world make it a good choice for those looking for a fun and engaging game experience.

[h1] They should have hacked Ubisoft to make a consistent story[/h1]
The game takes place in a fictionalised version of San Francisco, California and follows the story of Marcus Holloway, a hacker who joins the hacking group DedSec to take down a corrupt corporation and its city-wide surveillance system known as ctOS 2.0.

[h3] Pros and cons [/h3]
[table]
[tr]
[th] 🟩 Positives [/th]
[th] 🟥 Negatives [/th]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td]
- Solid open-world gameplay with a detailed and well-designed environment

- Improved hacking system that allows players to interact with the environment in new and creative ways

- Engaging story (maybe not well written) that deals with themes of surveillance, privacy, and the power of technology, social justice, racism, and civil rights

- Variety of activities and side missions, offering players a lot of content to explore

- The game's soundtrack is well-curated and fits the game's atmosphere and theme

- A good sense of humour, with various Easter eggs and references

- The game's improved driving mechanics and improved parkour system, making the gameplay more fluid
	[/td]
	[td]
- The game's stealth mechanics for being inconsistent, making it difficult to complete missions without being detected

- The game's story for being inconsistent, pointing out that the game's themes and messages are not always well-integrated into the story, the game's narrative is often disjointed and that the game's characters and motivations are not always clear

- The DLC is bad. It doesn't add much to the overall game

- [b]Steam achievements are no longer available for this game[/b]

- The structure of the main missions is too repetitive

- Some glitches and technical issues

- The game's AI is inconsistent and has aimbot

- The multiplayer is just a joke, as it doesn't add anything new
	[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]	

[h3] Gameplay [/h3]
The gameplay in Watch Dogs 2 is decent for a Ubisoft game. The game's improved hacking system is one of its strongest features, allowing players to interact with the environment in new and creative ways, from controlling traffic lights to hacking cameras and drones. The stealth mechanics were inconsistent, making it difficult to complete missions without being detected.

[h3] Story [/h3]
The game's story is engaging but not well-written, dealing with themes of surveillance, privacy, the power of technology, social justice, racism, and civil rights. Through Marcus's story, the game explores the impact of surveillance on individuals and marginalised communities and how the abuse of technology can be used to control and manipulate the population. 

However, the game's story is inconsistent, the game's themes and messages are not always well-integrated into the story, the game's narrative is often disjointed, and the game's characters and motivations are not always clear. The game's story does not always align with the gameplay mechanics, and the game's missions and side activities can feel disconnected from the main story.

[h3] Art Style [/h3]
The game's visuals on PC are generally considered to be very good (similar to the infamous E3 trailer for Watch_Dogs 1), with the game's open-world environment looking particularly impressive. The open-world environment is detailed and well-designed, allowing players to freely explore the city of San Francisco

[h3] DLC [/h3]
The DLC for Watch Dogs 2, which includes additional missions, weapons, and vehicles, has received mixed reviews. The DLC isn't worth the price, even though it adds new content to the game and expands upon the game's story. 

[h3] Steam Achievements [/h3]
Steam achievements are no longer available for this game due to Ubisoft's decision to remove the game's integration with the Steamworks API, which is a greedy way to force users to buy games on their platform to "unlock" more features. Features that should not be exclusive.

[h3] Conclusion [/h3]
Overall, Watch Dogs 2 is a good game with many negatives. Players that enjoy open-world action-adventure games with a strong emphasis on hacking and social justice themes might enjoy it, but players that are looking for a more consistent storyline may be disappointed.

Watch Dogs 2 is a fantastic sequel to the original Watch Dogs game, and it surpasses its predecessor in almost every way. The game takes place in the city of San Francisco, and players take on the role of Marcus Holloway, a young hacker who joins the hacking group DedSec to take down the corrupt corporate and government forces that control the city.

One of the biggest improvements in Watch Dogs 2 is the open-world environment. The city of San Francisco is beautifully rendered and feels alive, with a bustling population of NPCs going about their daily routines. The city is also much larger than the one in the first game, with a variety of neighborhoods to explore, each with their own distinct personalities. The game also features a variety of vehicles, from cars and motorcycles to boats and drones, that players can use to explore the city.

Another major improvement in Watch Dogs 2 is the gameplay. The game is more open-ended, allowing players to choose how they want to approach missions and objectives. Players can use stealth to infiltrate buildings and take down enemies, or they can use a more aggressive approach, using weapons and gadgets to take down enemies head-on. The game also features a variety of side missions and activities, such as races and mini-games, that add to the overall experience.

The hacking mechanics in Watch Dogs 2 are also a significant step up from the first game. Players can hack into various devices and systems in the city, such as cameras and traffic lights, to gain an advantage in combat or to complete objectives. The game also introduces a new feature called "profiler," which allows players to hack into the personal lives of NPCs to gather information and complete missions.

The story of Watch Dogs 2 is also much better than the first game. The game follows Marcus and DedSec as they take on the corrupt corporate and government forces that control the city. The game features a variety of missions and objectives that are both exciting and engaging, and the characters are likable and relatable.

In conclusion, Watch Dogs 2 is an excellent sequel that surpasses the original game in every way. The open-world environment, gameplay, hacking mechanics, and story are all top-notch, and the game is a joy to play. If you're a fan of the first game or open-world action games in general, then Watch Dogs 2 is a game that you don't want to miss.

"Watch Dogs 2" is a decent open-world action-adventure game. The gameplay is fairly standard for the genre, with players completing missions, hacking various objects and taking down enemies. The graphics are good, but not particularly impressive compared to other games in the same genre. The story is okay, but not particularly memorable. The open world is large, but can feel a bit empty at times. Overall, "Watch Dogs 2" is a solid, if unspectacular, entry in the open-world action-adventure genre. It's worth checking out if you're a fan of the genre, but it's not a must-play.

This has got to be one of the most forgettable games in my life. It isn't necessarily bad in the way that you might think, it's not brutally hard for no reason, it doesn't have the worst of developers out there, nor is does it have some kind of rage inducing story line. But what it does have is a lack luster story, annoying characters, and sometimes frustrating controls.

I'll start off with the story line and what I personally disliked about it. Firstly, there isn't exactly the deepest of stories that you need to follow, it more or less just boils down to "There be Evil Corporation, we must destroy said Corporation." This is indeed a format that can work greatly, but we the players are never truly given a reason to really fear or resent that corporation on a personal level. The only time you ever see the dastardly doings of the overlords is just looking at CCTV footage of a handful crooked cops or by being framed of various crimes, and that's really it. There is no kidnapping or torture of other characters, there is nothing really besides false accusations thrown against you, and your only ever told about their evil actions. 
However, if we look at the first Watch_Dogs game, there is a story to follow with the devilish CEO's as a backdrop for the setting, but I will admit that the story in the first game isn't the greatest. Since the corporation is the back drop, the main antagonists is the mafia, and what I liked about these bad guys is that you are given a reason for not liking them beyond just the idea that they're bad.  Another thing that set the original and the sequel is the fact that you would be punished for being a bad person yourself, with a bad ending as punishment for being an asshole. While in the sequel, I went on several murder streaks, killing dozens of civilians and law enforcement alike, but in the end I was still a "crime fighting hacker that only has the interests of the people in mind", even though I most likely caused more deaths than the CEO's you're supposed to be fighting against. The last grievance I'll touch on is the over all tone of Watch_Dogs 2, which felt way more bubbly and bright than it should've been, showing that the whole Bay Area was supposed to be under the iron fists of corporate fat cats. While the tone of the first game was a bit more darker and muted, it felt like it fit with the setting and story, with that setting being a decrepit Chicago that's being ruled over by a faceless system and organised crime syndicates, and the story being a broken man seeking revenge for the death of a loved one while simultaneously keeping his still living loved ones safe from the wake of his own actions. 

Secondly, there is the obnoxious characters. The main gripe that I had with these characters is mostly the fact that they don't mesh with the story that well. With the fact that they are literally just a bunch of kids going up against one of the most powerful forces in the entire world, and only coming out on top because they are the main characters. For example, these characters take over and destroy a massive corporation that is on the verge of taking over the world, where other people have been killed trying to only put a dent in the gigantic monopoly that this corporation has built, and five random people topple its entire regime in only a couple of weeks; with the only sort of loss that this group sustained being one of their friends being humiliated with a slap on the wrist before you come in and undo all that just happened to that character. Another thing that I didn't really like was the lack of screen time with other characters. With the best example I've found being that of Horatio. He is one of the founding members of DedSec (the hacker group you're a part of) and you have barely any interaction with him before he is killed off. Where you spend one mission with him and get a small amount of information about his character, and to only have him be killed a handful of missions later. The part that made this fact sting the most (for me at least) was the fact that he is my favorite character out of the entire cast you meet, and the sole reason he is my favorite is only because he is the most normal out of the cast. While there are three other characters who are just a bunch of weirdos with horrible fashion sense, who were either bullied too much or too little while growing up.

All in all, it definitely isn't the worst game I've played by far, it has some good music, an incredibly detailed and stunning map, and a large degree of customization. But with the lack of a solid connection between the story of the original and sequel, a boring story of its own, obnoxious characters, and odd controls has made the experience not the greatest for me. In my opinion until I play the third game, just stick with the original.

Not a terrible game and it is different from what Ubi normally gives us when it comes to open worlds. The city is fun to explore and like with most Ubi games, the world feels alive with AI pedestrians going about their ways. There are many areas to explore and items to collect. Aside from the slight pandering, what makes the game feel off though are just minor annoyances that stack up.

The story is not half bad, but I would definitely prefer the first game over this one. The first game felt like it had more purpose, where this one not so much.

The controls are decent but you can tell Ubi still hasn't gottent eh refinement down as it still feels clunky, most noticeable when turning the character. The game is "always" online and if you wish to not have people jump you in game, you can turn it off in the settings menu, or you can forego installing the anti cheat in the game and it will automatically turn online mode off.

Music is eh.. Doesn't have the strongest soundtrack compared to games that are similar. Driving is so so. Its decent and handleing feels stiff but in a good way. What sucks though is there is really no consequences for crashing, even on a bike. Speed in the game is arbitrary and the screen shakes to signify you are going fast. The police will always catch up to you and are brutally relentless.

I got stuck in walls and railings at times and had to reload a save or fast travel to a safe house when I could. The sky always has a slight flicker to it. It flickers black when the screen is at a certain angle and almost always when in cutscenes. While not tooooo bad, it is noticeable. I only had 1 crash.

Decent game overall, but repetitive and I got bored of the missions a little over half way through. If there was a neutral rating on steam, I'd give it that. The game does go on sale at a rather deep discount at times. The first game vs the 2nd game though, I'd suggest going with the first as they are basically the same thing....It's Ubisoft we are talking about here.

Watch Dogs 2 is an excellent open-world action-adventure game that's a lot of fun to play. The game has a vast and open world to explore, with a variety of activities and missions to complete. The controls are tight and responsive, and the game has a good difficulty curve that keeps things challenging but not frustrating.
One of the standout features of Watch Dogs 2 is its hacking mechanics. The game lets you hack into various systems and devices to complete missions and gather information. It's a fun and innovative gameplay mechanic that adds a lot of depth to the game.
The graphics in Watch Dogs 2 are excellent, with detailed character models and environments. The game's music and sound effects are also top-notch, adding to the atmosphere.
One downside to Watch Dogs 2 is that the game can be a bit repetitive. You'll be doing a lot of the same actions over and over again, and the missions can start to feel a bit samey after a while. That being said, the game has a high replay value, and you'll probably find yourself coming back to it again and again.
Overall, Watch Dogs 2 is an excellent open-world action-adventure game that's a lot of fun to play. Its hacking mechanics and vast open world make it a game that's worth checking out. The occasional repetitive gameplay can be a bit of an issue, but it doesn't really impact the overall enjoyment of the game. If you're a fan of open-world action-adventure games, you should definitely give Watch Dogs 2 a try.

A much improved version over the first that is more hip and trendy and really seems to work. Its a shame that the map is so small. Graphics are really well done. I find the controls are overly sensitive but get used to them over time.

Having lived in the Bay Area for a time it's really nice to be able to run around San Francisco, and part of Oakland and see all the sights. It's not a perfect recreation of course but it's definately got the vibe and it's fairly faithful to what the Bay Area actually looks like.

Marcus is a way better character than Aiden ever was, and having some black representation with an interesting character in a Big Name title is actually super legit. I pretty much like most of the crew in the SF DeadSec team, I thought I would hate Wrench at first but he grew on me pretty fast, they're all just kinda lovable dorks. The only one that seems kinda like a dead fish is Horatio, he doesn't seem to serve much purpose and is just kinda boring. 

The game is pretty much your standard open world fair, run around SF pick up collectibles, do meaningless side missions, engage with the main story when you feel like it. I tend to like these kinds of games cause they can be pretty zen when the collectibles aren't too tedious to find. That said it doesn't really hold a candle to something like the Witcher 3 which is pretty much what I consider to be the gold standard for Open World games.

I've also started to not really like games that give the option of being Non-Lethal or Lethal without any moral ramifications for either choice. Narratively it doesn't really make sense for Marcus or Deadsec to be carrying around lethal weaponry, you're not really like hardened criminals and it doesn't really make much of a statement as people fighting for Societal Freedoms to kill anyone, it just makes you into another sort of police force. I'd much rather all the weapons either be non-lethal or just go the complete opposite direction and make it clear that Deadsec aren't good people and lean into the lethal weapons.

Game runs fine, it's pretty enough. Looks good for something that released 6 years ago. I do have gripes with Ubisoft wrapping their fingers so tightly around all their games, I hate the Ubisoft overlay, it's pointless bloat and a poor anti-piracy measure, I turned it off but I know it's still running in the background. The lack of a dedicated pause button without going into the map or the settings is kind of annoying too. But neither of these things hold the game itself back they're just minor gripes I have about the systems.

I remember playing the original Watch Dogs game years ago but didn't finish it so I bought both of them on discount so that I can get through the first one and then progress right to the other hoping it would be the continuation of the story or something in that manner. 

Holy s*it was I disappointed.

No major spoilers but the original game had a story that actually got you involved with you accidentally revealing disgusting sinister activities of elites, had characters that were well made, likeable and it was funny from time to time when it mattered. The sequel? It's just a mess, it has boring stereotypical characters who act childish as hell, while in the meantime killing people and then going "yasss look at us we're so cool and hip and we're totally the good guys". The sequel has no character, it tries to sell you bringing down an oppressive system while you yourself or anyone around you is seemingly not actually being oppressed, but having a great time, much contrary to original game which had a much simpler goal which then kept spiralling out of control as the character dug in deeper and deeper.

I'm just disappointed with this game, the original is so much better than this.

Thank you to Ubisoft for this beautiful game! I enjoyed it while I played it. Yes, the game is not perfect in some plans, but the story is amazing! I rejoiced and grieved along with the characters and was happy to finally complete the company to the very end. It was the best hours of my life. The game is by itself lackluster. It's a mix of amazing design and asthetics, an open world devoid of life, a "parkour" mechanic that while fun to use faces the same pathing problem as other UBISOFT properties, a story that goes from interesting to absolute cringe in the span of 5 minutes (looking at some of the "join us" cutscene segments), uninteresting antagonists with good voice actors in deadpan characters, and a hacking system that while an improvment from WD1, becomes easily obsulete half way the game.

And here's my biggest grievences. 

1. Because the "hacking" fails to trigger the intended actions, you'll easily resort to a more agressive play, to wich the game designers force you to revert into the former;

2. The enemy a.i. are a pure comedy of awfull design as certain "traits" were implemented for you not to notice, making them go from extremely idiotic, to "I can see behind walls and trigger everyone in the map to your position!";

3. The collecting is easy puzzles made difficult. It's an easy hack or grab an item, almost always on rooftops, but the ways to access them is literally stopping every and any pacing or momentum in your playthrough to widly and very boringly search for the same exact solution for every single "puzzle". It's a sub-par design, made by someone that fails to comprehend the line between doing something fun and working and whomever was the cursed soul that decided this needs to be excluded from future projects.

4. Hacking sequences were always fairly easy, to wich they implemented useless timed triggers for a sense of urgency.

5. The game is litered with useless minigames, that with the limited control scheme, become a slog of doing the same over and over.

6. Forget the Online. Almost no one grasps the intended objectives and wants to troll, or you'll face easy invasions against people that lack the comprehension of what hiding or searching means. 

So in sum. The game is easy, the collecting is made extremelly and awfully tedious, the enemy a.i. is definitly broken with ungodly superpowers at points and you'll leave the main component (hacking) in the sidelines a LOT of time.

It's a huge improvment from the first one, but don't hold a candle for the sequel, as in Legion managed to be worse then both WD1 and WD2.

UBISOFT has the right idea in this entry, and it shows much promise and talent from everyone that worked in it, BUT if you're going to play this one, buy it a discount. It gets fairly repetitive around the 7 hours mark.

Id recommend to ask someone else for DLC opinion but from what ive seen, you aren't losing anything interesting as WD1 dlc.

Watch_Dogs 2 has its fair share of problems, but that being said its a solid improvement over the original game.

The original was a decent, if dull and kinda forgettable experience. It had some good ideas, but all in all it was ripe for expansion in a sequel. Watch Dogs 2 does make minor improvements all over the game, but its still not the knock-out it could've been.

That being said, Watch Dogs 2 is still an enjoyable experience and the devs at least gave it a good shot.

Visually, the game still looks pretty good for the most part and the new San Francisco location combined with the brighter art style allows for a more vibrant look. In general its just a good looking game. It is a shame though that its not optimised all that well. Despite having a pretty damn amazing system, regardless of settings the frames would vary hugely depending mostly on environment, which is a shame.

The story and writing is more engaging this time around, however its still overly safe and inconsistent. There are plenty of moments which will leave you scratching your head and the dialogue in particular can be pretty cringe worthy on occasion. But, the new main character Marcus is pretty likeable and the DedSec group dynamic setup here is really believable. Its miles away from award winning, but its far from bad.

The gameplay here is definitely better than the previous title, however there were some changes made which may cause issues for some people. For one, there's no manual save, which combined with the harsh checkpoints can lead to some very frustrating deaths. The driving is improved across the board and doesn't feel as floaty anymore. The game has a much bigger focus on the hacking/stealth aspects this time around. In fact, I'd argue combat is straight up discouraged this time around. Marcus dies insanely fast, even on the normal difficulty setting and the armoured enemies in particular can be super spongey, leading to loud combat that's far less enjoyable. This does fit with the games tone seeing as Marcus is very much displayed as a pacifist, but considering this is the case, I wonder why guns were even kept in if they were gonna get nerfed into the ground? Who knows.

My only proper issue with Watch Dogs 2 is the state of polish. Despite how long this game has been out for, I experienced a pretty common amount of jank. The game crashed 4 times on me in the 16 hours it took me to finish it. On top of this, I got mission soft locked more than once, the physics broke a few times and audio got desynced in one of my cutscene's. None of this is insanely game breaking, however it is pretty annoying. Obviously your mileage may vary, but from my experience it wasn't exactly smooth sailing.

Overall, if you just want to play a light, enjoyable open world shooter, I'd recommend it. It's not high art, but its a firm improvement over the original, and that's good enough for me.

The story of hacking into the new blume 2.0 network  is an interesting plot, but in order to actually do the fun part of the game you need to "Acquire Followers", Millions of them. You play missions and get a couple thousand, maybe up to 100k in big missions. It's just a tedious grind to get to the interesting part. Not to mention how weak the characters are. You basically play as a Terrorist running around the city killing people over the smallest little things. For example, there is a mission where you break into a movie studio to steal a car that is being used in a "Hacker Thriller". During this mission you can, and probably will murder ~15 guards in the duration of the mission. How am I suppose to feel good about stealing some prop car that holds up production of a bad movie that isn't hurting anyone, when I just killed 15 people. The characters are shallow and have no moralities.

In the first watch_dogs you played as Aiden Pearce, a man who's niece was killed during an assassination attempt on his life. Because of this he becomes the hacker vigilante. This game has a strong moral compass and your actions have consequences, however minor. When you kill a cop, your reputation goes down into criminal menace. And when you do good things, like prevent murders or steal something back for someone. You get positive points, making you a publicly adored vigilante.

This lack of morality is what absolutely kills my immersion and interest in the second installment of watch_dogs.

An aboslutley horrible PC port. Below is my exerience with the game in only 40 minutes of playtime. The majority of it was spent either alt-tabbed or shift-tabbed looking for threads on how to fix these issues. Eventually I'd decide to skip it because the game was running, and see if it got better after the intro. It got far, far worse. Everytime I decided to skip fixing a problem I would experience a much worse problem literally no more than 5 minutes later.

Stutters constantly, audio desyncs because of this during gameplay and cutscenes. The framerate doesn't reach 60 at any point no matter which graphics settings I use, in fact the lower I set the settings, the worse my framerate becomes, usually sits at about a solid 20 with constant dips into the single digits. Attempting to find a fix online yeilded no help because there are so many people with this issue and all of them have different solutions. Every single thread about the stuttering and framerates had at least 7 seperate possible fixes with the majority of users replying that none worked, I'd have tried more but I wanted to make sure I didn't go over the 2 hour refund limit which I just requested after only 40 minutes. The cutscenes seemingly play overtop of each other with audio from one drowning out the audio from another, and then after one finishes, the other cutscene begins to play again.

❝ It's a switch on your fears, fear of the other. They try to isolate you. It's called divide and conquers, and they tricked you into thinking it's what you asked for. You said with one voice: We will not be lied to. We will not be afraid. We will not be silent. ❞
-Marcus Holloway

[h1] 💻 Description: [/h1]
Ubisoft has had a bad reputation over the years in terms of its game building strategy. There are times when they create amazing games and there are other times when they basically “milk” an already used concept. Having played Watch Dogs 1 in the past, my expectations were quite low since the promises made in 2012 E3 were not fulfilled. I have never said Watch Dogs 1 is a bad game (don’t get me wrong) but the franchise had so much potential that thankfully, I was able to see it with my own eyes in its current sequel.

[h1] 📖 Setting: [/h1]
[h3] Summary [/h3]
Having failed to manage Chicago’s city-wide infrastructure, due to the influence of our beloved Aiden Pierce, the CTOS (Central Operating System) which connects everyone and everything has been installed in San Francisco. This time under new management called [b] Blume. [/b] Even though the system has been upgraded to its newest version CTOS 2.0, it covertly brings harm to many innocent citizens of the city, including our protagonist. Marcus Holloway an intelligent hacker from Oakland, having been accused of a crime he did not commit, decides to work with the hacking group called [b] DedSec. [/b] Filled with ambition and pride his new purpose is to take down Blume’s influence over the city. 

[h3] Characters [/h3]
Watch Dogs 2 lets us embark on a thrilling adventure. The plot revolves around a group of outlaws whose actions and thoughts can be very relatable to our own. A big comparison to the “vigilantly arc” experienced in the previous game. The cast has a funny (sometimes goofy) personality, with clear motivations and an intriguing character progression. The conversations can indeed get a little bit “nerdy” and “cringe-worthy”, but it's those features that make the interactions unique and thus more memorable. The dialogue ranges from happy moments to very dark ones (depending on the circumstances) giving us plenty of material to reflect upon. The only downside in my opinion is the main “villain” of the story. 

[b] Lesser Evil? [/b]
As you will see for yourself during your playthroughs, there will be times when you going to question both sides of the coin. Many arguments reflected upon the “villains” have a very valid point. Of course, they engage in illegal activities (the same goes for DedSec) which is considered an evil approach. However, their cause (for me at least) is far more justifiable than the one which DedSec stands for. A feeling that seems out of place, since the game in my opinion has no intention to offer. Overall, the writing is enjoyable but not perfect. There are flaws and plot holes, which to be honest was expected because the game relies almost completely on its gameplay aspect.

[h1] 🕹️ Gameplay: [/h1]
Watch Dogs 2 gameplay-wise truly outdid itself for many reasons:

[h3] Hacking [/h3]
[b] Toolkit [/b]
The hacking feature of the game, the soul and core of the franchise, is challenged to its fullest potential. You can hack cars, lights, robots, phones etc. in many different ways, something that the Watch Dogs 1 experience lacked. Furthermore, the many newly added features such as drones, provide an amazing toolkit for stealth lovers. Most of the missions can be completed without even having to engage in any combat!
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2896420429
[b] Limitations [/b]
The clever touch that Ubisoft added was the battery system. You have limited use of the hacking ability, a smart way which keeps in check the ending [b] god mode [/b] feeling. This way, you are forced to follow a more strategic approach during your missions, by focusing more on your upgrades, ability tree as well as stealth and hacking. The bar can be replenished though, so no worries.

[h3] Movement [/h3]
[b] Parkour [/b]
The parkour aspect and the fighting style, in general, feel dynamic and fresh, with newly added animations that left me speechless. Marcus does flips, tricks and many more moves that bring a smooth feeling when free-roaming.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2896419740
[b] Combat [/b]
During combat, you can notice many details that both the protagonist and the NPCs share. For example, when different gangs were fighting each other, 3 SWAT trucks came in immediately to protect the citizens. The wanted system in my humble opinion is very well made. The above-mentioned incident proves this statement.

[h3] Exploration [/h3]
[b] World [/b]
San Francisco is beautiful and vast with a colourful, warm aesthetic that pleases the eye even in the most extreme situations like police chases. Driving is smooth and fun, which can prove handy on many occasions with special tweaks that I won’t spoil. There is a variety of vehicles from the faster to the more humble ones, all easily obtainable on every corner of the map.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2896419293
[b] Interaction [/b]
The way the world is expressed in this game, compared to its predecessor is one of the biggest ways Watch Dogs 2 improved from the original. The NPCs finally feel alive and have a purpose. You even can pet [b] dogs [/b] for god’s sake! The freedom of choice is not negligible, as customization offers a variety of options that can please even the most demanding players. 

[h3] Difficulty [/h3]
The game introduced the newly added [b] Realistic mode. [/b] In other words, enemies become [b] smarter [/b] and more [b] accurate [/b] with aim. Their health is slightly raised but they take the same amount of damage as before. It raises the stakes, which will ultimately prove useful if you ever play online against other players!

[h1] 👁‍🗨 Visuals: [/h1]
Watch Dogs 2 has amazing graphics. For a game that's almost 5 years old, they hold up pretty well. Details such as the fog that occurs during a rainy day, create an atmospheric feeling that I enjoy watching. The only downside here is the character models. In my opinion, they could dedicate more time polishing the product, as cutscenes sometimes prove to be disturbing.

[h1] 🎧 Audio: [/h1]
The music provides a neat touch to the game. I still remember the time when the [b] Fortunate Son [/b] soundtrack was playing in the background, as I was heading guns blazing into the fight. Of course, there are some [b] skippable [/b] songs here and there, but the missions become more [b] fun [/b] and more [b] memorable [/b] with such additions as the one mentioned above.

[h1] 🗃️ Side Notes: [/h1]
Co-op remains among its least approachable and yet most buggy features, but let it not discourage you from giving it a try. There are the familiar invasions, bounty hunter modes as well as many online activities, where you can bring havoc either with friends or random people you meet online. Lately, the Epic Store has offered the game for [b] free [/b] to many players. As a result, online became relevant and thus more enjoyable!

The DLCs are good yet short. I advise you to wait for the [b] Steam sales [/b] before buying the whole package since the prize can be considered a little spicy.

[h1] 📋 Verdict: [/h1]
Watchdogs 2 deserves the title of [b] the [/b] perfect [b] sequel [/b] as it improves whatever came before it. The writing can be considered a delicate topic; however, the gameplay redeems the whole concept.

Easily one of my favorite sandbox, 3rd person RPG games. The gameplay is smooth, the gadgets and hacking mechanics are well thought-out and interesting enough to keep you entertained. The game emphasizes stealth and rewards planning when tackling missions but also leaves it open to go in guns blazing.

I love the fact that you can upgrade specific areas of hacking to improve vehicle hacking, gadgetry, social engineering and even City-level hacking which feels really cool and powerful.

The graphics are great, I loved walking through the radiant, vibrant streets of San Francisco, the Oakland suburbs where each area of the map has interesting features. Weapon handling and vehicle driving physicals are tight and predictable which make the game so much fun to play.
The story entities Blume, Gallelei, Nudle are social commentaries on Facebook, Google and even SpaceX which I though was brave and pretty eye-opening as the subjects/topics about data privacy, moral dilemmas  and ethics with an information-driven economy and socially very relevant to today. Pretty Impressive for a game made back in 2016.


The characters are satirical typical nerds, isolates, outcasts and flamboyant, egotistical techies which exist in the tech industry, so I don't take offense.lol.

WD2 is a solid game overall. Better than its predecessor and its sequel imo. The tone is best looked at through a parody lens, most of the humor is more cringey than it is funny but the characters do come across as realistic if you're familiar with average hipster-rebel Millenials. The plot makes enough sense if you're familiar with the fundamentals of cyber security, a lot of people seem to fail to realize exactly what a botnet is and how it can be used when reviewing this game. The gunplay is okay, the hacking is great, the stealth is alright. Game still looks good all these years later too.

GILGAMESH KING IN URUK

I WILL proclaim to the world the deeds of Gilgamesh. This was the man to whom all things were known; this
was the king who knew the countries of the world. He was wise, he saw mysteries and knew secret things, he
brought us a tale of the days before the flood. He went on a long journey, was weary, worn-out with labour,
returning he rested, he engraved on a stone the whole story.

When the gods created Gilgamesh they gave him a perfect body. Shamash the glorious sun endowed him with
beauty, Adad the god of the storm endowed him with courage, the great gods made his beauty perfect, surpassing all
others, terrifying like a great wild bull. Two thirds they made him god and one third man.

In Uruk he built walls, a great rampart, and the temple of blessed Eanna for the god of the firmament Anu, and
for Ishtar the goddess of love. Look at it still today: the outer wall where the cornice runs, it shines with the
brilliance of copper; and the inner wall, it has no equal. Touch the threshold, it is ancient. Approach Eanna the
dwelling of Ishtar, our lady of love and war, the like of which no latter-day king, no man alive can equal. Climb
upon the wall of Uruk; walk along it, I say; regard the foundation terrace and examine the. masonry: is it not burnt
brick and good? The seven sages laid the foundations.

Watch_dogs 1 was a gta-esque sandbox game with a compelling story and protagonist, spiced up with somewhat corny elements of modern-day hacking, which was used as an effective springboard for themes about corporate monopolies and spying (pretty ironic for a ubisoft-published game, but whatevs.) Watch_dogs 2, if anything, feels like something cranked out via corporate request. Yeah, I can tell a ton of money and dev time was put into this game (its a ubisoft game that isnt falling apart at the seams, which is incredible) but every single droplet of a good story is evaporated with the sequel. The best development the characters can be honored with is getting killed off, and the game can't set up a decent conflict without shoving a character in your face and screaming in your ear "THIS IS THE BAD GUY. THIS IS THE ANTAGONIST. DO NOT LIKE HIM. HE IS BAD." You can argue that Damien also filled this role in the first game, but he had some actual connection with our protagonist and came off more as a zealot that oversteps his boundaries, and wasn't instantly shoved in your face like Douche Badguy (they literally name this guy douche and thought that was a good decision huh.) The game is also Packed with token characters. I'm not about to go on a Gamer Rant about the evils of forced diversity, but it's absolutely insulting when a solid majority of the characters are insanely flat and are obviously there just to fill corporate check boxes. I think the most absurd example of these characters is the trans government official (i cant even remember her name or actual position, call it a testament to my shit memory or the shit writing) who we just, talk to? about videos of her surgeries getting leaked? and her possible information on a cult, I think. It ends with her giving us the info and going "idrc about the videos. lol." This is just, stupid. The entire conflict of her character is obviously written by what a cis person Thinks would be upsetting to a trans person and, like. Are we just gonna fucking gloss over that we have connections to The Government??? She is never brought up again, and I think a vigilante hacker group having an in with The Actual Government would be a big fucking deal? Obviously this can't happen because having a trans woman have any actual significance in the story would make the gamers angry, according to focus group session #49. The game also somehow has a huge disconnect with memes and internet culture that was not in the first game. I'll just sum it up with: this game is filled with trollfaces and 1337speak and other shit that wasn't even ironically funny in 2016, and the first game was pretty toned down, with the most obvious examples of memes being things like being able to hack billboards and None Pizza With Left Beef showing up. I'm rambling at this point, so I'll finish with.

Watch_dogs 2 is an incredibly meh game overall, but is outright terrible when compared to its predecessor, shitting all over the concept of any sort of coherent and compelling story. The gameplay is pretty good, but the only improvements that were made over the first game are a decent amount of feature streamlining, which is entirely negated by Ubisoft Brand Feature Bloat. 

tl;dr, play the first game

A definite improvement over the original
The cast of characters is much more fun, and Marcus is far more likable than Aiden. Even though Aiden is definitely more interesting, Marcus is a lot more fun to play as
The sense of style in the clothing is pretty good, and there's a wide variety on offer
Basic gameplay hasn't evolved much since Watch Dogs 1, but hacking controls are far more in-depth
There are about a dozen weapons, but personally I had the most fun only using the game's basic pistols: a silenced pistol and stun gun for stealth, and a regular pistol for combat. Watch Dogs 2 offers the player assault rifles and shotguns, which feels like it's pandering to an audience who might not appreciate the hacking mechanics; you play as a hipster with a magic smart phone, shooting up a military base with an AK just makes me feel like I'm playing the wrong game.

I don't like the youthful, colourful style of this part. I much preferred the gritty, dark athmosphere of WD1. Watch Dogs 2 is a good game, but nowhere near as good as the original.
The graphics are really amazing, the missions are fun to play and it's also fun exploring off-limits areas and messing with the guards. I'm missing the crime fighting side missions / aspects of part 1 though, being told where crimes occur and having the chance to intervene was part of what made WD1 such fun (I spent more time on WD1 than WD2).
Overall, I would recommend the game, but there are some major flaws. The protagonists are too youthful and wannabe-"cool", they're very annoying and not likeable at all.
The biggest flaw are the hidden research points though, which are hard to find even if you search areas with "6th sense" enabled (which is only possible on foot, making a full search of the entire map an unreasonable proposition).
I completed the game and all DLC missions and collected all the research points I could locate, but still I don't have the skill tree complete, which is a real shame.
If the game wouldn't stop awarding research points beyond level 20, I would at least have gotten a full skill tree by the time I finished the DLC (after story mode), which is far too late anyway given how much gameplay quality depends on having skills unlocked (by the time you receive certain skills, you can no longer do anything meaningful with them as you already plundered all restricted areas and completed all missions).
I'd say it deserves a 7/10, one point deducted for unlikeable characters, and two for the research point issue (near impossible to get them all, especially while still playing missions).

The storyline is lacking in depth as well, while the firsst one may not have been the most sophisticated, the second part offers a cool gang (which doesn't miss a single minute telling you about their hippness), which tries to go after corrupt and law-violating people and gangs.
For me this was a clear downgrade, however some new features are heading in the right track, more hacking options and a small remotely controlled cart are good additions. The graphics are also quite nice, while also stressing your hardware.

tl;dr 
Clear downgrade from the first part, interface and story (so far) are lacking, however some nice new features.

When I first played this game, it was a few years ago and right after I had finished the first one. I was already a little bit saturated with that type of game and the drastic change of setting and tone kinda put me off. That was a few years ago. 

I never played it again until recently. Now I can truly appreciate it. The graphics and sounds are beautiful. San Francisco is an amazing place to explore and the characters are really charming once you get to know them. You exchange the grim determination of Aidan Pierce for the playful idealism of Marcus and his friends, young hackers bent on changing the world and having as much fun as they can doing it. Made me remember what it was like to be that age, when I was free and everything seemed possible. :P Anyway, I think that change of setting and tone was actually a better fit for the gameplay. They added a lot of cool stuff and gameplay options (the RC buggy and drone add so many possibilities during missions).

Anyway, long story short, if you liked the first game, you'll like this one too. It builds up on what the first one did right and added several great features, like a good sequel should. But perhaps you should not play it right after the first one. Or maybe it won't bother you. And if you didn't play the first one, that's fine too. The story is lightyears away from the first one, so you won't feel like parts of the plot are missing because you don't know the story of the first one. There are online mission you can play with friends or random strangers, if that is your thing, and there are still plenty of people playing as of writing this review.

Watch Dos 2 is a masterpiece. Watch dogs 2 is highly underrated and I consider it to be one of the gaming greats. A story you get invested in, lovable characters, comedy, action, a surprisingly accurate depiction of San Francisco, decent graphics, advanced NPC interaction to the player and to each other and yet again highly underrated multiplayer modes. This game is quite extraordinary with realistic characters with real seeming emotions unlike other game characters. This game also features much diversity as two of the main characters are black, there is another main character with autism, a transgender character and there are LGBTIQ+ flags hanging everywhere. Watch dogs 2 is a huge improvement on the first game with updated graphics, a less dark tone, more charisma in the main character and in all the characters for that matter, a more enveloping story line and many MANY more hacking abilities. Overall, this game left me feeling satisfied and I felt genuinely sad when I finished it as the main story was over and I could never again fully experience the joy of playing through the missions for the first time. 11/10, an absolute masterpiece.
Best game ever, you wont regret buying it!

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week, he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character, and started playing but I was stuck on what I was supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Pros:
- Fun hacking/combat gameplay (when hacking into living spaces and doing main story hacking, there are some amusing results) 
- surprising amount of clothing customization
- Plenty of cars and weapons
- great graphics and mostly smooth gameplay (just an occasional glitch)
- sound track is pretty good
- tons of abilities to unlock
- fairly interactive world with tons of things and people's devices to hack into. 

Cons:
- Gameplay can be repetitive unless you deliberately attempt to approach hacking/combat in different ways.
- Wish different aspects of the game had more customization - like the HQ spots and more ways to tweak the vehicles
- While the side quests are necessary obtaining new abilities, i wish they had more to them- like more variety in the activities, or if they affected the main story/experience somehow. They are an rpg chore than anything.

Overall, the games main story is alot of fun, side operations are okay when you are bored, and free roam can be a good time-killer, especially when hacking into traffic lights or when you get the ability to call cops/gang members on unsuspecting npc's. 8/10

TL;DR: Remember high school? Well now those punk rebel kids and their weird grandpa are super "cool" hackers and they're gonna be really annoying about it. All they have to do to save the world from evil mega corp is plug the plorbus into the blumbis and the whole network is going to crack open for them to schmorgle the shmaegle. But there's gonna be a ton of guards in the way. Rinse and Repeat.

Originally gave a thumbs up, but after writing this switched to a thumbs down. Overall I give it a well deserved "meh."

It's leagues better than the first one and manages to not be as cringey for maybe a few hours. While the premise is good, and the gameplay overall enjoyable, Watchdogs 2 has some major holes in it. The whole "punk rock" hacker group trope starts off interesting but quickly becomes very stale. Gameplay wise Watchdogs 2 suffers from what most of these GTA type open world RPGs do, repetition, and superficiality. There is never really much going on in the world around you, and the world doesn't react to the things that you do in a very meaningful way. Apart from sending really annoying cops at you. The other enemies did NOT age well, I don't really understand what Ubisoft was thinking when they decided that the gangs were all going to be racial/ethnic stereotypes. 

There are so many immersion breaking aspects to the game and the story. Having a hypnotic screen break before every mission fragmented the game up in a really detrimental way. Despite all of this I felt that the biggest thing about Watchdogs 2 is that it is almost intentionally annoying. It felt like every character was trying way too hard to be this "i'm so edgy punk, screw society but I'm actually really cool about it" type. But that's also their whole personality. I guess what I'm trying to say is that all of the characters were really one dimensional. While playing I quickly became tired that there were these awkward moments where someone was having an angsty breakdown because "society is so screwed." No one's backstory is ever explored or explained in the main story and I frequently questioned how some characters even knew each other. 

The narrative also never acknowledges the gameplay. Ok, so I run in and shoot a bunch of people and blow up stuff. Well, why does no one outside the group ever start to say: "hey, this hacker group is literally killing people"? Why does no one inside the group say anything about that.... by the end of the game I was essentially also a mass murderer but that's ok as long as I was sticking it to the man? I felt that the game needed some kind of morality system for the narrative to work. Even though I took down evil mega corp at the end of the game, I still overall felt like the main character was more of a villain. But the whole time the story was trying to convince me that I was some sort of social hero. It didn't translate. 

By far the most aggravating aspect about Watchdogs 2 is that it NEVER stops explaining itself. In some ways it needs to. Tech is not a language everyone speaks, myself included. Even in this fantasy sense (because obviously all the tech/hacking techniques in watchdogs are made up to some extent) all the tech speak got very confusing. Sometimes it was like listening to someone say "Oh all we have to do is plug the plorbus into the blumbis and the whole network is going to crack open for us to schmorgle the shmaegle. But there's gonna be a ton of guards in the way." EVERY chance it gets, Watchdogs 2 makes a concerted effort to explain itself over and over and over. "What is this, why are we doing this, why is evil mega corp evil, and on and on and on, but make sure we never address these major plot holes and continuity errors".  Couple that with the repetitive missions that I mentioned earlier and it quickly turns into an absolute slog several hours in.
The writing was dated at the time of release, it's downright shit now. Also still buggy as all hell.
