[h1] 9.8/10 [/h1]
Went for the 100% completion on my one and only save game, took some time. Found all the research points somehow and searched every nook and crevice of San Francisco. Once you've thoroughly combed through the world of WD2, you come to realize how much there is. Endless NPC dialogue, and loads of choices.

Great game if you love detailed world exploration and extremely interactive environments. Definitely play WD1, I enjoyed the Chicago ending more but DedSec has its own flavor that never really matched Aiden's style. Sitara, Wrench, Horatio, Ray, and...that one dude, all compelling characters that make it feel like you're in a ragtag group of friends not entirely sure where they're going rather than the all-knowing persona they portray themselves to be (oh, the duality!). DedSec is a fun dynamic! Wrench is the cherry on top.

If I could sum up what to expect from the two games:
[b]DedSec's version of the "vigilante" is the whistle-blowing shepherd.
Aiden's version of the "vigilante" is one that sought revenge under the guise of justice.[/b]
The story from either game very much reflects these differences.

Personally, I enjoyed WD1's story more; but WD2's game mechanics are, of course, better (having built upon its prequel). Overall, awesome underrated experience. Tons of fun with multiplayer.

Important notes and tips. If these don't sound fun, or sound tedious, you might want to skip this game.
-Its a ubisoft sandbox without the towers but a lot of collectibles. This includes sightseeing and photography. The sightseeing has an ingame assistant to make this easier however. Most harder unlockables will have hints or story requirements that will point you to them directly.
-Stealth and your unlockable skills are the name of the game, not your weapons. Dedsec weapons have stealth options but better to use skills and traps than go loud.
-There is also a lot of driving and some very GTA style chase sequences that you need to pay attention to the map to find good spots to break sight gain distance, and lay low. You may be able to cheese it, but i haven't learned it yet. Overall i enjoy the driving mechanics, despite me playing on a keyboard with all the crashing into things that involves
-Use your drones. You can use them from inside of vehicles for additional protection to yourself if needed. Your jumper can even access some physical hacking locations without you needing to enter hostile zones.
-You are fragile, use every tool possible to avoid direct combat. Whether it be stealth, drones, environmental hazards, trap devices, or summoning police against gangs/gangs against police and security (it doesn't work very well the other way around and wastes botnet energy) to draw fire. Heck, you can hack cars to ram them into hostiles with great effect, just be sure to take out the ones that call reinforcements first.

Watch Dogs 2 [b]gameplay[/b] is mediocre at best. It's weird that Ubisoft made series like Splinter Cell (which felt extremely smooth) then made something like this. Watch Dogs 2 feels like it has Assassins Creed movement, but if it was a lot more... block-ey. The movements are a little slow, the animations are okay but also slow the movement process down; the movements seem limited. Essential movements are included such as running, sneaking, jumping, and climbing. However, the finer movements aren't quite there. The selling point of Watch Dogs 2 is the ability to hack into systems and use them to the player's advantage. This is a really fun aspect of the game and does require some skill to balance hacking and remaining undetected. Some hacking skills include overloading systems, unlocking systems, surveillance systems, and moving systems (such as driving a car remotely into something... or someone). The hacking mini-games are also a nice break away from the main game and test the player's reflexes and problem-solving abilities. As great as this is, it becomes a little cumbersome as the game goes on. Missions begin to feel repetitive and challenges begin to feel the same. The appeal of the game declines the more I drive. The driving is probably the worst part of the game (which the player will do a lot of).

The [b]graphics and visuals[/b] are actually well done. The approach they took between using CMD prompts, hacker-esque themes, and the overall layout of the UI is rock solid. I would argue this is one of the best parts of the game. Tied in with a riveting [b]story[/b], it delivers a very effective moral. The animations are okay, but I believe they could've been a little smoother. The damage to the vehicles (for example) seems to do general damage rather than specific damage. The [b]sounds and music[/b] are appropriate to the game. Sounds register where need be and the voice acting was done particularly well.

Overall, this game is worth a sale if you're really curious. Otherwise, I would recommend staying away from it. I was expecting something different, but got GTA mixed with some hacking features. I feel the most unique part of the game (hacking) wasn't properly utilized. The story is definitely worth watching, as for the rest of the game, not so much.

(making this review in light of recent events regarding ubisoft and DLC)
long story short: if watch dogs is just GTA with added hacking elements, then watch dogs 2 is the environment hacking game that we all wanted watch dogs to be with GTA stuff slapped onto it.
WD 1 and WD 2 are very, VERY different games. they differ wildly in tone, visual style, progression, and
most of all, gameplay.
watch dogs 2’s hacking isnt a tagline. it IS the game. no longer can you just silenced pistol your way through encounters. enemies are much more alert. they get alerted by missed gunshots, they spot you in seconds, they call backups much faster. in watch dogs 2, bullets hurt. like, they really hurt. you cant just hop up above cover, take a few shots, and then duck back down and regen your health to full. you go down nearly instantly. you dont have time to run away, you dont have time to melee an enemy when out in the open. and, the biggest kicker, is that theres no focus anymore. you cant just gun your way through bases anymore, slowing down time if it gets too hard. you need to think outisde the box. you need to be smart.
how? well, watch dogs 2 gives you much more tricks and tools to get your jobs done. well, its more like it gives you a few new tools, but those tools incredibly change up the game, and then they recontextualize alot of the existing ones. the RC jumper and quadcopter make all the difference, and can let you complete a mission without ever even setting foot on the restricted area. the crafting system and most of the gadgets from WD 1 have been combined and replaced, leaving only 2 throwable items: IEDs and Electro Shock grenades. no more Lures, because now EVERYTHING can lure enemies. no more Proximity Mines, because now EVERYTHING can be triggered by enemy proximity. no more Frag Grenades, because honestly did you ever use the frag grenades?
Vehicle combat in WD1 was, to be blunt, bad. Vehicle combat in WD2 is much better with 1 simple addition: you can now use guns while driving. you can shoot the driver, shoot the tires, shoot the engine, shoot anything.
the visual style of the game is fine. its a tiny bit of a downgrade, but it’s necessary for the upgrade in tone the game gets.
the games tone is much better than WD1. that game takes itself WAYYY too seriously. the characters in this game have actual personality and arent just cold, emotionless killers.
the graphics are like kinda better i guess. i dont really care.
the music is fine. the best thing i can say is it really fits the games tone, and it doesn’t sound terrible.
online functionality is improved alot.
all in all, i would say that WD2 is better, but like half life 1 and 2, it really isnt fair to compare them, and both are good in their own way.

Given the negativity surrounding this game's predecessor and sequel, [i]Watch_Dogs 2[/i] finds itself in an awkward spot. Despite the franchise's reputation, this game is very enjoyable; the story doesn't take itself too seriously, and hacking has vastly improved since the first game. The game certainly does have its faults -- the vehicle handling is a bit lackluster, and stealth becomes comically easy once you unlock the ability to distract people -- but this is heavily made up for by the game's setting. [i]Watch_Dogs 2[/i]'s San Francisco is, to this day, one of the most astonishingly busy game cities I've seen. It really makes you feel like a [i]part[/i] of this city, not the center of it.
     The NPC interactions are really a highlight here. Not only do people believably interact with one another, but the player as well. Wealthier people in the city will quickly identify you and pester you to leave them alone, making your infamy as a member of DedSec more believable. If you kill a member of a gang, that faction will start a conflict with you until you escape. If you use the [i]APB: Wanted Criminal[/i] ability to make some cops kill a gang member, that faction will start a conflict with the police. Factions go at each other without player interference, as well. I've spent tens of hours just running around and doing fuck all in this game -- I really cannot stress how entertaining (and bountiful) the different NPC interactions are.
     I can't conclude this review without mentioning the world itself, either. The environment is impressively well-constructed, and collectibles are (mostly) cleverly dotted all around the map. That aside, though... damn. This game is beautiful. Maybe it has something to do with that signature San Francisco fog, but the views at night are nothing short of incredible. Some of my favorite moments playing this game came from just driving around and sightseeing.
     This game is, unequivocally, the best in the franchise. It isn't perfect, of course -- the gunplay is just passable, the vehicle controls aren't nearly as robust as its contemporaries, and the story has its issues. The world is, in my opinion, the selling point here. I'd recommend buying the game for that reason alone. A lot of my love for this game is nostalgia-driven, but [i]Watch_Dogs 2[/i] really is a great title that I'd heavily recommend to anyone curious about the series.

Boy, did I ever want to like this game. I had heard positive buzz for the last six years about how it was better than Watch Underscore Dogs 1 (although it would be more impressive if it somehow managed to be worse than that game), and how the writing was actually decent. In particular, I remembered Austin Walker talking about how natural the code switching was between the game's black protagonist and the other black character on the team (which is true) and thought that sounded interesting and promising. I came in expecting not something especially great, but at least goofy dumb fun and enjoyable gameplay.

Well, I got at least... some of that. Mostly, it's just dumb. Very, very dumb. The first tutorial mission is genuinely great fun, opening with a charming and likable protagonist in a massive upgrade from the first game and having you do a heist that involves breaking in to a heavily secure evil corporation facility. It's great, it feels like Metal Gear Solid with phones, and beating it on Realistic with no deaths was hugely satisfying.

But then you get introduced to the OTHER main characters, who are either extremely bland and forgettable (can't remember their names for the life of me) or extremely unfunny and annoying (Wrench). Then you get to the first real open world mission, and it's about Marcus hacking an extraordinarily hamfisted and dated Martin Shkreli parody, one they were so worried you wouldn't understand that three separate characters explain the joke to you for five straight minutes. This carries all the way to the end of the mission, which is not as outright bizarre as WD1's sense of "humor" but is just as cringe-inducingly unfunny and difficult to watch.

OK, so, well, the game's fun isn't it? Well, it's really up and down. The side missions are when the game is at its best, letting you do arcade-y nonsense with little or no narrative while the charming protagonist cracks a few cute chuckle-worthy jokes (like calling himself "Will Smith" to an influencer whose gimmick is that she livestreams her drivers driving off sick-ass ramps). The game is often at its worst when it's Ubisoft Ubisoft-ing with thousands of pointless collectibles that are rarely any fun to actually get and mostly just means aggravating Donkey Kong 64 levels of pointless collectathon gameplay.

And then the online. Oh boy. Where do I start? It's fortunate that you can turn it off, and you should, because it's a terrible idea and terribly executed. As soon as your first open world mission, the "seamless multiplayer" kicks in, where in the middle of exploring the open world map you can get dropped into multiplayer matches with random players. If you've EVER played a multiplayer open world game, i.e. GTA4 or Just Cause 2 Online, you immediately might recognize this as a recipe for disaster. First of all, it happens completely randomly with very little warning or ability to stop it outside of disabling the "feature," so you can be in the middle of escaping a police chase when a random player spawns, starts trying to hack you, and then for some reason starts trying to hit you with a car (this happened to me.)

But the other thing is that you're severely underequipped and unexperienced compared to everyone else playing online, especially in 2022. The players who "invade" your game have more unlocked skills, better cars, and better guns, but they also have considerably more knowledge of the game and practice with the controls. If you're playing pacifist and using non-lethal weapons, which are considerably fewer and worse, you're even more screwed since you're literally outgunned. Since for some reason the online unlocks almost immediately rather than being locked until a certain point in the story, this has the effect of the game randomly becoming frustrating and confusing, if not nearly unplayable.

The game does look very nice despite being buggy (it sets the aspect ratio to your highest *possible* resolution which is baffling) and unoptimized (six years later and you simply can't hit 60FPS on max settings even with a new PC), and I would definitely argue it's more worth your money than WD1 or even something like RDR2 which has writing that's even more atrocious and characters even more unlikable but also restricts your ability to do anything outside the box at all... but there are definitely better games and better open world games. Driver San Francisco, Burnout Paradise, the more recent Assassin's Creed games, are all far better worth your time.

Also Ubisoft forcing you to use their horrible launcher and put up with their awful DRM is both enough for a negative review by itself and absolutely comical for a game about anarchist anti-capitalist rebel hackers.

If anyone were to want to understand what game design elements distinguish stealth games from cover-shooter games, I can think of three games that would suit that study perfectly: any Metal Gear Solid game, any Uncharted game, and Watch Dogs 2. Why the latter, you ask? Because while MGS mostly lacks combat sequences and Uncharted sneaking sequences, Watch Dogs 2 plays the two systems entirely… halfway. It wants to be a sneaking game where you can accomplish objectives totally remotely and, thus, undetected, using RC drones, but it also wants to be a shooter game where you mow down waves of enemies using insanely powerful weapons while some upbeat licensed song plays in the background just to make sure you really feel as invincible as your character.

And, while I understand that this might be an unpopular perspective, I would argue that it is this unwillingness to commit to either being a sneaking game or a cover-shooter that makes me feel that, for all of the gameplay and presentation improvements made over its predecessor, Watch Dogs 2 ultimately falls short as a complete package. But we'll get there; it’s time to sing some well-earned praises.

Watch Dogs 2 is a lavishly animated, lushly designed visual experience that showcases some exceptional skill and talent by the development team. Colors are bright and vibrant, some truly outstanding and evocative lighting can be found in a few select areas, and animations are fantastically smooth, especially with regard to characters and how they emote. The amount of polish poured over the look of the game absolutely deserves respect and is far-and-away one of its strongest aspects, the polish easily outshining the rather rough-looking first game.

Additionally, in spite of my remarking on the halfway-ness of some game mechanics, the wider array of usable hacks is definitely a highlight. There are so many ways to mess with enemies, either by making a nearby car suddenly speed backwards into a wall, blacking out a building, or (easily the most useful) distracting them with a text message so you can walk right past them undetected. The number of different hacks far exceeds what was seen in the previous game, which took its core selling point of “hacking stuff” and ultimately undercut it by favoring straight gunplay instead. That said, one could interpret this reserve to employing what basically amounts to a magic trick as an attempt to maintain at least the slightest bit of realism in the first game. 

Watch Dogs 2 completely throws all of that out the window; you can cause as much mayhem as you like or do all manner of stupid hijinks and there will be absolutely no repercussions; maybe police will be called and they might kill you eventually, and then… nothing, as if it never happened. It could be argued that Watch Dogs has a similar problem, but that game at least had a reputation meter which dictates whether or not NPCs will call the cops on you; it’s not a major aspect of the game at all, but it does make it just a tiny bit deeper. The sequel has this almost nihilistic element baked into it that is completely incongruous with the game’s characters and plot; if nothing you do in the world has even the slightest effect on the state of affairs, what’s the point of being a part of this vigilante hacker group?

It’s this lack of any semblance of realism and an underlying unwillingness to take any of the gameplay seriously that causes the game to start to lose me. This is especially true when one factors in that the actual plot is played very straight; the villain is painted to be extremely sinister and a side character even dies halfway through. Actually, let’s talk about those points for a moment. To address the latter one first, [spoiler]Horatio is killed off for no plot-related reason at all; it seems that someone decided that because Marcus, the playable character/main hero, is also black, some kind of misguided diversity quota was satisfied so Horatio is expendable? I mean, just… what [i]the f*ck?[/i][/spoiler] In fairness, Watch Dogs also killed off a character rather needlessly near the end, too, but such a fate was basically set in stone for that character given prior plot developments. As for the villain, his nickname being “The Douche” should clue you in to the fact that he’d be more at home as a villain in The Big Lebowski instead, but alas, here we are with this guy who has a man-bun, way too much facial hair, the attitude of a class bully, and (count ‘em) FOUR fit-bits.

I’m going to ask that you indulge me a little bit as I rant about my subjective dislike of Watch Dogs 2’s aesthetic. To paint an image of how inescapable the coating of ridiculousness was, here is a personal anecdote: I was fast-travelling from clothing store to clothing store, running from clothing item to clothing item, looking for some kind of serious wardrobe to wear (preferably a coat of sorts), but all I could find were plain hoodies, leather kuttes that were way too revealing, sagging pants, and preppy button-ups with (I kid you not) bowties. The one long coat to be found in Watch Dogs 2 was Aiden’s original one from the previous game, clearly more for purposes of parody than homage when you consider they didn’t even bother to make available a fedora that matches it in color. And the wardrobe issues are not even at the top of the list; the main characters act like idiots because, well, they’re stupid kids, but it’s kind of difficult to see these vigilante hackers as capable professionals if they behave unprofessionally damn near all the time. If I can’t even take my playable character, my proxy, the way in which I interface with this vast simulation, let alone any of the supporting cast, remotely seriously, how am I supposed to consider anything that happens in the plot that the game demands be taken seriously with any measure of dramatic weight? 

And in spite of all my ranting about aesthetic choices in Watch Dogs 2, it’s the absent character drama that is easily the problem most pertinent to me. To be fair, it does have a couple emotional moments, but these mainly exist in a vacuum. Watch Dogs has serious dramatic roots that fit with its gritty, crime-noir elements; it stands on its own as a genre piece about mobsters and corporations, injustice and vengeance, but it also functions as a neat character piece showing just how tortured the majority of the characters are. It’s dark and not at all funny. It’s deeply sad and steeped in a world of crime simultaneously unseen yet tolerated and abused by those in power. It’s brimming with rage at the unfairness of a broken city said to be a utopia and gateway to the future.

What happened to all those emotions? Where did all that anger go?

One may counter with the following question: “I’m here to play a game. If the gameplay itself is actually decent, why bother caring about things like story or emotion?” And that’s a fair point; if there’s one thing I learned in all of this, it’s that I probably enjoy films more than games, and, like all games, Watch Dogs 2 should be considered a game first. But I would argue that Watch Dogs 2 does not commit to this prioritization either; just the (very strong) possibility that one could play lethally in a game where dumb kids do dumb things in a dumb world to thwart dumb plans and nobody would ever care about the human cost involved in their actions goes to show that this is a game that is very confused about what it wants to be. Part of me wishes that Watch Dogs 2 was a dramatic tale about actually confused kids trying to find their way in the world while also working up the courage to stop a corrupt corporation. If the game had stuck to that creative vision, it would have (ironically) been less confused about what it is and how it would play.

Probably the only review I am ever going to write, but after trying to get into this game for a longer than I'd like I just want this perspective out there. I was not nearly as big of a critic of the first Watch Dogs game as most seemed to be. I thought the city was beautiful to walk around in ("BUT THE GRAPHICS WEREN'T AS GOOD AS THEY PROMISE" shut up, they were fine.) and I enjoyed the story. Now I know that's where a lot of people took issue with the original Watch Dogs. They think that Aiden talked too much about getting revenge for his niece, that he wouldn't lighten up. I mean, I think it's reasonable to be a bit vindictive after someone kills your young niece, but whatever.

Although apparently the directors for Watch Dogs 2 took that message to heart. Seeing as how in Watch Dogs 2 you play as this nerdy but supposedly funny psuedo-justice warrior that, inbetween getting wasted on the beach, going to burning man to cheer up, and nerding out over a new cheesy movie with his friends, likes to solve the social problems of our world by playing "sick pranks" on the evil corporate masterminds. That includes tricking a Pharma CEO into spending a million dollars on a new rap album that doesn't exist, or stealing the prop car for a new movie that is making fun of hackers and taking it on a joy ride around San Fransisco. And the most bewildering part of these pranks is that you are murdering between 1-10 security guards and cops just so you can pull off your dope pranks. It makes no sense! They aren't some gang bangers who are selling crack to the youth of SF, they're just some blue color employee who get gunned down by a meme slinging hacker who is just looking to have fun. It completely ruins any sort of immersion for me. 

And here I can say one positive thing about the game, the map is also very pretty, but that's about it... The game has the same subpar gunplay and driving mechanics that were in the first Watch Dogs game, and aside from the addition of some gimmicky remote controlled cars and helicopters, the hacking mechanics are pretty much the same.

Like it said, I just want my perspective out there, I know this game is receiving much higher reviews than its predecessor, but for those out there that enjoyed the original Watch Dogs, be wary about this purchase.

When everything is all put together, Watch_Dogs 2 is a mediocre open-world game from the king of mediocre - Ubisoft. Where this game specifically differs is in how the mediocrity is achieved - not through everything being in itself mediocre, but with the game not knowing what it's supposed to be, as the parts are great, but the sum is lesser than them.

Before even starting the game, there is one big problem that plagues Watch_Dogs 2. I hate Uplay, and I suspect most people do, but the bigger problem with this game specifically and many other games that came out post-2016 from Ubisoft is that it's region-locked, and so if you've bought the game from China or a CIS country, the language is specifically locked to either Chinese or Russian, including the voice acting (I've only heard this, and haven't experienced a locking to Chinese or Russian voice acting myself, so don't quote me on this), which is notably worse than the English performances. This disregards the fact that many people in CIS countries do not speak Russian or do not speak it to a reasonable extent so as to play the game. Foreigners living in CIS countries and China will also be at a disadvantage. There is a workaround, but while it's pretty easy to do, this shouldn't be a problem in the first place.

Watch_Dogs 2 does look good, though. It's a technically impressive game with a whole load of graphical options, and that's kind of what Ubisoft is known for, making good-looking games that are more tech demos than anything. San Francisco is an absolute joy to look at, and the city's landmarks are all there, gorgeously modeled and textured. The animation is also great in cutscenes, and the art direction is good at capturing the more lighthearted tone of the narrative as well as the more sunny city of San Francisco. The performances are also top-notch, with great voice actors given bad material to work with. The design in terms of sound and art hits the mark exactly, creating an atmosphere that sufficiently fits what the game's going for.

The same really cannot be said about the gameplay, seeing as it tries to do something interesting by including dynamic and systemic gameplay, but doesn't really go far enough. You'll see seamless transitions from singleplayer to multiplayer, as well as nice dynamic shootouts between different factions that you can actually influence, but nothing goes far enough as to actually make the systems affect the gameplay in an extremely meaningful way. The multiplayer missions are pretty bad, and with the game effectively being dead in terms of multiplayer - you'll see people around but they won't really play with you - the multiplayer missions are pretty useless. The systems of faction wars also don't work as well - the gangs don't even expand or take territory, and there's not much change going on in them. At one point, I spent a long time calling gangs and police into a mission area that left a whole lot of people lying on the floor, and yet they never stopped coming - every few minutes, someone from the faction that held the mission area would call for reinforcements, and since I didn't really bother to care about reinforcements, the entire manpower of that faction must have been completely sucked out of them. The game does give you a lot of gadgets like the Quadcopter or Jumper, two drones you can remote control, and that's great, and there's a whole lot of environmental objects that you can interact with, but eventually, the missions they're used in just bog down to scoping out the area through cameras or drones, hacking a key, hacking physically through sending the Jumper in, and then getting out. Combat as a gameplay style is also very much disincentivized through your health being really low - a few shots and you're going to have to go back to the last checkpoint. The challenge presented by the game can also be easily worked around - there's an ability you can get pretty early that simply allows you to disable security features like motion-sensors or bots, and there are get-out-of-jail-free cards like Mass Distract, which distracts everyone for a generous time window, or the fact that you can get out of a police chase by just going off-road for a bit and hiding in your car. While the level design is good for the main missions, you won't really get that out of the side missions, and some of the missions are so laughably easy or hard given your abilities.

Open-world design is, however, significantly better here than in other Ubisoft games. By removing the entire thing going on about radio towers and liberating areas, the entirety of San Francisco is open to you at the start, allowing you to explore. The side quests are also much better than in other Ubisoft games, and most of them you come across organically. There are also a few restricted areas in the open world that do not have any impact in the story and instead have money or tech tree points in them, and the fact that Ubisoft doesn't guide you to any of these is also great, in contrast to camp design in their other games. In this I feel like Ubisoft has really hit something - diverting from its standard open-world formula for something not too radically different, but still interesting. My main problem with the open world is that it feels absolutely soulless while walking through the streets - it's San Francisco, but it feels like a small town in a way because of the lack of population, and what population is there doesn't do much besides react to your actions and maybe serving as an easy way to get botnet, the "mana" used for hacking. The driving is also horrible, and the cars feel like they're lighter than a sack of feathers as they glide around while driving.

The writing is the only other part of the game that I feel is unequivocally mediocre at best. There are absolutely no consequences whatsoever to anything in the game - you take down megacorporations and they don't even bat an eye, you're made public enemy #1 and no one comes after you. One of the characters even dies at some point, and even that is disconnected from the main story and you don't even feel anything for them. The characters are hollow, their personalities only there to be vehicles for terrible jokes that differ in tone from what's actually going on in the game with corporate greed. Watch_Dogs 2 seems to have an addiction to joking around even when it doesn't fit with what's going on. These characters are insanely one-dimensional - Marcus is just the protagonist, a blank slate with no motivation pr backstory other than the fact that he hates Silicon Valley. Wrench, despite having the potential for a character arc through his lack of self-confidence towards women, can be summed up as just "a weird guy who likes to make references". Josh is just "the autistic guy", Sitara is "the video-maker and also kind-of the de-facto leader?", Horatio is pretty much nonexistent as a character, and Ray, who you might recognize as T-Bone in the first game, is just "the old guy who incidentally also likes to make bad jokes". The main villain is also surprisingly absent and doesn't really affect the story that much besides one encounter with him in the mid-game as well as the ending - he's just the quintessential Ubisoft villain, with a charismatic and ruthless charm. I will admit that the performances are great, and that the voice actors deserve serious props - otherwise, the story is very much hollow.

Because Steam has to have you make your review either a positive or a negative one, I'll lean towards the negative here. Watch_Dogs 2 has a lot of charm, yes, and it is fun, but it is essentially a hollow game. This isn't helped at all by the price tag, which even now, many years after release, is still high.

Watch Dogs 2 is easily my favorite entry in the series. Ubisoft has a bad habit of making half-cooked games, but they nailed all the checkpoints with this one. Marcus is an interesting character, the world is beautiful, and the game has a lively spirit which Watch Dogs and Watch Dogs Legion lack. For people who are fans of the movie Hackers, you'll likely see a lot of similarities while playing. The game doesn't take itself too seriously, but at the same time, manages to maintain a story where the events have meaning. With Watch Dogs 4, I hope they go back to more of the elements that make Watch Dogs 2 so great.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

End Remarks: The experience was amazing. The environment, ambience, and everything made San Francisco feel like the real thing, it felt really alive. With the NPC dialogue to the buildings, it very nicely depicts the Bay Area. The gameplay is really addictive but sometimes challenging (good). The parkour is really really really neat and the best of the Watch Dogs series. There are 2 cons: Ubisoft and the story. As Ubisoft, there is the weird online feature (which I do not like) where random people join your singleplayer game and can mess around and kill you. The second is the story. The story is meh. It's average at best. I feel like it is too comedic at times and is very predictable. But overall, it's an excellent game and definitely worth buying.

Watch Dogs 2 is a pretty interesting game. As someone who played the first game, jumping into this one is such a whiplash. The more lighthearted and comedic tone is a weird direction to go after the first game, but I think it works. It features a pretty likable cast of characters. Both the main protagonists and main antagonists are interesting and fun to interact with and have managed to keep me captivated with the story. My main problem is it's a Ubisoft game. As always with Ubisoft games, they become huge slogs to go through. I couldn't finish the game because it became way too tedious to play. While I think the gameplay isn't that bad, I can't really recommend the game and I will probably never go back to it.

Graphics - 5 - I'm not a picky person when it comes to graphics. This game looks great to me and has aged well so far.

Gameplay - 3 - I find the mechanics pretty good and have had fun using them. Although the drones can be a bit irritating to use and the hacking sequences have camera problems which can also be annoying. This game tries to be a stealth game, however it seems like the best option most of the time is to just cap motherfuckers with your high-powered weapons. The multiplayer is very fun and enjoyable to play and the missions are pretty decent if a bit repetitive. The later story missions are downright infuriating and is the main reason I stopped playing however.

Enjoyment - 3.5 - I quite enjoyed my time in multiplayer and singleplayer before it was just a chore to play. If I didn't play with friends, this score would be even lower.

Total - 11.5/15

While the game was promising for the first 20 hours, it just became a disappointment which is pretty sad to me.

This game is hollow. Beneath the stylish aesthetic, well-designed characters, and that gorgeous San Francisco sunshine, you will find zero personality. Please don't buy this game. For the price, there are so many other better experiences out there- better action games, better stealth games, better RPGs, even better hacking games. 

Pros:

Game looks beautiful, particularly when driving.

Hacking skills and tactics are cool, bamboozling the enemy is satisfying.

Genuinely profound commentary on corporate interference, privacy violations, and big tech abuse. 

Wrench.

Cons:

The story is so... nothing. Villain is generic, several plot elements end without warning or are never pursued. Several mechanics just have zero purpose (why have lethal and nonlethal weapons when there is no morality or karma system?) Strange, cringeworthy dialog... you aren't playing this for the story.

World is empty and meaningless. None of the many restaurants, pawn shops or clothing stores have unique items or services. All the world does is take up space between you and various interactive objectives.

Boring, repetitive quests. Go here, hold "e" on this object. That's 60% of the game. 

This is just me personally, but I hate Key Data. Essentially, if you want to unlock certain skills in the skill tree, you have to find key data in certain locations throughout the map. The placement of these items are totally arbitrary. There was no reason to add key data other than to pad the game out and make unlocking skills a slow, grindy experience. 

Most weapons aside from the grenade launchers and shotguns lack impact. 

This is such a nothing game. A really cool, stylish first 20 hours and a fun last 5 hours, and the most boring, meaningless 30+ hours in between. Play Orwell, Metal Gear, Hitman, any of those. Just do yourself a favor and don't buy this game. I played it so you don't have to.
ver e fun plaed for hors it was gopd
Good game

Ya know, I gotta say it. WD2 was better for me in almost every aspect vs WD1 (I played WD1 directly before starting 2). The open world just feels like its actually populated as opposed to the dead world of 1.
 
Pros:
- Goldilocks map size (not too big, not too small)
- Hacking civilians was less of a chore ( i hated the random missions you got on WD1, just tedious)
- The game ran great for me and loaded quickly (3070ti / 5600x)
- Unobtrusive multiplayer elements
- Decent gun play, controls are responsive, some of the mapping is a little weird
- GREAT music. Decent graphics.
- Voice acting, characters and storing all held their own IMO.
- Many of the side quest lines are unique and enjoyable.
- The collectibles are worth doing for the skill unlocks and cosmetics.
- The cosmetics are WAAAAAYYYY better than WD1, you can actually dress your character.
- The RC drone / car add some nice puzzle elements and variety to fights / secure areas.

Cons:
- I actually would have preferred they picked a path with the main character. If he's a good guy that doesn't do violence, why do I have a grenade launcher? Would liked to have seen more development on the non- lethal side of combat. 
- The RC stuff was kinda shallow.
- AI is still so DUMB. Holy cow they are so bad times its funny. No challenge really.
- The animation for the take down is ridiculous with how long it takes.
- No car mods / upgrades. Too many of the cars feel samey. Also you're almost immortal in vehicles.
- With no fail states for most missions, some of them still just devolve into killing everybody so I can just leave. 
- Not enough missions w/ cars and boats
- A little buggy here and there (my phone menu disappeared after I beat the main story and I had to Alt F4 out)
- Some of the node hacking is comically spread out and it starts to feel tedious.

Overall, I would definitely recommend this game, especially over WD1 (just an opinion). If you can, get the bundle and play both.

I have 100% this game. Twice.

Story
It's definitely fun, the story is cool although I would have liked to see the original lead. I relate heavily to the whole "Down with the man" killing corporate greed vibes. The art is sick and has it's own punk style.

Mechanics
Tons of fun, however slightly easier than regular GTA-like games because of the addition of hacking. Often I just wouldn't use it if I am mucking about but getting rid of cops while doing story is very easy and when you catch the cutscene just right, it is satisfying to see a cop headbutt a pole or get T-boned in traffic.

Overall even in 2022 I would definitely recommend this and the first one, if nothing more than to enjoy a good 2 days binge of a great story with cool characters.

Once again, like the last game, Watch_Dogs 2 has cool gameplay, but this installment has a story and cast WAY better than the first. I could actually relate somewhat to Marcus Holloway, as he actually displayed emotions, and so did the rest of the members of DedSec. I was laughing at the start of this game, just like the last installment, but this time it was because of the actions of Marcus. After the tutorial mission, Marcus gets plastered drunk, throws his phone into the ocean, then wakes up the next morning hungover, without pants, in someone else's house, and somehow he got a new phone in the process despite throwing it into the ocean the night before. Marcus then meets the members of DedSec, all of which bring their own special ingredient to the table.
Wrench: Comic relief. Love him and the mask.
Sitara: Branding artist. For some reason has beef with another character.
Horatio: I enjoyed the interactions between Marcus and Horatio. Both of them being black, they naturally get along quickly.
Josh: Meh. I didn't think about him that much at all.
[spoiler]Ray: Yes, T-Bone is back! For some reason Sitara beefs with him a lot, but he's just as funny as he was in the original title, as well as Bad Blood.[/spoiler]

Alright, so I'm going to be weird and review this game 5 years after playing it, but hear me out. If you're curious about the Watch Dogs series but short on time, I recommend just playing this one. It's unfairly forgotten because it's bookended by more controversial games (WD1 and WD Legion), but I think it's the best of the bunch for a lot of reasons. Rather than a true review I'll just try to convince you why WD2 is the one worth playing, since this is a well-known series anyway.

This game doesn't get enough credit for subverting a lot of the typical Ubisoft tropes and cliches. For example, the entire game's map is available to you from the start with nothing held back -- no tower climbing or busywork needed. You can just jump straight into the game and enjoy it. And your mileage may vary on the characters and dialogue, but I personally think it's better than the majority of Ubisoft games. It's lighthearted, funny, and weirdly self aware. Even among the trio of Watch Dogs games, WD2 stands out with regards to both of these things: the gameplay and writing are really good.

I think the fun of the Watch Dogs series is the "puzzle box" design of the missions and open-ended gameplay, and WD2 is where this is at its best. Scouting out a mission with the quadcopter and buggy and then sneaking around for non-lethal stun gun takedowns is gratifying and awesome. Aiden Pearce's toolkit in WD1 is much more limited, and you're pretty much forced to hide and get pistol headshots; WD2 is where the fun of using your gadgets and hacking/manipulating the environment really comes into play. To top this off, in WD Legion, the follow up to this game, a lot of these hacking abilities were removed or simplified, which is a real letdown.

Lastly to comment on WD2's aesthetic, it's a colorful parody of Silicon Valley culture. It doesn't take itself too seriously, and I think that's to the game's benefit. Also, you can call a SWAT team on an NPC for making of your shirt if you want to. What's not to love about that?

This game reminded me of Dead Island: Riptide in many way. Almost everything that was good about the first game makes a comeback here; smash-and-grab joyrides, duck-and-cover tactical missions, parkouring all over a major city looking for collectibles. The online community is here, too, with PvP hacking missions, co-op play, and even online vehicle and drone racing. Ubisoft has also added to the mix, giving players weird side missions like Instagraming at San Francisco's many points of interest or Ubering people around.
Much like DI:R, this game should be just as good, if not better, than its predecessor, since it keeps all the good things and adds to them. And yet, something is missing. It's all enjoyable but it feels stunted somehow. And then it hits you; it's all about the story. Watch_Dogs had a fairly interesting main story about the interconnections of modern hackers, old-school mobsters, and corrupt politics, all riding on the back of a giant tech corporation that makes operating systems. The sequel tries to do the same, this time with all of Silicon Valley being entangled with street gangs, corrupt politicians, dirty cops, and even more hackers working with or for the various "bad guys". Aiden Pierce was an tragic character who was stumbled across a dirty secret and was pulled into a fight with conspiring forces and being aided by hackers who open up his mind; Marcus Holloway is just some dude who wanted to join a group of woke hackers and anarchists and stick it to the man. It's not horrible, it's just....the most basic form of rehash without the emotional depth that helps someone connect to the main character.
Mind you, if you like GTA-style games, you'll have a good time playing the game. It's smooth, it's pretty, it's got some cool gadgets (namely a drone and a tiny RC bot on wheels that both offer creative alternatives to shooting everything to complete a mission), extensive unlockable outfit, car, and weapon customisation options, and, obviously, just as much hacking as the first game. The apparently repeatable online missions might even keep you playing the game for a few hours after completing the main story, side-missions, and collectibles. This is a game I definitely recommend, just with a note that it's marginally not better than its predecessor.

Watch_Dogs 2: The only game where a hacker can hack the whole city, fight cops and street gangs while wearing an oversize kitty hoodie.You can't do that in skyrim or elden ring or GTA V. This is a masterpiece of a game.

Simply held: It's Amazing.
I have two 100% runs on PS4 and Xbox, so don't get distracted by my Playtime on here.

First off: The Music
W_D2 has a nice score made for the Game itself, but the Copyrighted music just stands out. I am so glad that this Game has a Mediaplayer so I can make a banger Playlist of the Ingame songs. Songs like "San Francisco (Be Sure to Wear Flowers in Your Hair)" or "I want a new Dr*g" are just soooo good. 

The Graphics are pretty Standard. I mean it's a 2016 game, it's nothing we haven't seen before but it sure ain't ugly either. Especially now that I am on PC, I can embrace the Vibe of SF even more with Ultra Settings and 100+ FPS.

The Movement and the animations are beautiful, they're definitely the best in the Series. I mean, even the backflips off of random power boxes are so satisfying.

The Story ain't special by itself, but the setting and the characters that are involved make me like it so much. I mean, one of the first missions is to [spoiler] drive a Vehicle like K.I.T.T from Knight Rider around the City while listening to Turbo Lover by Judas Priest and being chased by Police [/spoiler] how cool is that??

The Characters are stereotypes, I have to admit that, but they're just so damn likeable? Like, Wrench is [spoiler] your typical  Anarchist that pretends to be cool, mysterious and untouchable, but in the end he's just as vulnerable as anyone else. A scared kid that doesn't really know his place in the world. [/spoiler] . Josh is [spoiler] the classic introvert that slowly becomes more confident as the story progresses [/spoiler] etc. etc.

The Customization is really good, but sadly it lacks the possibility to change your hair or beard. Besides that, there are many, many clothing options which you can try out. 

The Missions are fun. I can't think of one single Mission that I don't like tbh. Even the sidemissions are good! 
I can't really complain about variety of playstyle, since most missions can be played however you like to play.

The driving. I mean, it's Ubisoft. Do I have to say more? I guess so.
They were never good at making a decent Driving Experience. Wether it's Watch Dogs or Ghost Recon, the driving is whacky af. One of the only negative points that I have to aknowledge. Maybe even the only major one.

The Drone and Jumper features are a great addition to the game. They make Stealth even more approachable for new players that aren't skilled in Sneaky playstyles, but also give you a chance to execute a perfectly thought out Plan.

The Weapons all kinda feel the same, but there is a good amount to choose from. From Designs to the weapons themselves, everyone should find something that suits the personal taste. 

I might be a little biased, I have to admit, since it's my Fav game for years now. But, I deeply recommend Watch Dogs 2 with all of my heart. If you didn't like the first one because of the tone, the lack of Variety in Hacking or whatever it was, I promise you that W_D2 is at least worth a try. Like Titanfall 2, it flew underneath the Radar in 2016 and that's such a shame.

Is Ubisoft Connect down? Can't sign in and you can't play.
Did you set up 2fa? No? They say you did and won't let you sign in unless you input the 2fa code or recovery code they never sent you.
The fact Ubisoft makes you jump through pointless hoops just to launch a game you already payed for and installed is atrocious, stupid, short-sighted, etc.
I have already payed you and installed the game but now I have to install another separate piece of software and sign in through that every time just to play?
IDK what Ubisoft gets out of it but it must be worth it considering they are a constant annoyance everytime you launch the game and they don't care at all.

in short: Watchdogs 2 = Decent Game UbiSoft Connect = Terrible, annoying gatekeeper that serves no purpose other than to take up space and get in you way.

Almost everything that was good about the first game makes a comeback here; smash-and-grab joyrides, duck-and-cover tactical missions, parkouring all over a major city looking for collectibles. The online community is here, too, with PvP hacking missions, co-op play, and even online vehicle and drone racing. Ubisoft has also added to the mix, giving players weird side missions like Instagraming at San Francisco's many points of interest or Ubering people around.
Much like DI:R, this game should be just as good, if not better, than its predecessor, since it keeps all the good things and adds to them. And yet, something is missing. It's all enjoyable but it feels stunted somehow. And then it hits you; it's all about the story. Watch_Dogs had a fairly interesting main story about the interconnections of modern hackers, old-school mobsters, and corrupt politics, all riding on the back of a giant tech corporation that makes operating systems. The sequel tries to do the same, this time with all of Silicon Valley being entangled with street gangs, corrupt politicians, dirty cops, and even more hackers working with or for the various "bad guys". Aiden Pierce was an tragic character who was stumbled across a dirty secret and was pulled into a fight with conspiring forces and being aided by hackers who open up his mind; Marcus Holloway is just some dude who wanted to join a group of woke hackers and anarchists and stick it to the man. It's not horrible, it's just....the most basic form of rehash without the emotional depth that helps someone connect to the main character.
Mind you, if you like GTA-style games, you'll have a good time playing the game. It's smooth, it's pretty, it's got some cool gadgets (namely a drone and a tiny RC bot on wheels that both offer creative alternatives to shooting everything to complete a mission), extensive unlockable outfit, car, and weapon customisation options, and, obviously, just as much hacking as the first game. The apparently repeatable online missions might even keep you playing the game for a few hours after completing the main story, side-missions, and collectibles. This is a game I definitely recommend, just with a note that it's marginally not better than its predecessor.
Definetly not worth the money but sure go ahead if it's on sale. I also think it was very confusing learning to play the game so keep that in mind if you're thinking about buying it.

Watch_Dogs 2 was a great game for me.

It's an open-world hacking and stealth game where you can hack and remotely manipulate electronic devices, vehicles, etc., including via security cameras and drones.

The stealth mechanics and remote control capabilities really made it feasible for me to play in a nonconfrontational way, using cameras, drones, and environmental features to achieve my goals.

The messaging about corporate and governmental data abuse really resonated, and the writing and acting was well done.

I didn't do any of the online stuff, but with the main story and the single player side missions, there was always plenty to do.

First off the game is way better than the Original with a more exciting story and a prettier World to Explore.
With ability to hack vehicles, computers, street lights and anything with a chip in it, makes the possibilities endless. This game works best when you use stealth and not play this like GTA Guns blazing kill everyone. instead use tools your given and feel good when you Succeed in mission. San Francisco is the new setting of the game, and it serves as one of the best open world maps in any game I ever played. The city is just full of life and seems like every NPC in it walking the streets has a purpose. People are working out, walking dogs, doing martial arts at the park, they do yoga, they greet each other on the streets, they sit around under a tree chatting, they talk on the phone, get into car crashes, play guitar, go shopping and the list just goes on and on. There is never a boring scene anywhere, and I often just spend time walking around doing parkour, and exploring all the sights and sounds. There are side missions but they dont feel like side mission and if you do them all you will find your time was not wasted. I could write about this game for hours, but I rather go back and play it now. All in all, it is an amazing sandbox experience with great action, smooth driving, cool parkour and an excellent story.

Watch Dogs 2 is... Fine.
It is an open world Ubisoft game, so you should know what you're getting into. And for the most part it does function quite well. The driving is still as good as the first one, and it does enough different to make it a sequel rather than "Watch Dogs 1 but a bit more". The RC Jumper and the Drone really do put a spin on things and tickles some Puzzle Solving jolts in a different way. I never found it too hard, and it does allow you to play your own way. Though 'Stealth' did seem to suffer during the transition from the first game, whereas enemies detect you significantly faster. And sometimes killing someone with a (silenced) headshot alerts the entire base.

It's the Theme, story, and main character that really start throwing me off though:

The Theme - I never really cared for Dedsec in WD1. The deep voice, the videos, the graffiti style, it all didn't appeal to me. The fact that your "Experience" bar is replaced by (Online) Followers... I mean, it's kinda clever for a game and it does make sense in a story/lore standpoint. So Kudos on them for that. Honestly? I think I'm either just too old for this theme, or it's just not for me. It's not terrible nor does it make the game unplayable, but I was getting vibes of "Looking back at your teenage/high school years and what you thought was COOL back then, then groaning as result." If you're fine with the cheese, go for it. To each their own, but I'm not a cheesy person.

The Story - A lot more light-hearted this time around, often enough your missions are "let's stick it to the man!" style of teen rebellion. Overall the story itself is fine, it does have its flaws, but I easily put it below WD1's more serious story/warning of the dangers of technology. Sure, WD2 does touch on it as well, but... It didn't feel quite the same. I'm having a hard time placing a claw on exactly what it is.

Characters - I didn't like them at first, but they grew on me. It got to the point where I was playing the story/side stories to see what they would say or do- especially Wrench. Wrench was just the best by far. But I even grew to care for Josh and some of the other side characters, having a bit of a soft spot for the Autistic and Transgender. I honestly felt like they did them well.

But Marcus/Retr0/your main character... Don't get me wrong, his VA did a great job. But the guy is suuuuuch a Gary Sue: I never spotted a weakness in him through the entire game. He was good at everything, friendly to everyone, capable in any situation, remained cool under pressure- the list goes on. There was no flaw to be found anywhere. It's nice to have the very wholesome moments with the other members of Dedsec, but Marcus never seemed to have his down moments. Aiden was a lot more of a complex character dealing with a lot of heavy weight, he may not have been everyone's cup of tea but... Marcus just kinda felt like a generic flavor to please everyone. "The Safe Option." Not bad, and several thousand times better than a silent protagonist, but they could've put a little bit more into his side of the story.

That final mission was pretty cool though (no spoiling). WD1's still felt more satisfying, but WD2's final one was a good idea.

Overall, I do recommend the game for sure. Just... Know what you're getting into.

Also: if you're like me and just want to play the game 100% on single player/offline; look into mods. Just getting any mod (like "skip the intro bumpers") is enough to keep your game offline and not have to worry about people suddenly joining in. Seriously Devs: ALWAYS give the player the option to turn this jazz off.

NFT stands for non-fungible token. It’s generally built using the same kind of programming as cryptocurrency, like Bitcoin or Ethereum, but that’s where the similarity ends.

Physical money and cryptocurrencies are “fungible,” meaning they can be traded or exchanged for one another. They’re also equal in value—one dollar is always worth another dollar; one Bitcoin is always equal to another Bitcoin. Crypto’s fungibility makes it a trusted means of conducting transactions on the blockchain.

NFTs are different. Each has a digital signature that makes it impossible for NFTs to be exchanged for or equal to one another (hence, non-fungible).

Ubisoft may now be more than satisfied with all that Epic bribe money, while giving the loyal community it built here on Steam the middle finger. But I'll be damned if "Watch Dogs 2" is not an incredible game. I think I like it more than "GTA V" (I definitely like the characters better).

When I first played this game, I didn't love it so much, for I felt it was a little too grindy: the missions felt all the same. Go to a place, kill people, retrieve data, repeat. The story was strong, and so were the characters and the writing. The gameplay was fabulous, but the missions themselves were repetitive. Once I concluded the game, I moved on to other interests... but I couldn't help but to remember the game every once in a while. The characters, the dialogues, the moments... it was a lasting experience in that regard.

So, I decided to play the game again. And let me tell you, it becomes much better when you approach it for what it is: a stealth game. A game where you have to use all of the resources at your disposal before going for the gun. Because once you grab the gun... the game becomes boring.

Now, just to clarify, I've never actually played the infamous first game. There was so much bad publicity around it... I felt it wasn't worthy of my money (maybe I'll give it a go during a sale; maybe it's not that bad). But anyway, what I mean with this is that I'll be judging this game for what it is, without holding it to what its predecessor did.

As a stealth game, you have to think your next moves very carefully. And that sense of staying out of the sight of your enemies is what makes the game more gripping: the point of all your tools is to help you stay hidden and distract guards. And each mission becomes more challenging that way.

Unfortunately, the game seems to be always online, and I can't enjoy it for too long before someone jumps into my session and starts hacking me. The game also has this thing of designating the Esc button as a be-all, end-all key: it doesn't just pause the game. It also closes gadgets and skips dialogues. This may have been a way the developers found to make for more intuitive commands... but sometimes I forget about it and I end up skipping a dialogue or quitting a gadget just when I wanted to pause the game.

But otherwise, the game is great: it's beautiful looking, decently optimised (nothing like "GTA V", however) and its world is very immersive and realistic. The game also felt to me as a love letter to San Francisco itself: it really goes for broke in replicating the city's culture, history and architecture. And even if it's not as sprawling as other open world maps, the city has enough activities to keep you busy for a time.

Some of its puzzles are actually quite fun to complete, while others can be frustrating - you may need to have the proper tools before tackling them, but the game wouldn't tell you.

Last but certainly not least, there's the soundtrack. It's just one of the greatest game soundtracks I've heard in these last years - because the game is about computing and hacking, the original soundtrack goes for electronic music, which suits the game very well. Right from the start, you'll be mesmerised by the game's menu/pause theme.

Also, the radio music selection is great, with some very original choices. The game even allows players to do playlists, but it has this rather strange mechanic in which you can only carry songs with you once you "unlock" them with this Shazam-like app. I bet this sounded cool among the developers, but it's a nuisance.

It's very much a flawed gem of a game, that is rough around the edges, but that shines brightly nonetheless. I know that Ubisoft today may not deserve our consideration, but this game surely does, so get it on a sale. The game could have done what "Dishonored" did, by giving gamers different endings depending on their playstyle - that would really encourage them to go for stealth, rather than gunfire.

Like Watch_Dogs 1, the story itself is a bit meh. It tires to do a bit too much but it certainly still holds up and builds on the dystopian stuff in many regards. I think that 1 and 2 are good not for their actual main stories but for the believable future they try to show us where everything is connected and monitored. WD2 in specific does a good job with this by building on to the systems laid down in the first game and going more into the social media and data gathering aspect of it, showing how large companies can use data you let them collect for nefarious things. I also like that the whole point of the game is to gain followers and use social platforms as a means of raising a sort of radical follower base, with dedsec being something more akin to very redical 4chan users or something like that. Makes it a lot more believeable.

This is a game for clueless anarchist kiddies.  The basic premise of the game is that a bunch of anti-establishment hackers armed with guns and SMARTPHONES go around hacking the world to restore peoples privacy (a little bit) and make the world a better place (apparently).  The graphics and sound are good and it's a big open world game, but the way that terminals and objects are "hacked" is so completely ridiculous and so far removed from reality it makes me wonder if the writers actually went through more than 10 kilos of cocaine writing the story to this game.  This is yet another game pretending to be anti-establishment / anti-corporation that is anything but what it is selling itself as.  While this game may appeal to 10 year old brats, it's not going to appeal to adults because the story is utterly ridiculous - hacking with SMARTPHONES, having anti-establishment conversations around SMARTPHONES, doing dodgy stuff with SMARTPHONES all of which appear to be completely unmodified in any way - it's dumber than dumb it's 100% retarded to the point of being brain dead.  I just can't get into this game because the storyline is so painfully stupid it's just annoying to play and that's why I can't recommend it to other people.

I had a lot of fun playing this. Even thou it is from a big corporation, it seems like a lot of love was put into it. There were some minor bugs and occasionally some mechanics don't really click and the game forces you to use the intended solution, straight out blocking you from any "creative" attempts (usually not even that creative. Many missions could be completed just by the remote drone, but the game insists Marcus goes there personally.) The main characters are painted as a group of geeky hackers trying to expose lies and crimes of big corporations, but in reality, they are a terrorist organization with a huge body count, fighting the big corpo. More pacifist options would be nice.

But even thou there are issues with it, it is still incredibly fun game. Recommended.

Do not buy this game. It's just Watch_Dogs 1 but worse in every way, and that game was already not great. I have never seen such a genuinely impressively lazy game.

The Good:
- Acceptable gunplay with a surprisingly nuanced cover system.
- Multiplayer can be fun when it works.
- A couple cute character moments.

The Bad:
- Awful, inconsistent stealth and detection systems.
- Multiplayer frequently doesn't work and is plagued by cheaters when it does
- Token/pointless progression systems
- Tons of bugs
- No difficulty
- No room for creativity or skill expression in gameplay
- Boring open world objectives and collectathons
- Mission design that is at best lazy, and more often terrible
- Lame, stereotypical characters with little to no depth
- Poor story with poor pacing
- Such an intense obsession with political correctness that the game circles back around into bigotry with outright sexism, racism, and mocking views of the disabled in its attempts to be diverse.
- Hypocritical messages, and inconsistent morality.

The story is much better, but the gameplay is a major step back

-only 3 weapons can be equipped instead of always having whatever weapon you picked up or bought

-very small crashes from traffic lights compared to the first watch dogs

-blackout is now blockout

-no more crafting for different special items

-no enemies icons to display what specialty they are

-way too many enemies can call for reinforcements and you cant disable them like you could in the first game. You either have to kill them or jam their comms to stun them

-non lethal traps that are a worse option over lethal in every way

-police are now GTA and teleport in front of you, which makes road hacking pretty pointless. Speaking of which, there less things on the road to hack. No underground garages, less road barriers, no spike traps and the ground transformers aren't on the road. And the traffic light crashes are so small I could never, and I do mean never, use it to stop the police. Compared to the first watch dogs, the traffic lights were so good at stopping the police cars, that at almost every stoplight, the game would give you a prompt to perfectly time a stoplight crash that would cause the cop cars to crash into other cars. You could even just cause one while passing through without timing perfectly and it would still be enough to slow the police down thanks to the car pile-up.

This game saved my life.

I am 69.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiralling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

[h1]Hack the Planet[/h1]

I felt the need to start the review with a Retro (pun intended) quote from a very known famous hacker movie from the 90s. How else i was supposed to start this otherwise?

Damn, for the last few days i played this continuosly whenever i had time, it really glued onto me, i feel like a zombie because i decided that sleep is for pitiful mortals.
It's a scarily addictive game, with a very big open world with so much cool stuff to do, you never get bored. 
Ubisoft (I will have a rant at the beginning) always does manage to get really talented and creative people to work on their games, despite their awful treatment towards their customers.

If you played the first game and were unhappy with movement, car driving/handling, you will be very pleasantly surprised to know they really improved these things in WD2.
I honestly didn't expect it, but they fixed all that was wrong in the first game. Driving is a pure and smooth joy to do.

There's a lot to explore in the beautiful city of San Francisco, even if you got tired from seeing it in like 90% of Netflix's series and movies, exploring it in WD2 will be a delight.

All of that combined with lots of new gameplay features and elements create a very good gameplay experience that cannot possibily bore you out.

Difficulty is balanced, the leveling system is balanced, and one thing i loved about the game is that you can absolutely play it however you want, you can go guns blazing if that's your thing, although it will be hard, the game won't punish you, and the other characters in the game won't judge you.
If you decide to be a ghost, it will feel pretty rewarding, and as someone that loves anarchy and chaos, i was impressed by this aspect.

At times you will have to think out of the box, and figure things out. While it might be a bit frustrating, it will be worth it afterwards.

I really had a lot of fun in this game, there's simply a ton of fun activities to do besides the main mission, side missions and DLCs (Which i did all of 'em).

It has some really cool multiplayer features too, which you can disable if you really aren't into that, but before you do, give them a try. It's not a scary multiplayer system like in most games. It keeps things to a minimum, without much interaction, and it's perfect the way it is. I even found people randomly that helped me when i was stuck. And there's no chat either, so no griefing :)

Characters are well written (Love you, Wrench!), and while dialogues and some lines are a bit cringey and stupid, they're fun and feel pretty authentic.

Music is also very nice, you'll encounter good stuff from great names such as Culture Club, M|O|O|N, Prodigy, Naughty by Nature, Judas Priest, but also classics such as Mozart, Tchaikovsky, Chopin, if you're into that, and many other great artists and groups. They really did try to cover as many styles as possible.

Overall, story/gameplay, i absolutely recommend this game. It's tons of fun, with some interesting challenges, but properly balanced.

Now, the bad.

- Optimization is so bad, which, in my personal experience is like Ubi's artist signature. Game came out in 2016, and it's a lot worse optimized than Cyberpunk 2077
- Ubi has horrible practices when it comes to selling the game, basically a big middle finger to all the gamers and loyal customers. If you buy the game in CIS region, you only get Russian and Chinese languages. Trust me, almost nobody in Russia or CIS wants the localized version. These kinds of localizations are never good for an infinite numbers of reasons. It feels like a bootleg game. You can patch it, but it will take you a bit of time. But it's just awful to force people to use a BROKEN localization. If you are interested about this subject, Google around, people have been complaining about this ugly and bad business model of Ubi for years and years. Not to mention not everyone in the CIS region knows Russian (Although, the majority does).
- A ton of expensive DLCs, and they aren't really worth it. Feels like they wanted to milk the cow until she passed out and then they beat her with golf clubs.

Ubisoft hires amazing talent for writing, designing, and all the artistic stuff, but when it comes to coding or marketing, i swear to God, i think they hire people from Craigslist or something.
So, Ubi better make sure their artistic part of the company is treated properly, because if they'll walk away, Ubi will ultimately go down. They'll fall like the cow i mentioned above being thrown from a plane. 

Enough with cow analogies and random ramblings. 

Short version - Game is amazing, worth getting, everything that was awful and clunky in the first one is now fixed and things are smooth as butter.

If I had to pick which game Watch_Dogs (this or the original) I would choose as my favorite, I would hands-down choose Watch_Dogs 2. The cast of characters in this game just felt so much more alive and human compared to Aiden and the other characters in the original game. Of course, the tone of the game was much more dreary (much like Chicago), but that doesn't take away from the fact that I had much more fun with this game. The little interactions between Marcus and anyone else was the absolute best. The voice actors in this game did a FANTASTIC job! 

If there's one gripe I have about the campaign, it would be about a major character's death halfway through the game. For me, they were my favorite character, so to have them be killed in such a way was nothing short of tragic and heartbreaking. Of course, it's not like I don't want the punishment of death to exist in the story. So for one mission, we track down their killers and dispose them, but after this mission, WE DON'T EVER MUTTER THEIR NAME EVER AGAIN!? They were such a homie, and the fact that no one in the story so much as mentions their name after the fact just makes me sadder. I would have thought that they would have at least had a statement like "I wish xxx was here to see this" tossed their way at the end of the game. But nope. They are just lost to the winds of time, never to be talked about again. Actually tragic.

There is nothing more fun than getting the Police and the Gangs fighting each other to utter destruction, leaving you, dear reader, to pick up the remains at your leisure.  Hacking into a camera from a safe spot (not always possible) just makes it that much more entertaining when you sick the Bratva onto an unsuspecting rent-a-cop that makes over 100k a year.

Just for this, the game is well worth it.

Oh, and the best way to get around 'Frisco is on a motorcycle.
